book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, and in Him we seek help.

Abu Muhammad al-A'rabi said: I contemplated what Abu Muhammad Yusuf ibn al-Hasan ibn Abdullah al-Sirafi explained regarding the verses of Sibawayh's book, and I found him regarding them to be like what Jaz' ibn Dirar, the brother of al-Shammakh, said:

*I settled matters, then left behind me ... calamities in their sleeves that had not yet split open.*

This is because he explained only a drop from the ocean of the verses of that book, and even the little he explained contains much defect and clear corruption. It was as Bishr ibn Hakim, the brother of Banu Rabi'ah ibn Malik, said:

*Adi did not multiply among us so as to be feared ... nor was it good when I said: Adi's number is few.*

For there is a verse where he made a misspelling, and poetry he attributed to other than its speaker, and meaning he diverted from the path of correctness, and wording he shifted from its structures. So I have clarified the places of error in all of that, and established the correct version beneath each verse. I have dedicated this to the assembly of the Chief Abu Sa'id Bundar ibn Jahshtiyar, for he is the mine of literature and concerned with the knowledge of the Arabs. And success is through Allah, and He is my Sufficiency and the best Disposer of affairs.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Muzahim al-Uqayli said:
*And whoever sees a gift like what I have seen ... hardships will split him and exhaust him towards it.*
*And my passion for her is the passion of one who lost his camel ... at Nakhlah, upon whom the compassionate ones did not turn.*

S [The Author] said: This is the place of the proverb:
*They remained gathering [wood] at night upon a broken tree ... its driver is the slave and its water-provider is the bondmaid.*

Whoever explains this strange poetry without having thoroughly examined the obscure poetry of the Arabs, and without having mastered it with knowledge, is like one who gathers firewood in the hamd (saltwort) plant [blindly]. Ibn al-Sirafi advanced here what should have been delayed, and delayed what should have been advanced. Between the two verses are verses without which their organization cannot be put in order. The order of the verses is:
*And my passion for her is the passion of one who lost his camel ... at Bakka [Mecca], upon whom the compassionate ones did not turn.*
*He saw roughness from his two companions, and missed him ... at its sandy ground, the hasty, turning camels.*
*So they said: Do you know the stopping places of Mina? ... Not everyone who comes to Mina do I know.*
*And I did not forget from her the night of the valley-bend when she walked ... towards me, while my companions were dismounting and standing.*
*She extended fingertips to shake hands as if ... they were the daughters of the sand-dune [plants] which the winding sands leaned upon.*
*She reminds me of a gift, despite distance and enemies ... throughout the nights, and the cooing pigeons.*
*And two lovers frightened by separation, so of them ... is one striving, and one restricted, upon whom the chain rattles.*
*And whoever sees a gift like what I have seen ... hardships will split him and exhaust him towards it.*
*For the early riser going with the people there is a driver ... violent, and for the follower with the chain there is a stopper.*
*Like a spear of Marran wood, beneath its shadow ran ... a canal fed by the overflowing seas.*

S said: It is long, but sufficient for you from the necklace is what surrounds the neck.

Chapter of Masdars (Verbal Nouns)

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Sibawayh said in the Chapter of Masdars, Al-Marrar said:
*The family of al-Mughira knew that I ... attacked and did not recoil from striking, making [them] hear.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: "I found in this chapter the verse attributed to Al-Marrar, but I saw it in the poetry of Malik ibn Zaghbah al-Bahili. Banu Dubay'ah had raided Bahila, so Bahila caught up with them and defeated them."

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Will singing and riding heal the soul ... of a sickness within it when you have departed?*

What Ibn al-Sirafi mentioned hardly heals the one seeking benefit, especially since the little he mentioned is defective. The verse belongs to Malik ibn Zaghbah al-Bahili, referring to Misma' ibn Shayban, one of the Banu Qays ibn Tha'labah. He [Misma'] and Ibn Kadra' al-Dhuhli had gone out seeking blood revenge for those killed by Bahila from Bakr ibn Wa'il on the day Abu al-A'sha ibn Jandal was killed. This reached Bahila, so they met them and fought fiercely. Banu Qays and those with them from Banu Dhuhl were defeated, and Misma' ibn Shayban was struck and escaped wounded. The verse is the first of verses, the order of which is:
*The family of al-Mughira knew that I ... caught up and did not recoil from striking, making [them] hear.*
*And if my sword had not betrayed me [by breaking] its edge ... I would have left birds and hyenas to visit him.*
*And Ibn Kadra' al-Sadusi fled after ... I took a strip [of flesh/equipment] from him in the attack.*
*Did you come so that you might violate our sanctuary? ... So you encountered striking and mutilating stabbing.*
*So you returned disgraced, small, humiliated ... with spears interlaced together in your shoulders.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Akhwas al-Yarbu'i said:
*What you have caused regarding your brother will come to you ... companies from the horizons, diverse are their places of return.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*Ill-omened ones, not reformers of a clan ... nor cawing, except for separation, is their crow.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Na'b is the sound of the crow, and al-Na'ib is the crow. Al-Akhwas said this concerning a war that occurred between the clans of Banu Yarbu', in which Abu Badr al-Ghudani was killed. [He said this] in speech resembling this, which has no benefit.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Oh, would that my share of you was the one with the veil: That you do not harm me and do not benefit me.*

If Ibn al-Sirafi had remained silent about explaining this poetry, the story and order of which he did not know, it would have been more useful for his beneficiary. This is because he said: "This poetry was said concerning a war between the clans of Banu Yarbu'." However, the fighting was between Banu Yarbu' and Banu Darim. By saying "Ill-omened ones" (masha'im), the poet meant Banu Darim ibn Malik, not Banu Yarbu'.

The story of this poetry is that people from Banu Yarbu' and Banu Darim gathered at al-Qar'aa. A man from Banu Ghudanah, kunya Abu Badr, was killed among them. Banu Yarbu' said: "By Allah, we will not leave until we exact our revenge." Banu Darim said: "We do not know his killer, so establish a collective oath (qasamah) and we will give you your right." Banu Ghudanah said: "We will do so." They brought out fifty men. All of them swore except one man, that the one who killed Abu Badr was Ubayd ibn Zur'ah. The remaining one of the fifty said: "Will you not hand Ubayd over to us if I complete the fifty?" They said: "No, but we will pay his blood money because we do not know who killed him." The remaining one—who was Abu Bayd al-Ghudani—then said: "By Allah, I will never complete them, and Ubayd shall not part from us until we kill him."
Then Dirar ibn al-Qa'qa' ibn Ma'bad ibn Zur'ah and Shayban ibn Hanzalah ibn Bishr ibn Amr stood up and guaranteed Ubayd. Banu Ghudanah handed him over to them. When night covered them, Dirar and Shayban said to Ubayd: "Go wherever you wish."
In the morning, Banu Ghudanah went to Banu Darim and said to them: "Your companion has fled, but accept this blood money from your brothers, and do not seek other than that, lest you become like the one who cut off his own nose. If we knew the location of your companion, we would have gone to him."
When Al-Akhwas heard them mentioning the blood money, he said: "Let me speak." They said: "Speak, O Abu Khawlah." Al-Akhwas said:
*Yarbu' has no poverty regarding blood money (aql) ... nor is there filth from which their clothes would be blackened.*
*So how are the Sons of Malik [Banu Darim], if you forgive ... them this? Or how [will it be] after its abuse?*
*Ill-omened ones, not reformers of a clan ... nor cawing, except for bad omens, is their crow.*
*If you do not kill for your brother ... then be prostitutes, [carrying] their bags in their palms.*
*News of what you caused regarding your brother will tell ... companies from the horizons, diverse are their places of return.*

These are verses from which I mentioned what is indispensable regarding the meaning of the verse in the Book [Sibawayh].

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Ja'di said:
*And how can you communicate with one whose ... friendship has become like Abu Marhab?*

He said: Abu Marhab is one of his cousins, and I think he is from Banu Qushayr. He means that Abu Marhab cut him off and shunned him for a reason in which he needed him.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*You claimed the description of horses; you did not lead them ... nor did your ancestors lead them in times past.*

If Ibn al-Sirafi had limited himself to mentioning syntax and language, and had not exposed himself to mentioning men and genealogies, he would not have made himself a target for the tongues of critics. But the wretched one is slapped by every palm.
Abu Marhab here is the one who says to you when he meets you: "Ahlan wa Marhaban" (Welcome), and nothing else. Al-Ja'di's verse is similar in meaning to al-Kumayt's verse:
*He sees me in passing as a friend to him ... while the desert gazelle is frightened by the hunter.*
And like the saying of another:
*A friend who, as long as his eye is visible to you [he is a friend] ... but if he is absent, then beware of Da'laj.*
And like the saying of another:
*A friend of presence and a friend of the eye ... but for the one who is absent, he is not a friend.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Abu al-Aswad al-Du'ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said:
*If you come to a doorkeeper of his, he says: Marhaban (Welcome) ... Is not a welcoming, unconstricted valley your valley?*
He addresses the doorkeeper: Is not your valley, O doorkeeper, welcoming and unconstricted?

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*And how can one travel who has no camels?*

Often those who do not practice the science of genealogy stumble in a name like this, which is his saying: Abu al-Aswad al-Du'ali. The earlier grammarians used to say this, but it is not from their science. Abu al-Nada informed us, saying: He is Abu al-Aswad al-Dili. He said: His name is Zalim ibn Amr ibn Sufyan ibn Ya'mar ibn Hils ibn Nufathah ibn Adi ibn al-Dil ibn Bakr ibn Abd Manat ibn Kinanah.

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
He said: And in Rabi'ah: al-Dawl ibn Hanifah ibn Lujaym. In Azd: al-Dil ibn Haddad ibn Zayd Manat ibn al-Hajar. In Anazah: al-Dawl ibn Sabah ibn Atik ibn Aslam ibn Yadhkur ibn Anazah. In Taghlib: al-Dil ibn Zayd ibn Amr ibn Ghanm ibn Taghlib. In Dabbah: al-Dawl ibn Tha'labah ibn Sa'd ibn Dabbah. In al-Rabab: al-Dawl ibn Jala ibn Adi ibn Abd Manat. In Abd al-Qays: al-Dil ibn Amr ibn Wadi'ah ibn Lukayz ibn Afsa. In al-Hun: al-Du'il - with Hamza, on the pattern of al-Du'al - ibn Muhallim ibn Ghalib ibn A'idhah ibn Yathi' ibn Malih ibn al-Hun ibn Khuzaimah. In Iyad: al-Dil ibn Umayyah ibn Hudhafah ibn Zuhayr ibn Iyad. In Azd: al-Dawl ibn Sa'd Manat ibn Ghamid. In Qays: al-Dil ibn Himar ibn Naj ibn Abi Malik ibn Ikrimah.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Marrar said:
*You cut off [relations] but were not cut off, and you are cutting ... and how can one who is called forbearing play the youth?*
*And you turned away, and prolonged the turning away, and rarely ... does union last with prolonged turning away.*

He said: He says you cut off this woman before she cut you off, addressing himself. Then he said: And how can one who has grown old and forbearing act like a youth? And this woman turned away, and you prolonged the turning away, and with prolonged turning away, nothing of affection and love remains. This is how I saw it explained.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*O people of virtue, let her pass ... for you are but Nabateans and donkeys.*

This is among the most disgraceful things Ibn al-Sirafi came up with, for this poetry is not of the obscure kind that confuses anyone. The correct reading is: *Sadadti* (You [feminine] turned away) and you prolonged the turning away. The organization of the verses is:
*You cut off but were not cut off, and you are cutting ... and how can one who is called forbearing play the youth?*
He says: You cut off but were not cut off with a permanent cutting, but rather a cutting of coquetry.
*You turned away and prolonged the turning away, and I do not see ... a union that lasts with prolonged turning away.*
It is as if he is addressing himself and blaming her [the woman] for the prolonged turning away. Meaning, the union of beautiful women does not last except for one who sticks to them and submits to them. This is explained by the two verses after them, which are:
*Beautiful women are not for roughness, nor for him who ... has concerns that distract him from demanding their debt.*
*But rather, the promise is fulfilled for a follower ... of their desires, one who swears to them, a sinner.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Marrar said:
*I am the son of the one who left the Bakri, Bishr ... the birds upon him, watching for him to fall.*
The position of "watching him" is accusative as a state (Hal), meaning watching his death to eat him.
*He struck him with a blow that sent by night ... his wailing women, and made the 'budu' (flesh/women) cheap.*

He said: He meant Bishr ibn Amr ibn Marthad, and a man from Banu Asad killed him, so al-Marrar boasted of his killing. Bishr refers to [the tribe of] Bakr ibn Wa'il. "And made the 'budu' cheap": meaning the blow made the flesh cheap for the birds. Some narrators claimed that by 'budu' he means the sexual organs (budu') of his women, i.e., their marriage. He says: When they killed him, they captured his women and married them without a dowry. And 'budu' means marriage. The first explanation is more pleasing to me.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*I became, from the memory of a purple [cloth], like ... one who sends water and holds back the foam.*

How often Ibn al-Sirafi favors the bad over the good, and the counterfeit over the permissible. This is because he inclined to the saying that 'budu' here means flesh. By my life, if they were the flesh of goats and camels, it would be permissible for cheapness and expensiveness to apply to them; this is complete stupidity. The correct meaning is that when they killed him, they exposed his women to captivity, because there remained no one for them to protect them and defend them. Furthermore, he did not mention the killer of Bishr, from which of the tribes of Banu Asad he was. If the truth of this is not known, it is not known why al-Marrar boasted about it.
His killer was Sab' ibn al-Has-has al-Faq'asi, and the leader of the army, the army of Banu Asad that day, was Khalid ibn Nadlah al-Faq'asi, who is the grandfather of al-Marrar ibn Sa'id ibn Habib ibn Khalid ibn Nadlah.
The story of this day—the Day of Qilab—is that a clan from Banu al-Harith ibn Tha'labah ibn Dudan raided, led by Khalid ibn Nadlah ibn al-Ashtar ibn Jahwan ibn Faq'as. They said to a soothsayer of theirs: "Look, does your companion [jinn] inform you about water?" He covered himself with his garment, and his devil came to him and said: "Ride a high [horse] and a galloping [horse], and measure the earth in miles, for you will see tall hills, and between them is water/moisture." So they put a man of theirs on one of the two horses, and he galloped it, and found hills with a pond of rainwater between them. So the people drank and watered [their animals] and ate dates from their provisions. Bishr ibn Amr came across their tracks and said: "These are the tracks of Banu Asad." When they reached the water, he said: "Look at what they do with the date stones. If it is Banu Asad, they throw the stones behind them, and if it is Tamim, they throw the stones in front of them."

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
When they found the place where their date stones were thrown, he said: "These are Banu al-Harith ibn Tha'labah. One of them captures the woman's hair braids and demands a hundred [camels] as ransom. Charge the people!" His son said to him: "Among Banu al-Harith ibn Tha'labah are Banu Faq'as, and if you meet them, you meet [real] fighting." He said: "Be silent, for your face resembles your mother's face at the time of entry [wedding]." So the people proceeded.
When they met, Bishr's army was defeated. The cavalry pursued him—and he was a man of fine horses—until three horsemen followed in his tracks, closely spaced. The first was Sab' ibn al-Has-has al-Faq'asi, the middle one was Amilah ibn al-Muqtabis al-Walibi, and the last was Khalid ibn Nadlah. The arrow of al-Walibi, the middle one, reached Bishr ibn Amr's horse; he shot it and hamstrung it. Sab' caught up to him and grappled him. Khalid came and said: "O Sab', do not kill him, for we do not seek blood revenge from him, and he has much wealth, and he is a master of his people." So they sat him between them, and al-Walibi withdrew. The cavalry came to them; whenever a man passed by him, he ordered them to kill him, until some of the people began to threaten him, so Khalid drove them away. Then a man intended to direct his spear at him, so Khalid rose on his knees and said: "Keep away from my prisoner!" Sab' became angry that Khalid claimed him, so Sab' thrust [his sword] into Bishr's throat, and he fell on his back. He grabbed his leg and followed the sword through the opening of the armor until he pierced his liver. Bishr said: "Protect my trousers, for I did not shave [my pubes]." Then he released him, went to his horse, and led it away. He said when he killed him, while angry: "[He is] your prisoner and your father's prisoner!"
Al-Khirniq said, mocking Abd Amr ibn Bishr when he incited against Tarafa and al-Mutalammis:
*Why did you not kill Ibn Has-has and Khalid ... there? You did not kill there and you did not signal.*
*They stabbed your father in the opening of his armor ... and you turned away, not looking back, fleeing into a hole.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Miskin al-Darimi said:
*And the cousin of a man, know, is his wings ... and does the falcon rise without wings?*
*Your brother, your brother! For he who has no brother ... is like one rushing to battle without a weapon.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*He zig-zags me with deceit ... He sees me, I do not think [he sees me].*
Ibn al-Sirafi advanced from the two verses what should have been delayed, and delayed what should have been advanced. The correct order is:
*Your brother, your brother! For he who has no brother ... is like one rushing to battle without a weapon.*
*And the cousin of a man, know, is his wings ... and does the falcon rise without wings?*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-A'sha said:
*I see a man among them, sorrowful/angry, as if ... he presses to his flanks a dyed hand.*
*And he has no ancient glory, nor does he have ... any advantage from the wind, neither the South wind nor the East wind.*

He said: It is as if, from the intensity of his anger, his hand has been cut off, so he presses his hand to his sides while it is cut off. He says: This man looks at me with the look of an angry person as if I have cut off his hand. "And he has no ancient glory"—meaning he has no old nobility—"nor does he have any advantage from the wind"—meaning he has no power in any direction. This is how I saw it explained. He satirizes thereby Amr ibn al-Mundhir and his people, who are cousins of Al-A'sha.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*And he who Hudhaym tends his sheep ... is confessing to the wolf and the forced war.*

Whoever relies on this amount mentioned by Ibn al-Sirafi has not benefited much, because he did not mention the story that caused this admonition and satire. The cause of that was that a man from Qays Aylan was a neighbor to Amr ibn al-Mundhir ibn Abdan ibn Hudhaqah ibn Habib ibn Tha'labah ibn Qays ibn Tha'labah. A riding camel of his was stolen, and some of its meat was found in the house of Haddaj, Al-A'sha's leader. He was beaten while Al-A'sha was sitting. So he said, admonishing them in the poem from which these verses are taken.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: And Al-A'sha said:
*We are the horsemen on the day of al-Hinu, appearing ... on the two sides of Futaymah, neither inclining nor unarmed.*

He said: Futaymah here is Futaymah bint Sharahil ibn Awsajah from Banu Qays ibn Tha'labah, the people of Al-A'sha. She had two sons from a man not of her people called Asram. Asram wanted to take her two sons and pledge them to Yazid ibn Mushir al-Shaybani. She sought help from her people, so they gathered and defeated Banu Shayban, and Al-A'sha boasted of that. Al-Hinu is the bend of the valley.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*I said when they emerged from a peak ... The donkey lied, even if he passed form the left [bad omen].*
Meaning the horse and the camel. This is impossible, because Futaymah is the daughter of Habib ibn Tha'labah ibn Sa'd ibn Qays ibn Tha'labah. And al-Hinu here is a specific place, which is Hinu Qaraqir, mentioned by Al-A'sha in his saying:
*Ransom for Banu Dhuhl ibn Shayban is my she-camel ... and her rider on the day of meeting, and I said [it].*
*They struck at al-Hinu, the Hinu of Qaraqir ... the front of the Hamarz until it turned away.*
And Qaraqir is one of the waters of Bakr ibn Wa'il.

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
Ibn al-Sirafi said: Humayd al-Arqat said—and he used to satirize the guest when he stayed with him:
*And destitute ones upon the saddles, their clothing ... is ragged garments and cloaks in which there is variety.*
*They spent the night while our baskets of Shahriz [dates] were between them ... as if their fingernails were knives in them.*
*So they reached morning with the date stones topping their stopping place ... and not all the date stones do the poor throw away.*

He said: His saying "not all the date stones do the poor throw away" means that whoever is intensely hungry and in need of food, and has nothing to spend, should eat the date with the stone to become satisfied sooner, and not eat many dates. Humayd meant that his guests ate the dates with their stones and did not throw any of them away.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*And does anyone know the diseases except their doctor?*

Ibn al-Sirafi did not know the counterparts of these verses, nor did he explain the verse he interpreted regarding the stones and the poor well. Such poetry is not known except by one who has matured in investigating poetry and cared for it. The order of the verses is:
*And destitute ones upon the saddles, their clothing ... is bags and cloaks in which there is variety.*
*Presenting noses in their bands ... hooked; may those noses be cut off.*
*They were given veiling in a group when they rushed ... and every good upon them afterwards is stored away.*
*No welcome to the faces of the people when they departed ... as if they were, when they came to me, the jars of devils.*
*They write news for us when they dismount ... and everything they wrote is an enablement for swallowing [food].*
*And if you protected yourself where the gazelle takes refuge ... or where the wild cow licks its young.*
*I thought their hospitality would not end from us ... until we are, while our starting place is the gardens.*
*A land in which eagles hover, growing ... from where the date stalks grow in the summer.*
*They spent the night while our baskets of Shahriz [dates] were between them ... as if their fingernails were knives in them.*
*So they reached morning with the date stones topping their stopping place ... and not all the date stones do the poor throw away.*

The meaning of this last verse is that they ate most of the dates with their stones out of greed and gluttony, and despite that, they piled up their stopping place with the stones they threw. By "the poor" (al-masakin), he means these guests, as if they piled up: meaning they made a pile for themselves. He pointed to them and said: "And not all the date stones do the poor throw away." This pointing is like the saying of another:
*The lightning rose from the direction of Hejaz and thrilled me ... and for every Hejazi, the lightning is thrilling.*
Meaning *this* lightning specifically.

Abu al-Nada informed us, saying: A messenger from al-Hajjaj stayed with Humayd al-Arqat, so he hosted him and honored him. When he brought the food, a Bedouin approached, greeted, and sat down, and began asking about al-Hajjaj and his condition. Humayd al-Arqat said to him: "Eat and let the man feed, for you are asking about what is not your concern."
And Humayd said:
*When we hosted the one coming from the city among them ... a yellow-bowl returning [guest] came to my fire.*
*My fire appeared to him at the canopies of the sanctuary ... while Wadi al-Salib was between us and al-Afakil.*

He said: And he informed us, may Allah have mercy on him, saying: The misers of Mudar are: Al-Hutay'ah, Al-La'in al-Minqari, Humayd al-Arqat, and Abu al-Aswad al-Dili.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: And Tufayl al-Ghanawi said:
*And Huraym was a successor from Sinan ... and Hisn, and from Asma' when they disappeared.*
*And from Qays, the one staying at Rumman is his house ... and on the day of Huqayl, another pleasing one died.*
*And at al-Sahb, one of auspicious nature, his saying ... to the seeker of favor is 'Family and Welcome' [Ahlan wa Marhaban].*

He said: These are a group of Tufayl's people who perished, so he eulogized them. Rumman is a specific place, and he meant by his house his grave. Huqayl is a known place. Fada means died. Al-Sahb is the open space of the land. [He said this] amidst nonsense resembling this.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Little sufficiency from old women of hunger ... papers in their bellies are lines.*

What Ibn al-Sirafi mentioned does not avail a wick's worth. It is known that these are men not camels, and these are places not saddle-pads. But if the story of these men and their days, and the names of these places specifically and what happened in them are not known, the meaning is not complete. In the first verse there is a mistake, and in the third a misspelling. The correct version is:
*And Sinan was a successor of Huraym*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
By placing Sinan before Huraym, because Huraym is the dead one, and Sinan is Sinan ibn Amr ibn Yarbu' ibn Tarif ibn Kharshabah ibn Ubayd ibn Sa'd ibn Ka'b ibn Hallan ibn Ghanm ibn Ghani. He was a noble horseman, had led and commanded, and he is the companion of Ibn Hadm al-Absi, the king's fugitive. The king asked him: "How did you kill him?" He said: "I charged at him in the *Kubba* (main body of the army), and stabbed him in the *Subba* (anus/buttocks), until the spear came out of the *Labbah* (throat pit)." Huraym is Sinan's uncle, and he had led and commanded.
Asma' ibn Waqid is from Banu Riyah ibn Yarbu' ibn Tha'labah ibn Sa'd ibn Awf ibn Ka'b ibn Hallan ibn Ghanm ibn Ghani, and he is one of the stars [famous figures].
Hisn is Ibn Yarbu' ibn Tarif, and his mother is Jayda' bint Amr ibn al-A'raj ibn Malik ibn Sa'd ibn Awf.
Qays is the son of Yarbu' ibn Tarif. This Qays came to some kings, and the king said: "I will surely place my crown on the noblest of the Arabs," so he placed it on Qays's head, and gave him what he wished, then let him go to his country. Tayy met him at Rumman while he was returning to his family and killed him. Then they recognized him later, and remembered favors he had done for them, so they regretted it. They buried him and built a house [tent/structure] over him. He is Qays ibn Jayda', she being his mother. His brothers are Huraym, Amr, Hisn, and Al-A'raj; their mother is Jayda' bint Amr, and their father is Yarbu' ibn Tarif.
Huqayl is in the land of Banu Asad; in it, Banu Asad killed Al-Harith ibn Muwaylik al-Ghanawi. In the land of Ukl there is also a Huqayl, which is other than this place, and it is the one mentioned by Al-Ra'i: *From Dhu al-Abariq when they grazed Huqayl.*
His saying "wa bi al-Sahb" (and at al-Sahb) is a misspelling. The correct reading is: *Wa bi al-Shahd* (And at al-Shahd), meaning Budayl ibn Waqid. Asma' and Budayl, the sons of Waqid, were men of battles against Tayy. They killed ten men, each of whom carried the banner of his people, called Banu Hamal. A sister of theirs said eulogizing them:
*O eye, weep for Banu Hamal ... hero horsemen in the intensity of fright.*
*By my life, and my life is not easy to me ... Ghani has indeed taken from us ibn Waqid quietly.*
*If the days lead Ghanm ibn Waqid ... Asma' is straightened by spears again and again.*
Then Tayy met Ghani and captured Budayl, who was a master and chief. He feared that Tayy would mutilate him because of the losses he inflicted on them. Mirdas ibn Muwaylik was striving in his matter to ransom him, but they refused. So he killed himself, and they killed Asma'. Mirdas ibn Muwaylik said eulogizing Budayl:
*My female friend complains to me of fatigue and weariness ... and you forget what the prisoner of chains suffers.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Shaqiq ibn Jaz' al-Bahili said, replying to Jahl ibn Nadlah al-Bahili:
*Do you threaten me with your people, O Ibn Jahl ... mixed groups who are thought to be slaves (al-Ibad)?*
*With what you gathered of Hadan and Amr ... and what are Hadan and Amr and the Ji'ad (horses)?*
*If Banu Sa'd strutted behind me ... and defended me with spears, a [true] defense.*

He said: *Yukhaluna* (they are thought) means they are thought to be slaves. Hadan, Amr, and al-Ji'ad are tribes.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Turn back to your family, O old woman ... for the selling of the night does not pass.*

This is the most disgraceful thing Ibn al-Sirafi came up with. He stated that al-Ji'ad is a tribe, and this indicates complete stupidity and obvious ignorance. Al-Ji'ad (steeds) here are noble horses. He says: What do these have to do with noble horses? Meaning they are not horsemen of noble horses. His saying: "He meant by al-Ibad here slaves" is also an error. By al-Ibad, he meant people who used to gather at the gate of al-Nu'man, servants from every tribe. He likened these people to those, meaning they are mixed breeds.
The first verse also contains confusion, which is his saying: "Do you threaten me with your people, O Ibn Jahl," while the address is to Jahl himself, not his son, so how can he say O Ibn Jahl? The correct reading is: *Do you threaten me with your clan, O Juhayl (little Jahl)?*
In the verses he cited, there is advancing and delaying and much defect. They will come to you in their order with the help of Allah.
Jahl ibn Nadlah said answering Shaqiq ibn Jaz' al-Bahili:
*Your soul made you wish, O Ibn Jaz' ... foolish things that will become difficult upon execution.*
*You wanted to scatter the affair of a people ... and you attempted severance and corruption.*
*So gently, O Shaqiq, for my war ... is corruption for the one who ignites it.*
*And how many a group have fought us ... I prepared for them a determined, loud-voiced [battalion].*
*It was nothing but that they saw its flash ... so its clarity was horses returning.*
*Upon them from Banu Amr are mature men ... and youths shaking the spears.*
*So they remained stitching them with brown [spears] ... as locusts are strung in baskets.*
*So they returned with the men bent over ... driving the newly gained wealth and the old.*
*And your help is far from me, slow ... as if you have a steed [rushing] to abandon me.*

So Shaqiq ibn Jaz' answered him and said:

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*My steeds roamed freely over your lands ... and brought back from you sturdy, strong camels.*
*Because you did not thank the favor I did ... and if you wish, we will return again.*
*Do you hope to equal the tribe of A'ya ... and Sahb? What you hope has failed and increased [in failure].*
*With what you gathered of Hadan and Amr ... mixed groups who are thought to be slaves (al-Ibad).*
*If Banu Sa'd strutted behind me ... and defended me with spears, a [true] defense.*
*You saw death before me, so you desisted ... and its strong pillars did not rise.*
*Do you threaten me with your clan, O Juhayl ... and what are Amr ibn Hisn and the steeds?*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Sibawayh said: Durna bint 'Ab'abah from Banu Qays ibn Tha'labah said. But what I found is: Durna bint Sayyar ibn Sabrah ibn Hattan ibn Sayyar ibn Amr ibn Rabi'ah said:
*And they claimed that I panicked over them both ... and is it panic if I said: O father of them both!*
*They are the two brothers in war for one who has no brother ... if he fears a calamity one day and calls them.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Between the obedient and the turning rebel.*

This explanation confuses a person, so he does not know right from wrong, and does not know to which one it relates: to Durna bint 'Ab'abah, or to Durna bint Sayyar? This indicates that he could not conceptualize the lean from the fat regarding them. The correct one is: Durna bint Sayyar according to the second lineage. She said [this] eulogizing her two brothers. They are pleasing verses, the order of which—as Ibn al-Sirafi recited them—has entered into defect. Their order and completion is:
*People refused except to say: It is them, it is them ... and if we were able, they would be other than them.*
*They are the two brothers in war for one who has no brother ... if he fears a calamity one day and calls them.*
*If they became poor, they did not beg for fear of death ... and a client did not fear a loss from them.*
*If they became rich, love of everyone was towards them ... and the surplus of their wealth was generous to the closest ones.*
*They wear glory in the best clothing ... stingy with what they are able to [protect of honor], both of them.*
*And they claimed that I panicked over them both ... and is it panic if I said: O father of them both!*
*And my family is a ransom for the two protectors, both of them ... and may I not live if the heart hated them.*
*If they descended into a land where death is feared ... their blade-edges calm their anxiety.*
*And the two thrones do not delay to be pulled from them ... the bones of the anchors [mountains/leaders] if their covering tilts.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Jarir said:
*Leave the road for the one who builds the lighthouse on it ... and go out with Barza where fate compels you.*

He said: Barza is the mother of Umar ibn Laja'.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Wardan farted in a bare land.*

This is false. Abu al-Nada, may Allah have mercy on him, informed us saying: Barza is one of the grandmothers of Umar ibn Laja', [one of] the singing women.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: The Rajiz said:
*Are you, O Basita, the one whom I feared ... would be my companion in the midday nap?*
*You certainly knew which time was my obstacle.*
*She is the one who said at the midday heat ... when the stars in the sky turned away.*

He said: Al-Basita is the flat, extended land.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*He is not called for help except her brother.*

Ibn al-Sirafi erred here previously, because he did not know the stopping places of the Arabs and their locales. Whoever interprets such poetry without mastering three types of knowledge—Genealogy, Days of the Arabs (History), and their Locales and Stopping Places—his mistakes multiply. Basita here is a specific land, which is between Kufa and al-Hazn, the rugged ground of Banu Yarbu' ibn Amr. Regarding it, Adi ibn Amr al-Ta'i says:
*Were it not for the burning of what their stepping scatters ... on Basita, the eyes would not have caught up with them.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Tharwan ibn Fazarah ibn Abd Yaghuth said:
*For you will not mind after a year ... whether a gazelle was your mother or a donkey.*
*The lowest have caught up with the highest ... and baseness surged and the lineage mixed.*

He said: What is in the Book [Sibawayh] is: *Whether a gazelle was your mother or a donkey*. But what is in his poetry is: *Whether a gazelle was your maternal uncle or a donkey*.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*He was a donkey, then he became a she-donkey.*

How can a donkey and a gazelle be mothers when they are the most masculine of animals? Even the proverb is struck with the donkey, as it is said: *Who copulates with the wild ass copulates with a great copulator.* The correct version is what Abu al-Nada, may Allah have mercy on him, recited:
*Whether a gazelle copulated with your mother or a donkey.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
The phrase was inverted only out of embarrassment/piety (taharruj), in my opinion, and then the grammarians cited it according to its apparent [sanitized] form. This is a curious piece, which Abu al-Nada dictated to us, mentioning it is by Tharwan ibn Fazarah ibn Abd Yaghuth ibn Zuhayr ibn Rabi'ah ibn Amr ibn Amir. It is:
*And how many people of a dwelling have I seen ... a leader called them, so they marched.*
*So their era became like the clipping-place of a horn ... no eye perceives [them] nor a trace.*
*Maqass* (Clipping place): A place where the land is tracked/clipped. Meaning no trace is found for them or their era, just as no trace is found of one walking on a rock or a horn of a mountain.
*You have exchanged people after people ... so there is no wonder in that and no mockery.*
*For it will not harm you after a year ... whether a gazelle copulated with your mother or a donkey.*
*The lowest have caught up with the highest ... and the people surged and the lineage mixed.*
*And the Find (mountain/fool) returned like Abu Qubays ... and the ten-month pregnant camels were driven with the mongrel [female].*
Metonymy for the low man. Abu Qubays: The noble man. Al-Mu'lahajah: The one of corrupt lineage. Meaning this mongrel female married and was given the dowry of a noble woman. This is how Abu al-Nada recited it to us: *And the Find returned*. The people's recitation is *The Slave*, and Abu al-Nada mentioned that is a misspelling.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Zarafa al-Bahili said:
*Is it in the judgment that if you became wealthy ... and secure, then I am the distant stranger?*
*And if there is a hateful event, I am called for it ... and if the Hays (date/butter dish) is stirred, Jundub is called.*
*This, by your life, is humiliation itself ... no mother for me if that is so, and no father.*
*Wonder at that judgment! And my staying ... among you upon that judgment is more wonderful.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*And where is the face/life from the land of the Muslim?*
What is between the correct [view] and what Ibn al-Sirafi mentioned in these verses is [like]:
*Further than Rahwah from Nisah*
And Nisah is without nunation (tanwin). Rahwah is in Najd, and Nisah is in Yamama.
This is because he claimed that these verses belong to Al-Zarafa al-Bahili, but Allah did not create anyone in Bahila named Zarafa. Yes, in Banu Asad there is a poet called Zarafa, and he is the one who said:
*And whoever does not attain until he blocks his gap ... finds the desires of the soul not few.*
Abu Ubaydah mentioned in the *Book of the Disobedient and Obedient* that these verses belong to Hani ibn Ahmar al-Kinani. Abu al-Nada denied that and said: They belong to Amr ibn al-Ghawth ibn Tayy. I had mentioned to you that whoever does not master the science of genealogy and days and stopping places of the Arabs, then proceeds to interpret such ancient poetry, will be disgraced.
Abu al-Nada, may Allah have mercy on him, dictated to us saying: While Tayy was sitting one day with his son in the Two Mountains (Aja and Salma), a man from the remnants of Jadis approached, extended in build, of ancient nature, almost blocking the horizon in height and exceeding them in reach. It was al-Aswad ibn 'Affar ibn al-Sabur al-Jadisi, who escaped from Hassan Tubba' on the day of Yamama. He caught up to the Two Mountains and said to Tayy: "Who brought you into my lands and my inheritance from my fathers? Leave them, or else I will do such and such." Tayy said: "The lands are ours and our possession is in our hands; I only claimed them when I found them empty." Al-Aswad said: "Set a time between us and you to fight. Whichever of us wins deserves the land." So they agreed on a time.
Tayy said to Jundub ibn Kharijah ibn Sa'd ibn Fitrah ibn Tayy—and his mother was Jadilah bint Subay' from Himyar, and they are known by her; they are Jadilah Tayy, and Tayy favored her—he said to this Jundub: "Fight for your honor." His mother said: "By Allah, you will leave your [other] sons alone, and expose my son to killing. He shall not do it." Tayy said: "Woe to you, I only singled him out for that." But she refused.
Then Tayy said to Amr ibn al-Ghawth ibn Tayy: "Then you, O Amr, take the man and fight him." Amr said: "I will not do it." And he began to recite saying regarding that—and he was the first to speak poetry in Tayy after Tayy—:
*O Tayy, inform me, for you are not a liar ... and your brother is your truthful one who does not lie.*
*Is it from the judgment that if you became wealthy ... and secure, then I am the distant stranger?*
*And if hardships, with hardships, once ... force you into holes, then I am the nearest beloved?*
*Wonder at that judgment! And my staying ... among you upon that judgment is more wonderful.*
*And for you together are the good waters and their pasture ... and for me the shallow water holes and their barren pasture.*
*This, by your life, is humiliation itself ... no mother for me if that is so, and no father.*
*And if there is a hateful event, I am called for it ... and if the Hays is stirred, Jundub is called.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
The last verse became a proverb. He means Jundub ibn Kharijah ibn Sa'd ibn Fitrah ibn Tayy. Then Tayy said: "O my son, it is the noblest abode among the Arabs." Amr said: "I will not do it except on a condition: that the sons of Jadilah have no share in the Two Mountains." Tayy said to Amr ibn al-Ghawth: "You have your condition." The sons of Jadilah are Jundub and Hor, sons of Jadilah bint Subay' of Himyar; she is their mother, and their father is Kharijah ibn Sa'd ibn Fitrah ibn Tayy. As for Hor, he perished with no offspring, and the number of Banu Jadilah refers back to the two sons of Jundub; they are Jadilah Tayy.
Al-Aswad ibn 'Affar al-Jadisi came to the appointment carrying a bow of iron and arrows of iron. He said: "O Amr, if you wish I will wrestle you, and if you wish I will shoot with you, otherwise I will race you." Amr said: "Wrestling is more pleasing to me. Break your bow so I may break mine too and we wrestle." Amr ibn al-Ghawth ibn Tayy had with him a bow connected with rings (zarafin); if he wished, he could tighten it. Amr motioned with it towards the mountain and the rings opened. Al-Aswad struck the mountain with his bow and arrows and broke it. When Amr saw that, he took his bow, assembled it, strung it, and called out to him: "O Aswad, seek help from your bow, for shooting is dearer to me." Al-Aswad said: "You deceived me?" Amr said: "War is deception." It became a proverb. Amr shot him and split his heart.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Mundhir ibn Dirham al-Kalbi said:
*And the newest covenant from Aminah was a glance ... at the side of the highland when I was standing.*
*She says: Mercy! What brought you here? ... Are you a possessor of lineage [here] or do you know the tribe?*

He said: The estimation is "What thing brought you here?" "A possessor of lineage" means: Are you a relative in the tribe, or do you know them so you intend [to visit] them?

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*I say to Layla: My leg is for me, and my lock of hair ... is the remainder of what Husayn ibn Murajjiḥ left.*
Here is a remaining meaning that is not complete except by knowing the third verse, which is:
*So I said: I am a possessor of need and a submitter ... so the constricted predicament closed upon us.*
These are curious verses, recited by Abu al-Nada for Mundhir ibn Dirham al-Kalbi. The beginning is:
*Is it from the love of Umm al-Ashyamayn and her memory ... your heart is lovesick for her or committing [sin]?*
*I wished for her until I wished that I be seen ... from passion, a dog familiar with the two Wakis.*
*May a cloud traveling from the end of the night, following ... water the garden of al-Muthri and its people from us.*
*I say, while I have no need in my frequenting ... other than her, to the people of the garden: Are you turning [favorably]?*
*And the newest covenant from Aminah was a glance ... at the side of the highland when I was standing.*
*She says: Mercy! What brought you here? ... Are you a possessor of lineage [here] or do you know the tribe?*
*So I said: I am a possessor of need and a submitter ... so the constricted predicament closed upon us.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Qays ibn Dharih said:
*You weep for Lubna while you left her ... and you were more capable over her at al-Mala.*
*If the world turned over with Lubna ... then for Time and the World are bellies and backs.*

He said: His saying "Then for Time and the World are bellies and backs" means that in the world, a human only sees its exteriors, and does not know what is in its consequences.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*And you practiced matters without prudence ... so you do not know whether it is lean or fat.*
Ibn al-Sirafi did not know the third of the two verses, which is the answer to his saying: "If the world..." The correct reading in his saying "fa-lil-dahr" is "wa-lil-dahr" (And for Time) with a Waw. He thought that was the answer/apodosis, but it is the completion of the hemistich, a parenthetical statement between "If" (In) and its answer. The verses are:
*You weep for Lubna while you left her ... and you were more capable over her at al-Mala.*
Meaning of "you were more capable over her": he was deceived regarding her until he divorced her, so he regretted divorcing her.
*If the world turned over with Lubna ... and for Time and the World are bellies and backs.*
Meaning of "bellies and backs": hardship and ease.
*[Then] there was in her a place for trust ... and a seeking-place for the hand and a view for the eye.*
*And for the hovering thirsty one, a quenching that nourishes him ... and for the trailing joyful one, wine and intoxicant.*
*As if I am in a swing between ropes ... whenever a memory of her strikes the ground.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Amir ibn al-Tufayl said:
*They said to her: We chased his horses ... Qulah al-Kilab, and you were not chased.*
*So I will seek you at Qana and Awarid ... and I will advance the horses to the lava field of Dharghad.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
He said: His saying "They said to her" refers to a woman he loved from Banu Fazarah called Asma'. He means that Banu Fazarah told her that they defeated him and chased him away. There was a battle between Banu Fazarah and Banu Amir that went against Banu Amir, in which a group was killed. Dharghad is a known place.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*You will not catch the horses while you walk fast ... except with a passing like the passing of the falcon.*

The meaning of this poetry is not known except by knowing the Days (battles) related to it. Furthermore, if Dharghad, Qana, and Awarid are not known specifically—in which place of Allah's lands they are—the addressee of his speech is not known. Amir said this on the Day of al-Raqam, the day Banu Murrah defeated them. Amir fled, and his brother al-Hakam ibn al-Tufayl strangled himself. On that day, Uqbah ibn Anis ibn Khulays al-Ashja'i killed one hundred and fifty men from Banu Amir; he drove them into the ravine of al-Raqam and slaughtered them, so Uqbah was named that day "The Slaughterer" (Mudhabbih). Qana and Awarid are two mountains in the land of Banu Fazarah. About them al-Shammakh ibn Dirar says:
*As if she, when Awarid appeared ... was an Adbiyyu (white antelope) obscure in the mirage.*
*And the night is crouching between the two Qanas ... at the side of the valley are sandgrouse rising.*
The addressees of Amir's poetry are Banu Murrah and Fazarah. Asma' is Asma' al-Sukayniyyah from Banu Fazarah; Amir loved her and wrote love poetry (ghazal) about her, and he had committed adultery with her. About her he says:
*Are you dismounting, Asma', or not dismounting? ... Clarify to us, O Asm, what you are doing.*
Kharashah al-Absi says about her on the Day of al-Raqam:
*So who will convey from me to my friend Amir ... Have you been consoled regarding Asma' or are you remembering?*
*For behind the valley bend are gazelles of a thicket ... their ears and helmet-liners perfumed.*
Dharghad is one of the waters of Banu Murrah.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Khufaf ibn Nudbah said, and it is said Abbas ibn Mirdas:
*So he spoke to me the speech of one of opinion and ability ... experienced, wise, pure from suspicion.*
*I commanded you the good, so do what I commanded ... for I have left you possessing wealth and property.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*A bay horse and a reddish-yellow one; indeed that is from the error.*
The verse belongs to neither of the two men. Rather, it belongs to A'sha Banu Tarud, who are from Banu Fahm ibn Amr, and their count is among Banu Sulaym, in a beautiful poem starting with:
*O abode of Asma' between the plain and the wide space.*
Ibn al-Sirafi did not mention who it was that said to him: "I commanded you the good." The poet is actually recounting this from his father and boasting of it, and mention of him will come in the poetry.
A'sha Banu Tarud said:
*O abode of Asma' between the foot of the mountain and the wide space ... It became desolate and the passing of eras effaced it.*
*Nothing remains of it except stones arranged ... and three anchored ones around an erect one.*
*And a courtyard of the house where winds blow ... moaning in it like the moaning of the bereaved woman.*
*A house of Asma' when my heart was fond of her ... and when the nearest of it was not approachable.*
*Indeed, the beloved whom I have come to abandon ... not out of hatred from me nor anger.*
*I turn away from him in watchfulness lest I visit him ... and whoever fears the speech of slanderers watches.*
*I have acquired a noble deed over the people ... of old, and my father warned me of what they fear.*
*And he said to me the speech of one of knowledge and experience ... regarding the past matters of time and eras:*
*I commanded you the good, so do what I commanded ... for I have left you possessing wealth and property.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Talid al-Abshami said:
*I healed the thirst [for revenge] from Sumayr and Ja'un ... and the Lord of al-Salasil, Amir, escaped us.*
*And he became certain that if the horses engaged him ... there would be for the palm shoots after him a pollinator.*

He said: The cause of this poetry is that groups from Abd al-Qays raided the Abna' (Sons) from Banu Sa'd. The Abna' defeated them and killed Sumayr and Ja'unah among them. He said in the poetry "Ja'un," truncating it (tarkhim) outside of the vocative case. "Lord of al-Salasil": it is possible he meant by it that he is possessor of weapons and horses, and salsalah is the sound of iron. This is how I found it with this wording and spelling. And Allah knows best the truth.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*If you intercepted like the interception of the she-cat ... you are about to fall into a calamity.*
If Ibn al-Sirafi had remained silent about explaining such poetry of the tribes, in which skilled scholars and genealogists become exhausted—he would not have made himself a target for every archer. It was narrated from Abu Uthman al-Mazini that he said: "We carried the selections of al-Mufaddal and read them to al-Asma'i. Regarding everything in them from the poetry of famous poets, he answered. But when we came to the poetry of the tribes, Abu Sa'id [al-Asma'i] was exhausted/stumped by it."

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
This is a difficult chapter, and I had said: Whoever does not master the science of genealogy and the locations of the Arabs, and wades into explaining such poetry, his foot slips. The correct version is what Abu al-Nada, may Allah have mercy on him, recited to us:
*We healed the thirst from Sumayr and Ja'un ... and the Lord of al-Sulasil, Amir, escaped us.*
With Damma on the Sad of al-Sulasil. He mentioned that it is a water source belonging to this Amir, in a valley called al-Jawf, containing many palms and abundant farms. They hardly say: "Fulan Rabb Kadha" (So-and-so is the Lord of such-and-such) unless he is a great one among their greats, and a master among their masters, as they said: Lord of Marwan, Lord of Ma'add, Lord of Khasaf, and as they said: Lord of al-Khawarnaq and al-Sadir and the like.
S said: It was mentioned that a group from Abd al-Qays came to Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, and sought his judgment regarding this water source, meaning al-Sulasil. Some of the people recited this saying of Talid al-Abshami to him, so he judged the water to the descendants of this Amir. These are noble verses recited to us by Abu al-Nada, may Allah have mercy on him. The story is what Ibn al-Sirafi mentioned, except he did not mention their names and titles, and I will mention that after presenting the verses. They are:
*Banu Qays came to us with a huge gathering ... and Shann and the Abna' (Sons) of the great Amur.*
*They spent the night in the stopping place of a guest until ... the sparrows chirped with the dawn in the illuminating garden.*
*We rose against them and drew our weapons ... Yemeni [swords] and honed ones from India, cutting.*
*And arrows from the valley in the hands of our archers ... and short-haired horses like the ropes of well-buckets, strong.*
*We healed the thirst from Sumayr and Ja'un ... and the Lord of al-Sulasil, Amir, escaped us.*
*And he became certain that if the horses attached to him ... there would be for the shoots of al-Jawf after him a pollinator.*
*Calling in the desert of al-Faruq while appeared ... the peaks of Dab': That open the door, O Jabir.*
The Abna' (Sons) are the 'Uqad (Knots): Awf, 'Awafah, Malik, and Jusham, sons of Sa'd, who allied together. The Amur from Abd al-Qays are: Al-Dil, Ijl, and Muharib, sons of Amr ibn Wadi'ah ibn Lukayz ibn Afsa ibn Abd al-Qays.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Abu Sidra al-Asadi said:
*Hawwas thought and became certain that I ... would ransom myself with it from one whom I do not fight.*
*So I said to him: Dust in your mouth! For it is ... the young she-camel of a man who is treating you with hospitality, not what you fear.*

He said: In the Book [Sibawayh]: Abu Sidra al-Asadi. Some claimed he is Hujaymi from Banu al-Hujaym.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*You were endowed with stupidity, so stick to what you were endowed with ... What does the fool endowed with provisions do with intelligence?*
If Ibn al-Sirafi were provided for according to the measure of his correctness, he would have eaten leather strips out of hunger. Anyone who does not know whether Abu Sidra is Hujaymi or Asadi should not expose himself to speaking on such poetry. Abu Sidra is Suhaym ibn al-A'raf, from Banu al-Hujaym ibn Amr ibn Tamim. He has beautiful short pieces in the Book of Banu al-Hujaym ibn Amr ibn Tamim. Among them is his saying:
*To Hassan from the sides of Najd ... we saddled the white camels blowing in their nose-rings.*
*We count kinship and we count in-law relationships ... and happy by kinship is he who respects it.*
*And whatever you do, my soul ... counts the righteousness of your soul as part of its richness.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: The Rajiz said:
*I describe a donkey from the donkeys of Khanzarah.*
*In every donkey are two hundred glans (penises).*
He said: Khanzarah is a place in my opinion. The Rajaz attributed to Al-A'war ibn Bara' al-Kilabi, satirizing Umm Zajir, both from Banu Kilab:
*I describe donkeys that came to Ahmara.*
*And every donkey is lined with ten.*
*In every donkey are forty glans.*
*They met Umm Zajir at al-Muzdarah.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Oh thirst! And the water is near me ... and the Barni dates are in my lap.*
Ibn al-Sirafi did not know from this poetry what would quench the thirst of the thirsty. If poetry's completion and story are not known, it has no sweetness in the palate of the beneficiary. The story of this Rajaz, as Abu al-Nada dictated to us—may Allah have mercy on him—is that a woman and a man from Banu Abdullah ibn Kilab satirized each other. As for the man, he is Al-A'war ibn Bara', and as for the woman, she is Umm Zajir, and they were both slaves. Al-A'war ibn Bara' said:
*I describe donkeys that came to Ahmara.*
*And every donkey is lined with ten.*
*In every donkey are forty glans.*
*They met Umm Zajir at al-Muzdarah.*
*So they screwed her coming and going.*
*Until the light of Venus appeared.*
*They came with a flood like the notch of the chest-callus [of a camel].*
And Umm Zajir said:
*O son of the one who harms the milch camels.*
*Then covers them until the morning.*
*Then she is screwed in a swollen vulva.*
*The scoundrel or the farmer piles her.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
He said: So Umm Zajir and Al-A'war met at the place of a man from Quraysh who was sent as a tax collector over Banu Kilab. While the Qurashi had people gathered around him collecting charity, he heard Umm Zajir rising while saying: "Hush struck one, hush struck one, your father's penis is bright red, swallowing frogs, and the head and trotters, and every deceitful lizard." He said: And between them were ugly exchanges.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: The poet said:
*By my life, if I have become, O Umm Jahdar ... distant, I have worn out an excuse in seeking.*
*May my people lose each other as they sell my soul ... for a girl—woe to them after her, woe.*
And he said following this: The poet said:
*Do not lower the curtain, O Umm Jahdar ... Suffice the peaks of the mountains as a curtain between us.*
*If only I knew, is there to Umm Jahdar ... a way? For as for patience from her, there is no patience.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*And if you undertook a matter or were concerned with it ... let there be no falling short nor cheating.*
Such poetry, if its speaker is not known, and the cause that pulled it is not mentioned, becomes as was said:
*And some speech has no utility ... like churning water has no butter.*
The cause of this poetry is that Ibn Mayyadah used to compose love poetry about Umm Jahdar bint Hassan al-Murriyyah. Her father swore he would marry her to a man not from his clan and would not marry her in Najd. A man from Syria came to him, so he married her to him. He took her and went out with her to Syria. Ibn Mayyadah followed her until his family caught up with him and brought him back silenced, not speaking out of passion. I have affirmed for you all the verses because they are from the necklaces of poetry:
*Greeting a quarter at Dhu al-Ush that is effaced ... and a quarter at al-Mamdur, silent, desolate.*
*Violent winds struck it until its era was disguised ... sweeping the dust in it, a sweeping.*
*So Dhu al-Ush, may you be watered by the clouds, and may ... the wild herds not cease grazing in you, thick, flourishing.*
*My two friends from Ghayz ibn Murrah, convey ... messages from us that do not increase [burden] like a load.*
*And pass by Tayma, asking its Jews ... for regarding Tayma, from its rider, is a mention.*
*And by al-Ghamr she passed, and her mounts veered ... so the morning clouds watered the valley of Niyan then al-Ghamr.*
*And when she saw that they approached Abayir ... traversing a plain, leaving in it gaps.*
*The distance of the abodes stirred [sorrow] for her, and she mumbled ... matters and needs with which her chest was tight.*
*If she passes Busra, her connection is cut ... and two doorkeepers lock a palace without her.*
*So there is no connection unless ... young camels bring us close, crossing the desert with us like a bridge.*
*Ghurayri in lineage or Matili ... disputing the hands of the people, twisting, brown.*
*When the sun circled from an orbit and put down ... its carpets, and the squinting eyes became soft.*
*If only I knew, is there to Umm Jahdar ... a way? For as for patience from her, there is no patience.*
*And if a vow brought Umm Jahdar near ... to me, I would have made a vow incumbent upon my neck.*
*Do not lower the curtain, O Umm Jahdar ... Suffice the peaks of the mountains as a curtain between us.*
*By my life, if I have become, O Umm Jahdar ... distant, I have worn out an excuse from seeking.*
*If only I knew, will our family settle ... and your family in meadows at the belly of al-Liwa, green.*
*And will the wind knock, blowing at midnight ... with your scent, mounting with it the dusty highlands.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Khansa said:
*She weeps for a sadness; she is the tearful one and she wept ... and without him from the surface of the earth are veils.*
*The yearning of a 'walih' (distraught female) who lost her familiar one ... she has two yearnings: a soft one and a loud one.*
*She grazes as she grazed, until when she remembered ... it is nothing but coming and going.*

He said: The *walihah* could be a wild cow, or a gazelle, or a she-camel.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Either Khuza'ah or Muzaynah or ... Either Fazarah or Banu Abs.*
Ibn al-Sirafi's statement: "The *walihah* could be such or such or such" increases the beneficiary's confusion, leaving him in ambiguity, not knowing which to take. This statement also indicates Ibn al-Sirafi's stupidity, for the Arabs do not strike proverbs regarding intensity of yearning and distraction (*walah*) using gazelles and cows, nor do they say: "More yearning than a cow" nor "More yearning than a gazelle." They have said: "More yearning than an old she-camel (*sharif*)." Mutammim ibn Nuwayrah said:
*And not the passion of three nursing [camels] loving [their young] ... who found a drag-mark of a foal and a death-place.*
*They remind the sad one with grief of his grief ... when the first one yearns, they coo for it together.*
*[Are they] more passionate than me the day I left Malik ... and the hearing announcer stood with him and announced.*
And another said—recited to us by Abu al-Nada, may Allah have mercy on him:
*And they separated after uniting for an intent ... neighbors must surely separate.*
*The sturdy camels do not have patience when they separate ... until they yearn, but the human has patience.*
And a Bedouin from Banu Kilab said:
*Whoever has not yearned, then I and my she-camel ... at Hijr for the people of the Hima are yearning.*
*She yearns and shows what she has of ardor ... and I hide that which, were it not for sorrow, would have killed me.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
Ibn al-Sirafi said: Hibr ibn Abd al-Rahman said:
*She spent the spring in Liwa to her Ruha' ... until when it flew from her long hair.*
*And became like sheets upon her back ... she follows the sound of the braying from her folds.*
*She pulled upon it the ink (dark color) from her cloak ... she remembered Tuqtad by the coldness of its water.*
*And the urine dried upon her thighs.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*By Allah, sleeping at the sandy hill of al-Hafar ... is easier than binding skins at the early dawn.*

If Ibn al-Sirafi had busied himself with syntax and a little lexicography, and not presented such Rajaz poetry whose author and order of verses he did not know—it would have been easier for him, and less likely to attract criticism upon him. The sequence of the verses as I have established for you here is what Abu al-Nada, may Allah have mercy on him, dictated to us, and he mentioned they are by Abu Wajzah al-Sa'di.
*She remained at that Qahr from her equal ... between Uqaybayn to her Ranqa'.*
*In what cooled the eye of her pastures ... from the grass of the earth and its fruit.*
*Until when was completed of her thirsts ... and the urine dried upon her thighs.*
*And the weakest of her shepherds gathered her ... the gathering of the young girl of the fold of her cloak.*
*She remembered Tuqtad by the coldness of its water ... and the ancient reeds of its wells.*
*So she outstripped the incapable of her shepherds ... and came in the morning more disheveled than her camels.*
*The pulling [at the well] blesses her thirst ... [she came to] a Talh tree spending the night in its shelter.*
*As if she, when she attended to her water ... was a battalion that returned to its banner.*
*The enemies shook her from meeting her ... she almost in the crowd and in her aggression.*
*Drips the muscle from her folds ... when the summer [camel] howls from her nourishment.*
*He insisted like thunder from her singing.*
Abu al-Nada said: Tuqtad is a village in Hijaz, between it and Qulha is a mountain called Adimah. At the top of this valley are meadows called al-Falaj (with a dotted Jim), gathering people in the days of spring. It has many holding places for rainwater, which suffice them for their summer and spring if they get rain.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Jarir said:
*Is it Tha'labah the Horsemen or Riyah ... you equated Tuhayyah and the Khushab with them?*

He said: Tha'labah and Riyah are two tribes from Banu Yarbu', who are Jarir's people. Tuhayyah is from Banu Malik ibn Hanzalah ibn Malik, and they are closer to Al-Farazdaq than to Jarir. He addresses Al-Farazdaq with this, and denies that he equates Tuhayyah and al-Khushab with Banu Tha'labah and Banu Riyah.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Two shares of my heart: A share obeyed me ... and a share departed with the union of the beautiful women.*

Ibn al-Sirafi mentioned some of what is in the verse incorrectly, which is the lineage of Tuhayyah from Banu Malik ibn Hanzalah. Rather, she is: Umm Awn and Abu Sud, the two children of Malik ibn Hanzalah, and Tuhayyah is the daughter of Abd Shams ibn Sa'd ibn Zayd Manat ibn Tamim. And al-Khushab—which is what he did not know—are Rabi'ah and Rizam, the two sons of Malik ibn Hanzalah; they are called al-Akhshaban, and in plural they say al-Khushab. His saying: "Tha'labah and Riyah are two tribes from Banu Yarbu'" is from the blindness of his heart regarding lineage, because it is said "So-and-so and So-and-so are two tribes from Banu So-and-so" if there are grandfathers and fathers between them and the great tribe. But if they are from his loins, it is only said: They are his two sons. Tha'labah and Riyah are the two sons of Yarbu' ibn Hanzalah.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Amr ibn Ma'di Yakrib said:
*I want his gift and he wants my killing ... your excuse regarding your friend from Murad.*
*If you met me, you would have met a peer ... and the fat of your heart would have cleared from blackness.*

He said: The cause of this poetry is that Amr ibn Ma'di Yakrib raided with a man from Murad called Ubayy. When they wanted to divide the spoils, he asked Amr to give him the like of what he took. Amr refused to do that, so Ubayy threatened him. It reached Amr that he threatened him, so he said this poetry.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Indeed, in this lowland, the lowland of Tihama ... is the desire of the soul, not in the rugged terrain of the plateau of Najd.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
The poet's intent with this verse is not Ubayy whom Ibn al-Sirafi mentioned. How could that be, when Ubayy is Ubayy ibn Mu'awiyah ibn Subh, from Banu Musliyah ibn Amir ibn Amr ibn Illah ibn Jald ibn Malik ibn Udad, and he is not from Murad? So how could he say: "From your friend from Murad"? Rather, the intent of this verse is: Qays ibn Hubayrah ibn Abd Yaghuth al-Muradi, who is the nephew (sister's son) of Amr ibn Ma'di Yakrib, and Hubayrah is al-Makshuh. As for Ubayy—who is from Banu Musliyah—he is the one about whom Amr says in another poem of his:
*Ubayy wished to meet me ... an ostrich of a desert seeking the hatching place.*
And about him he also says:
*And Ibn Subh heedlessly threatening me.*
The cause of this poetry is that Qays ibn al-Makshuh said addressing Amr in a long poem of his:
*O convey to Abu Thawr a message ... there is no love between me and you.*
*You wished that fates would meet you ... Abu Thawr, so do you have a desire for combat?*
*If today you want a peer ... then bring close your person to my person.*
*With horses that meet from us and from you ... otherwise, individuals to individuals.*
So Amr answered him in a long poem of his:
*I want his gift and he wants my killing ... your excuse regarding your friend from Murad.*
*And whoever drinks from the water of al-Jawf excuses ... what was of the foolishness of the heart.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Shaqiq ibn Jaz' ibn Riyah al-Bahili said:
*And it returned to him that the horses were ... streaks between fleshy and thin.*
*As if their excuse at the south of Sula ... was ostriches waking up in a barren land.*
He said: Sula is a specific place. Banu Dabbah had raided Bahila, led by Hakim ibn Qabisah ibn Dirar al-Dabbi. Bahila defeated them, wounded Hakim, and killed Ubaydah al-Dabbi.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*The noble returned with captives as spoils ... and Banu Nahd returned with two penises in a basket.*
Ibn al-Sirafi brought two scandalous mistakes in explaining this poetry, because he mentioned that Banu Dabbah raided Banu Bahila, and Bahila defeated them. This is due to his ignorance of Sula, whether it is in the land of Bahila or the land of Dabbah. He also presented the verses separated, not consecutive, and there is also advancing and delaying in them. The correct version is what Abu al-Nada, may Allah have mercy on him, dictated to us. He said: Shaqiq ibn Jaz' al-Bahili raided Banu Dabbah at Sula and Sajir, which are two meadows belonging to Ukl. Suwayd ibn Kura' meant them by his saying:
*My heart is dispersed from his love at Sajir ... and another is at Kufah, a distant love.*
Dabbah, Ukl, Adi, and Taym are allies neighboring each other. Regarding them Laqit ibn Zurarah says:
*Has anyone seen the two slaves when mentioned to him ... Adi and Taym seeking someone to ally with?*
*So ally, for by Allah you will not descend a valley ... of the earth except you are knowledgeable of humiliation.*
*And Dabbah is a third slave with no brother ... just as the changer pushes the spurious coin with the palm.*
Returning to the story - so he defeated them. Awf ibn Dirar escaped that day, and Hakim ibn Qabisah ibn Dirar after being wounded, and they killed Ubaydah ibn Qadib al-Dabbi. Shaqiq ibn Jaz' said regarding the escape of Awf ibn Dirar:
*Awf escaped us at the spear points ... at al-Warha' stabbing at the bridle.*
*He was the healing [of revenge], but saved him ... the excellence of the back [of the horse] and the high girth.*
*Like an ash-colored pigeon thrown ... by the two sides [of the valley] from the ash-colored pigeons.*
*He disdained food for it [the horse] so he did not lose it ... the morning of fright when Azam [hardship] bit.*
And Shaqiq said regarding the Day of Sula:
*My eye was cooled regarding them at Sula ... and the meadow of Sajir possessing the Arar plant.*
*I repaid the Mulhabbins with what I slid ... of misery, the spears of Banu Dirar.*
*We break the upper parts [of spears] in their backs ... and the Samhari spear goes through in breaking.*
*And Hakim escaped from our spearheads ... choking [with saliva/distress] like the escape of the wild ass.*
*And it returned to him that the horses were ... streaks between fleshy and thin.*
*As if their excuse at the south of Sula ... was ostriches waking up in a barren land.*
*And when I saw Abu Hudayr ... thrown down by the people, my caution became true.*
*I was not envious of anything upon him ... and nothing benefited me except my taking an omen.*
*I left the birds circling over them ... as women circle an idol.*
*And were it not for the night, it would have returned to them with misfortune ... with the most ill-omened bird, ascending and deviating.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*So if you kill Abu Hudayr ... then I, my victory has healed my soul.*
*They left Ubaydah al-Dabbi falling ... on the hands, his lower garment soiled with sand.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Ajir al-Saluli said:
*So the worries of the chest spent the night, diverse, returning to him ... as a corpse in the open, killed, is visited [by beasts].*
*While he was buying his saddle, a sayer said ... whose is a camel, loose of the side, tall?*
*Adorned with noble collars, as if they are ... remnants of silver whose sound is a jingle.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*You have nothing of Buthaynah except what you see: Longing that concerns you and the alienations of distance.*

The beneficiary has nothing from what Ibn al-Sirafi presented in these verses except trifles, confusions, and mix-ups, from which a person gains no benefit. This poetry is not by Al-Ajir al-Saluli, nor are the verses orderly. Rather, the correct view is that they belong to Al-Mukhallab al-Hilali as Abu al-Nada, may Allah have mercy on him, recited to us. He said to us: There is no Bedouin on earth but he memorizes this poem:
*I felt regarding her the passion of one whose lean camel was lost ... in Mecca one day while the companions were dismounting.*
*He sought what he sought until the night came without them ... and a wind raising the dust, sweeping.*
*He came to his two companions after his quest was lost ... where Amir and Salul met.*
*He said: Carry my saddle and your saddles together ... They said to him: You speak all foolishness.*
*He said: Carry me and leave the saddle, for it is ... in a place, and outcomes change.*
*They said: Allah forbid! So their two beasts galloped ... and their saddles were Mahri camels and swift.*
*He complained of roughness from his two companions, and his cash ... when he stood to bargain for riding camels was little.*
*While he was buying his saddle, a sayer said ... whose is a camel, loose of the side, submissive?*
*Adorned with noble collars, which sprinkle him ... crescents of Jinn, between which are separators.*
*So he hailed [God] for a time, then went with his lean camel ... and the sun of the day had time to set.*
*The horn of the sun did not complete [setting] until he made it kneel ... at Qarn, and for the hasty ones there is slipping.*
*When he folded [passed] the two figures and turned away from them ... and settled him at al-Naqra while he was submissive.*
*They stood dragging their clothes, both of them ... because of what they had kept secret from the friend shortly before.*
*He said: Lift your saddles and depart ... for the water of the water-skins in the desert is little.*

He said: Al-Mukhallab has curious short pieces. Among them is his saying:
*The dark beautiful women surprised us at al-Saram after ... new means [of contact] occurred between us.*
*The heart refused all but his love, unhurried ... possessors of front teeth and leaning hair branches.*
*Wide of buttocks, languid of eyes ... beautiful when the folds of the braids appear.*
*As if polish from silver pitchers ... when they stand, appears from the gaps of the shifts.*
*Those capture the naive youth himself ... and bind the one who disputes with them in the ropes.*

And he is the one who also said:
*Nay, by the majesty of Allah, if a union were sold ... we would bid high then for your union.*
*And if proximity of distance were sold, I would buy it ... at a high price or by the judgment of your men.*
*And if one from the estrangement of the abode were ransomed ... by something, I would raise the ransom for your separation.*
*And if they slaughtered with the sword the most passionate one ... for you, my soul would be certain that I am that one.*
*So reap the young she-camel of al-Maliki despite the pain ... to a land beloved in the curve of your sandals.*
*So by Allah, if I made my saddle reach her family ... at the plateau of al-Safa, that you be released from your ropes.*
*And that you not traverse desert after desert ... and that you not spend a night in your shackle.*
*And that you descend Dhat al-Sulaym and hear ... in it the sound of the rumbling of the intense camels of your beauty.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Amir ibn Juwayn al-Ta'i said:
*Have you not seen how many at the bend of Malakat ... and how many at the highland of white camels kept for breeding?*
*And I have not seen like her, the spoil of one ... and I restrained myself after I almost did it.*

He said: The Jaz' is the bend of the valley. Malakat is the plural of Malikah (Queen). Al-Sa'id is the face of the earth.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Gently, let them come to Siwaj ... There the news of the barbarians appears.*
