*And the blacksmith and the shopkeeper and the weaver.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
This is the most foolish thing Ibn al-Sirafi came up with. If he had shame, he would not have approved for himself to enter into such a heinous misspelling. But there is no cure for one who has no shame. The correct reading is: *Ma bi al-Jaz' min Malakan* (What is at the bend of Malakan). Malakan is a mountain in the land of Banu Tayy. It used to be called: Malakan of the Romans, because the Romans used to inhabit it once in the Jahiliyyah. Abu al-Nada, may Allah have mercy on him, recited:
*Malakan of the Romans refused to be grateful to us ... and a day at the slope of al-Qur did not pass.*
He said: The parallel of Malakan in meter is Warqan, which al-Khudari—from Banu Khidr ibn Muharib ibn Khasafah—mentioned:
*If the peaks of Warqan vanished ... I would find my affection for you not vanishing.*
*So say to the pigeon of al-Kharja': Rain ... for your shadow where the noon nap overtakes you.*
Its parallel is also Badlan, which Imru' al-Qays mentioned:
*Our nights at the slope of Badlan.*
Parallels to that are many. Amir ibn Juwayn al-Ta'i recited these verses about Hind, the sister of Imru' al-Qays ibn Hujr, when he fled from al-Nu'man ibn al-Mundhir and stayed with him. Amir wanted to betray him, so he moved away from him. They are:
*Are the litters of Hind those departing ... to grieve me, or is my female friend coquetting?*
*No egg which the male ostrich spent the night surrounding ... and spreading soft feathers for it, velvety.*
*And placing it between the wing and his side ... against a dry chest at the soft ground of Hawmal.*
*Is more beautiful than her the day she said: Do you not see ... taking a replacement friend? For I am changing.*
*Have you not seen what is at the bend of Malakan ... and what is at the highland of white camels kept for breeding?*
*And I have not seen like her, the spoil of one ... and I restrained myself after I almost did it.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Shammakh said:
*And she promised me what I do not seek its benefit ... the promises of Urqub to his brother at Yatrab.*
Yatrab: A place on the pattern of Yarm'a, and it is other than Yathrib.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*He revives the eggs and kills the chicks.*
Often Ibn al-Sirafi is fond of heinous misspelling and leaves the pure explicit aside. Yatrab here on the weight of Yarm'a as Ibn al-Sirafi mentioned is a heinous misspelling. The correct reading in this verse is Yathrib, which is the city of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him; it was called Yathrib in the Jahiliyyah, and there the story of Urqub occurred. As for Yatrab and Bilad, they are two lands near Hajar al-Yamama, whose arrows (gambling shares/crops) are good. The verse is from verses by Al-Shammakh, which are:
*She promised me what I do not seek its benefit ... the promises of Urqub to his brother at Yathrib.*
*And she promised me a running mare between its wall ... and its side, half a far limit.*
*She sways as maidens swayed over their sisters ... virgins in a tent with ropes.*
Abu al-Nada, may Allah have mercy on him, recited to us regarding the promises of Urqub—and it is a proverbial verse—:
*As if the promises of the Quda'i to his neighbor ... were the promises of Urqub to his brother at Yathrib.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Layla al-Akhyaliyyah said:
*Indeed al-Khali' and his group from Amir ... are like the heart, clothed in a chest and a windpipe.*
*Do not approach ever the family of Mutarrif ... whether they are oppressor or oppressed.*

He said: She praises thereby Hammam ibn Mutarrif, and he is from the offspring of al-Khali'.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Indeed, the defenders of glory are few.*
Knowledge of such poetry and the genealogy in it is rare. The verse is not by Layla al-Akhyaliyyah, but rather it is by Humayd ibn Thawr al-Hilali in his poem that begins:
*When the loads appeared, I thought them ... Dwm trees at Ayla, fresh, covered.*
It consists of [several] verses. Ibn al-Sirafi did not mention al-Khali', who he is among people. He is from Banu Uqayl. The Khula'a (Ousted ones) are: Amr, Amir, and Uwaymir from Banu Rabi'ah ibn Uqayl. Al-Khatim the Thief meant them by his saying:
*If I were from the clan of al-Asamm ibn Malik ... or the Khula'a or Zuhayr of Banu Abs.*
*Then Qays would have defended behind me with stones ... and the criminal would not have been surrendered for what he committed yesterday.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Humayd ibn Thawr said:
*And she is nothing but in a loincloth and a shift ... the raid of Ibn Hammam on the tribe of Khath'am.*

He said: He is Amr ibn Hammam ibn Mutarrif from the Khula'a. Khath'am had killed his father Hammam ibn Mutarrif, so he came to Najdah ibn Amir al-Haruri [the Kharijite] and pretended to be of his opinion, asking him to send some of his companions with him. So Najdah sent horses with him. He raided Khath'am and struck them, taking revenge for his father, and became a head among the Kharijites. When he fulfilled his need, he returned to his people and settled among them, then put the sword to the Najdiyah [Kharijites].

S said: This is the place of the proverb:

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*Your two garments deceived me regarding [the size of] my testicles ... Would that my testicles were on my neck.*

Humayd's Mim-rhymed poem, which begins:
*Ask the quarter where Umm Salim headed ... and is it a habit for the quarter to speak?*
deceived Ibn al-Sirafi, so he imagined that this verse was from it. Al-Kamar (testicles/glans) resemble Al-Kamar. The verse belongs to Al-Tammah ibn Amir ibn al-A'lam ibn Khuwaylid al-Uqayli. He is an excellent poet and has beautiful short pieces. He is the one who says in a poem of his boasting:
*And they traveled from the two salty lands, the salty land of Sa'ayid ... and Tathlith, a journey riding the vertebrae of old camels.*
*They did not fall short in the journey until they reached ... Banu Asad in Darahim and Banu Ijl.*
*Leading short-haired horses from the daughters of Mukhalis ... and A'waj, followed by the camels and the herd.*
Al-Tammah al-Uqayli said:
*I knew for Salma a trace of a dwelling you would think ... playgrounds of Jinn or a written book.*
*My covenant with Salma and youth is as if it is ... a palm branch growing in a wet place, so it straightened.*
*And she is nothing but possessor of a soft drape and a shift ... the raid of Ibn Hammam on the tribe of Khath'am.*
*A young girl, she did not exceed the wrapping cloth ... nor did her breast exceed dreaming [swelling].*
*I loved her amidst the girls, naive ... and she was adorned with nothing but arranged pearls.*
*Until she called for the chemise before her peers ... and returned appearing more beautiful and grand than them.*
*And her two bracelets choked [her wrists], so they did not fail her ... when they reached the hands, to become straight.*
*And she returned like a sand-dune from a compacted dune ... and she filled the two anklets until they cracked.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Harith ibn Jabalah al-Udhri said:
*Until it was as if there was nothing but remembering him ... and Time, whichever state, brings calamities.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*The night mixed with the colors of the pebbles.*
Ibn al-Sirafi confused this name; it is Jabalah ibn al-Huwayrith al-Udhri. Ibn al-Sirafi cited the completion of the verses.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Amr ibn Qami'ah said:
*The daughter of Amr asked me about the ... lands when she did not recognize their signs.*
*When she saw Satidama she wept ... To Allah belongs the milk of the day of the one who blamed her.*
*She remembered a land wherein are her family ... her maternal uncles in it and her paternal uncles.*

He said: Satidama is a mountain, and 'ista'barat' means she wept.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Whoever does not fatten a steed he used to ride ... in fertility, will stand with it in drought, lean.*

I mentioned to you that whoever does not practice the science of stopping places will not succeed with such poetry. Because if the beneficiary does not know Satidama is in which of Allah's lands, he will not conceptualize the meaning of this verse, nor the cause of her weeping, nor the meaning that when she left the land of her people and fell into the land of the Romans, she wept and regretted that. Amr meant by these verses himself, not his daughter, but he used her as a metonym for himself. Satidama is a mountain between Mayyafariqin and Si'irt. Thus Abu al-Nada informed us. Amr recited this poetry when he went out with Imru' al-Qays to the Romans, and their story is well known.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Dabi' ibn al-Harith al-Burjumi said:
*Whoever's saddle is in Medina in the evening ... then I and Qayyar are strangers in it.*
*And hasty birds do not bring near to the youth ... success, nor does he fail due to their slowness.*

He said: Qayyar is the name of his camel.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*A substitute for the falcon is a pied crow.*
Ibn al-Sirafi placed a heavy camel in the place of a swift horse. Qayyar is the name of his horse, not the name of his camel. It is the horse that Dabi' made trample some boys of the people of Medina until Uthman took him and imprisoned him.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: A poet from Hamdan said:
*They pass by al-Dahna, light imply their bags ... and they exit from Darin dragging the bags.*
*At a time when the bulk of their affairs distracted the people ... So snatch, O Zurayq al-Mal, the snatching of foxes.*

He said: Zurayq is a vocative, and it is a tribe. As if he said: Snatch, O Zurayq al-Mal. Al-Dahna is a place, and Darin is a place too. His saying: "At a time when the bulk of their affairs distracted the people": he means when people were occupied with sedition and wars. It is said: He describes merchant people carrying goods from Darin and selling them, passing by al-Dahna after selling their goods. And it is said: He describes thieves coming to Darin, stealing and filling their bags, then emptying them and returning to Darin.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*He gives him drink from every hand with a cup ... so the heart is between hope and despair.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
Ibn al-Sirafi spoke with all the speech he had regarding this poetry, but he did not succeed or prosper. This is because of what I told you: whoever has not trained himself in the science of genealogies and days (history), then objects to such poetry with his speech, targets himself for the tongues of critics. If the polite scholar does not know the speaker of this poetry, nor whom it was said about, nor the tribe addressed by it—who they are and from whom they are—he will not realize the meanings of these verses.
The story is that Al-Nu'man ibn al-Ajlan ibn al-Nu'man ibn Amir al-Zurqi—and Zurayq is Ibn Amir ibn Zurayq ibn Abd Harithah ibn Malik ibn Ghadb ibn Jusham ibn al-Khazraj—Ali, peace be upon him, appointed him over Bahrain. So a man from the Ansar said:
*I see a sedition that has distracted the people from you ... So snatch, O Zurayq al-Mal, the snatching of foxes.*
*For Ibn Ajlan, whom you have known ... squanders the wealth of Allah like the act of plunderers.*
*They pass by al-Dahna, light their bags ... and they exit from Darin dragging the bags.*
When you know the story and the order of the verses, the meaning appears to you in its truth, and it calls out for itself.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: The poet said:
*And you, your place from Wa'il ... is the place of the tick from the butt of the camel.*
Meaning he is the vilest of the tribes of Bakr ibn Wa'il and the lowest of them, for in the vileness of his rank and his falling, he is not paid attention to, like the tick attaching to the butt of the camel.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*If one sufficed, I would have sufficed him ... but with feathers the bird flies.*
How can this satirized person be the vilest of Bakr ibn Wa'il when he is a man from Banu Taghlib? This is also due to Ibn al-Sirafi's ignorance of genealogy, which is indispensable in knowing such poetry. The poet of the verse is Utbah ibn al-Waghul al-Taghlibi, satirizing Ka'b ibn Ju'ayl al-Taghlibi. So he is then the vilest of Banu Taghlib, not the vilest of Banu Bakr ibn Wa'il. It is a beautiful poem, beginning:
*Perhaps the distance will bring Salma back ... and my Lord will gather the scattered hope.*
*She captivated me with cool, scattered [teeth] ... sweet of the kiss, pure, distinct.*
In it he also says:
*You named Ka'b [Heel] with the evil of bones ... and your father used to be called Al-Ju'al [Beetle].*
*And you, your place from Wa'il ... is the place of the tick from the butt of the camel.*
Meaning like the place of the tick, i.e., you are in the rear of the people.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: The Rajiz said:
*When I ate fish and Farad (dates).*
*I went length and I went width.*
He said: It is as if he said: I went long in a direction, and I went wide in a direction. He meant that his eating the fish and this type of dates made him tall, wide, and fat.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*The matter turned back until there remained sitting ... Abu Hubayrah giving Fatwas and Ibn Shaddad.*
What indicates Ibn al-Sirafi's ignorance of this Rajaz, and his undertaking what he did not know, and his setting himself up to seek leadership without competence—is that he brought these two verses separated, not consecutive. Then his explanation of it: that this type of fish and dates made him tall, wide, and fat. How excellent is what the sayer said:
*For every disease there is a doctor to treat it ... Except stupidity; its healer tires.*
The order of the verses, as Abu al-Nada dictated to us—and he claimed they are from the playful banter of the Bedouins—is:
*If I drank sour milk and fresh milk.*
*Then ate Raby (dates) and Farad (dates).*
*And the butter tops some of that over some.*
*Then I drank after it water/milk (Marad).*
*I towered in length and went in width.*
*As if I am eating wealth that is a loan.*
Abu al-Nada said: This is like their saying:
*If I had lunch and my soul felt good.*
*Then there is no boy in the tribe like me.*
*Except a boy who had lunch before me.*
And his saying: "I towered in length and went in width," he means from pride.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: A man from Khath'am said:
*I resolved to stay until the morning ... for a matter; he who prevails prevails.*
He said: He means I resolved to stay until the time of morning, because I saw that opinion and prudence necessitate that.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Every favor from Abu Ka'b is a catch.*
The amount Ibn al-Sirafi mentioned in explaining this verse is a lot from him [considering his usual], because he did not know the speaker of the verse, nor the reason that necessitated his saying: "I resolved to stay until the morning." This verse belongs to Anas ibn Mudrik al-Khath'ami. He and another chief from his people raided some Arab tribes, supporting each other. When they approached the people, evening came, so they spent the night until night covered them. His companion stood up and left, taking no booty. Anas stayed until morning, then launched the horses against them, so he struck and took booty, and his companions took booty. This is the meaning of his saying: "I resolved to stay until the morning," and it is the last of the verses.

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
Abu al-Nada said: Anas was a neighbor to Banu al-Harith ibn Ka'b. His companions found roughness from them, so they wanted to leave them. He said to them: "Stay until the morning." When Banu al-Harith defeated Banu Amir on the Day of Fayf al-Rih, he said then what he said. The beginning of the verses is:
*I called Banu Quhafah and they answered ... So I said: Arrive [at the water], for the arrival is good.*
*I called for combat and they answered me ... with a arrival that increase does not restrain.*
*As if a cloud flashed upon them ... from the summer clouds, thunders shaking it.*
*I resolved to stay until the morning ... for a matter; he who prevails prevails.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Jarir said:
*With Rajaz poems, O son of baseness, do you threaten me ... while in Rajaz poems, I thought, were baseness and weakness.*

He said: He meant by this speech Umar ibn Laja'. He says: Do you threaten me with Rajaz poems, while in Rajaz poems I thought were the baseness of poets and their weakness.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*No udders flow for the two sons of Qari'ah after it ... in a starting visitor nor a follow-up.*

Ibn al-Sirafi did not succeed in correctness in this verse. He erred in it from two aspects: First, he attributed the verse to Jarir, but it is by Al-La'in al-Minqari. Second, he changed the rhyme from "al-fashal" (failure) to "al-khawar" (weakness). He erred from a third aspect as well, which is that he made this verse a satire of Umar ibn Laja' al-Taymi, while it is a satire of Ru'ba ibn al-Ajjaj. The verses are by Al-La'in al-Minqari satirizing Ru'ba, and they are:
*I am the son of clarity [well-known] if you know me ... O Rub [Ru'ba], and the deaf snake in the mountain.*
*With Rajaz poems, O son of the hollow, do you threaten me ... while in Rajaz poems is the house of baseness and failure.*
*There is no intelligence in the spurs on my leg ... at the betting, nor am I cauterized for scrotal hernia (afal).*
Umm Malik bint Sa'd was from Kalb, and her co-wives used to call her Afil [one with hernia/defect]. Ru'ba is from Banu Malik ibn Sa'd, and these Banu Malik ibn Sa'd are called Banu al-Afil.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: The poet said:
*Be, you and the sons of your father ... the place of the two kidneys from the spleen.*
He said: He says: Be close to the sons of your father and support them, and let your place from them be like the place of the two kidneys from the spleen.

S said: I do not know this verse with this recitation. I know "the place of the two kidneys from the spleen" in verses by Shu'bah ibn Qumayr al-Mazini. Perhaps this is that, but changed. Shu'bah's verses are:
*So convey to Malik a message from me ... and wealth does not substitute the messenger for you.*
*You deceive us regarding ourselves and promise us slowly ... like the habit of the wolf creeping towards the gazelle.*
*So do not do it, for your brother is sturdy ... in consolation regarding it, possessing resourcefulness.*
*And we will make our two clients ... the place of the two kidneys from the spleen.*
*And we will suffice in accidents for our brother ... as the right hand suffices for the left.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Shammakh said:
*Lean-bellied, as if his nostril when ... he sounds at their rear is a bellows.*
*He has a sound like the voice of a singer ... when he seeks the stolen herd, or a flute player.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*The piebald mare farted, she roamed in the halter.*
This is false. The verse is not by Al-Shammakh; it is by Rabi' ibn Qa'nab al-Fazari.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Mudarris al-Asadi said:
*Kilabi, Wabar-dwelling, Habtari ... she distanced herself from you and betrayed the promises and covenants.*
He said: In the Book [Sibawayh] it is *Habtariyah* with Ba and Ta dotted with two dots. And in his poetry it is *Hanthariyah* with Nun and Tha dotted with three dots. *Na'atka* means she distanced herself from you.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*I belittled him until my back sweated ... I let him go and he is safe, departing.*
Ibn al-Sirafi hovered around the correct [view] but did not land. This is because he mentioned that in the Book it is *Habtariyah* with Ba and Ta dotted with two dots, then said: And in his poetry it is *Hanthariyah* with Nun and Tha dotted with three dots. Then he remained silent and did not weigh the correct against the incorrect, so the beneficiary does not know which to take and which to leave. This is complete foolishness. The correct word in the verse of the Book is *Hanthariyah* with Nun and Tha dotted three times from above. He is Hanthar ibn Wahb ibn Wabar ibn al-Adbat ibn Kilab. In Tamim also—and this is not its place—is Hanthar ibn Ghawi ibn Salamah ibn Ghawi ibn Jarwah ibn Usayd. In Asad also is Hanthar ibn Kahil ibn Asad. As for *Habtar* with Ba and Ta dotted twice from above, he is Habtar ibn Adi ibn Salul from Khuza'ah. Similar to Mudarris's saying in arrangement is the saying of Sinja' ibn Rakkad al-Sulami, recited to us by Abu al-Nada:

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*The heart refused all but loving her, an Amiri woman ... her abode is far from me and I do not attain her.*
*Dibabi, fortified, Artawi ... often dwelling in the sides of the Arak trees.*
*And she is nothing but [such that] a raid befits her ... you see the horses in it settled, their small groups.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Ru'ba said:
*O abode of Afra and abode of the Bakhdan ... in you the murmuring one having a foal and the young gazelle.*
He said: *Al-Bakhdan* is narrated in two ways: *Bakhdan* on the weight of Ja'far, and *Bikhdin* on the weight of Zibrij.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*The humiliated one is eaten by the ostrich, and eaten by the vulture and the owl.*
The fool is he who is deceived by this saying of Ibn al-Sirafi. How can *Bakhdan* and *Bikhdin* be permitted when it is a proper noun? Names do not shift from their rules. Just as it is not permitted to say *Kiltham* with a kasra on the Kaf and Tha instead of *Kaltham*, so too *Bikhdin* with a kasra on the Ba and Dal is not permitted.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Imru' al-Qays said:
*Excellent is the youth whom you seek the light of his fire ... Tarif ibn Mal, the night of hunger and cold.*
He said: The witness in it is the truncation (tarkhim) of Malik outside of the vocative case.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Leave raiding unless you sell and rub.*
Ibn al-Sirafi was not among the men of genealogy, so he erred regarding the saying of Tarif ibn Mal an error whose two ends do not meet. How can Mal be a truncation of Malik as he claimed, when the man's name is Mal (Mall)? He is Tarif ibn Mal ibn Umayrah ibn Taym ibn Awf ibn Malik ibn Tha'labah from Tayy.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Farazdaq said:
*I inherited from my father his morals: hastening hospitality ... and striking the hocks of the following camels with its 'Shabub'.*
He said: *Al-Shabub*: The sword.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Rejoice in his joy ... there is no rest from you.*
When will Ibn al-Sirafi bring something with good in it? When was the sword called *Shabub*? It is but a misspelling. The correct word is *Sabubaha* with an undotted Sin. He means that he hamstrings (cuts the hocks of) the camels. *Al-Sab*: Cutting. From it is the saying of Dhu al-Kharq:
*So what was the sin of Banu Malik ... that a boy of theirs insulted so he was cut (Subba)?*
*With a white [sword] having ridges, sharp ... cutting off the bones and peeling the nerves.*
He means by *Sabubiha* the soul of the praised one.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Labid said:
*We, the sons of the mother of the four sons ... and we are the best of Amir ibn Sa'sa'ah.*
He said: Umm al-Banin is the wife of Malik ibn Ja'far ibn Kilab. She bore him five sons: Mu'awiyah ibn Malik, called Mu'awwid al-Hukama (Trainer of the Wise); Amir ibn Malik, Mula'ib al-Asinnah (Player with Spears); Salma ibn Malik, Nazzal al-Madiq (Dismounter in Straits); Rabi'ah ibn Malik, Rabi' al-Muqtarin (Spring of the Destitute), who is the father of Labid; and al-Tufayl ibn Malik, Faris Qurzul. So Labid needed to say "Mother of the Four Sons" for the sake of poetry, though they were five.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*A bucket (hawwabah), multicolored, quenching a returning drinker.*
*Al-Hawwabah*: The bucket. Such genealogy exhausts Ibn al-Sirafi and his likes who have not worked in the science of genealogy, nor exerted themselves in it. Ibn al-Sirafi erred in his saying: that Salma ibn Malik is from the children of Umm al-Banin. For the children of Umm al-Banin are five: Ubaydah, Tufayl, Mu'awiyah Mu'awwid al-Hukama, Amir Mula'ib al-Asinnah, and Rabi'ah the father of Labid the poet—sons of Malik ibn Ja'far. Their mother is Umm al-Banin bint Amr ibn Amir ibn Sa'sa'ah. As for Salma and Utbah, the sons of Malik, their mother is Hind, a woman from Banu Sulaym. Ubaydah ibn Malik was not like his brothers in fame and renown, but he was truthful and pious. Labid only mentioned the four notables.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Qays ibn Dharih said:
*The slanderers surrounded me and disturbed me ... So oh people, for the obeyed slanderer!*
His saying: "So oh people, for the obeyed slanderer"—he meant that she obeys them when they incite her to abandon him and distance herself from him.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Turn over, O turner.*
Ibn al-Sirafi turned the meaning of this verse from correct to incorrect. The one obeying the slanderer here is Qays, not Lubna. This is because his father and a group of his people gathered against him until he divorced Lubna, so he regretted it. He began to say in a long poem of his:
*O my sorrow! And my illness has returned to me ... and parting from Lubna was like deception.*
*The slanderers surrounded me and disturbed me ... So oh people, for the obeyed slanderer!*
*So I became this morning blaming myself ... for a thing that is not possible.*
*Like one cheated, biting his hands ... his loss becoming clear after the sale.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Ajir al-Saluli said:
*Do not make my guest a guest brought near ... and another isolated from the house, put aside.*
*And do not assign me a servant I do not love ... lest a fever and headache seize me from that.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
He said: He means do not rank my guests, honoring some and humiliating some, but honor all of them and do not despise any one of them. He said: And his saying "And do not assign me a servant I do not love to serve me, lest I get a fever from hating his service."

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*If you came to Anbasa ibn Yahya ... you returned garlanded with the boots of Hunayn [empty-handed].*
What benefit is there for the beneficiary in what Ibn al-Sirafi mentioned here of saying: Do not rank my guests, honoring some and humiliating some, without mentioning what the cause of that is, and why the speaker of this poetry hated honoring some and humiliating others? This, by Allah, is obvious foolishness, and the foolishness of men is plentiful. Al-Ajir only meant by this statement that if she honored some guests over others, it was because of her desire for him [the guest]; and likewise if she employed a servant Al-Ajir hated, that was also for a suspicious matter. Whoever does not know the story of these verses and the verses of the whole poem—for every verse indicates what I told you—does not know the meaning of this poetry. That is because Al-Ajir's wife was recalcitrant towards him, so her matter made him suspicious. She said: I must go to Hajj. Her son said: My mother must go to Hajj, so let her saddle one of these camels of hers. He did not see her except leading one of them which she had brought and bridled. So he said—and she is Athmah bint Ma'bad ibn Abd al-Rahman—:
*O Lord, do not forgive Athmah her sin ... and if Al-Ajir does not punish her, then [You] punish.*
*I did not see her except leading her camel ... She said: Give me rest [tell me], which rider-group shall I accompany?*
*I said to her: Youths have gone before you ... on Qatari camels, light of bags.*
*I fear for you that Allah will place piety ... other than you, and you will meet some of those Slavs.*
*I fear when ropes heave and change ... and the trotting of noble camels hides the people from you.*
*And a madman tucks up [his clothes] on a mischievous she-camel ... seeing the wife of the Sheikh while the Sheikh is absent.*
*When his hand reached for the young camel so you could ride ... his hand fell to commit one of the wonders [adultery].*
*So she inclined a turn, not fleeing, and I wish ... I could see you, and for the decreed matter there are bringers.*
*While a tangled-fang [stallion], his danger has risen ... guards the isolated ones, angry among the plundered ones.*
*Faster than me in jealousy, so beware of me ... on the head, or a blow behind the knuckles.*
*And the falcon of Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf, gripping ... is not faster than me in the glance of an eye with an eyebrow.*
*Forbidden upon you is the Hajj, do not approach it ... when the time of Hajj for repenting Muslim women comes.*
*And do not make my guest a guest brought near ... and another isolated from the house, put aside.*
*And do not assign me a servant I do not love ... lest a fever and headache seize me from that.*
*And gather the saddles of the people or expose them ... and do not do what the likes of me do not approach.*
*Her eye gazed, while the white camels blew into the nose-rings ... towards a rider, excluding whom are a thousand riders.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Khansa said:
*And a girl from the daughters of the kings ... rattled her anklets against the horses.*
*Like the *Kirfi'ah* (cloud) of rain possessing the *Sabir* (cloud formation) ... she comes to the clouds and *ta'taluha*.*
*So no rain cloud poured its rain ... nor did a land grow its vegetation.*

He said: *Ta'ti al-sahab*: She intends towards the main body of the clouds, moving towards the clouds with gentleness and slowness. *Ta'talu*: She repairs the clouds by joining them. *Ta'talu* is the *tafta'ilu* form from: *Ala al-shay' ya'uluhu* if he repaired it.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*For the night of a maiden between her combers ... and midwives and her mothers.*
*Is easier than the night of her suffering.*
If Ibn al-Sirafi had left alone such poetry, which he did not know, nor its author, and brought it separated not consecutive, and did not explain his saying *ta'taluha* as repairing the clouds, and busied himself with syntax and a bit of [grammar]—he would have been more guided. These verses are not by Al-Khansa. Also, a verse has fallen from them which is the best of them. His saying: *Ta'taluha* means repairing the clouds is a scandal, because if it were so, it would necessitate raising the Lam (nominative), because there is no accusative particle here for the verb. The verses are by Amir ibn Juwayn al-Ta'i, and their order is:
*And a girl from the daughters of the kings ... rattled her anklets against the spear.*
*Like the *Kirfi'ah* of rain possessing the *Sabir* ... she throws the clouds and it is thrown for her.*
*The speckle-faced [cloud] promised her after the passing of the stars ... increasing its pouring.*
*So no rain cloud poured its rain ... nor did a land grow its vegetation.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
Ibn al-Sirafi attributed this poetry to Al-Khansa only because he was deceived by her poem which begins: *Ala ma li-'aynika am ma laha* (What is wrong with your eye or what is wrong with it?). "And not every black thing is a date." Two verses from these verses, namely "Wa jariyah" and "Ka-kirfi'ah," were inserted into this poem of Al-Khansa, and the address in them was made to Sakhr. This is not hidden from the insightful critic. His saying: "Tarmi al-sahab wa yurma laha" (She throws the clouds and it is thrown for her): The Arabs say: A cloud originated, so the clouds began to be thrown to it (*yurma laha*), meaning joined to it. Jami' ibn Amr ibn Markhiyah al-Kilabi said:
*A green night-cloud covering them watered ... dwellings of Dahma' that had been effaced by the sand.*
*Green, reviving the decayed earth that had worn out ... its night-traveler follows the morning cloud with darkness.*
*From the sea, it originated, the clouds being thrown to it ... until its Najdi and Tihami parts poured rain.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Hassan ibn Thabit said:
*The children of Jafnah around the grave of their father ... the grave of Ibn Mariyah, the generous, the preferred.*
*They are visited until their dogs do not growl ... they do not ask about the approaching person [blackness].*

He said: He praises thereby the family of Jafnah the Ghassanid, and their land is in Syria. Mariyah of the Two Earrings is the mother of Jafnah ibn Amr Muzayqiya. *Yughshawn*: Seekers and beggars visit them and multiply at their place. In speech resembling this.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Ma'add took away the height, and Nahshal ... from between a reciter of his poetry and a rogue.*
The scholars took away the knowledge of the pleasing meaning in this verse, a meaning from which Ibn al-Sirafi is isolated, as well as the genealogy in it. As for Mariyah, she is the daughter of Al-Arqam ibn Tha'labah ibn Amr ibn Jafnah. She is the one of the Two Earrings, the two pearls like ostrich or pigeon eggs that she had. She is the mother of Al-Harith ibn Tha'labah ibn Jafnah ibn Amr Muzayqiya ibn Amir Ma' al-Sama'. His saying: "Around the grave of their father"—which is the meaning Ibn al-Sirafi did not know—means that they are kings who do not leave their country and where their father's grave is; they are not nomadic Bedouins moving from land to land. As Imru' al-Qays said mentioning a Bedouin woman moving from water to water:
*Is it because of a Bedouin woman whose family settled ... south of Al-Mala that your eyes are rushing [with tears]?*
*So their tears are pouring, spilling, continuous rain ... sprinkling, dripping, and streaming.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Zayd al-Khayl said:
*Mazyad wished for Zayd, so he met ... a brother of trust when the spearheads clashed.*
*Like the wish of Jabir when he said: Would that I ... encounter him and lose some of my wealth.*

He said: Mazyad is a man from Banu Asad. He used to wish to meet Zayd al-Khayl. Zayd al-Khayl met him and stabbed him, so he fled from him. Zayd said regarding that poetry, the beginning of which is what I recited.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*If the neighbor of the house is between Muharib ... and Abs, then do not give him glad tidings of honor or victory.*
*Their defense of him when they gather ... they found [like] the defense of the two labia of the clitoris.*
This amount mentioned by Ibn al-Sirafi regarding the story of this verse does not avail the beneficiary anything. He also did not mention Jabir, who he was among people. He is a man from Ghatafan. He wished for Zayd, who is from Bahila [correction: Zayd is Tayyi, context implies a mistake or specific alliance context here? Zayd al-Khayl is well known as Tayyi. Perhaps the text implies Jabir wished for Zayd?]. Zayd came upon him in the morning. His wife said to him: "You used to wish for Zayd, so here he is with you." They met and exchanged two stabs while both were armored. Jabir's spear broke and availed nothing. Zayd stabbed him with a spear of his called 'Ilaj—and on every joint was a band of iron—and knocked him out so he flipped over, back to belly, and his back was broken but he did not kill him. His wife said when she came to him—lifting him with a broken back—: "You wished for Zayd so you met a brother of trust."

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Abu al-Khatharim al-Bajali said—in the boasting contest (*munafarah*) of Bajila and Kalb, when they sought judgment from Al-Aqra' ibn Habis, and Bajila said 'We are brothers of Nizar' and they have stories—so Abu al-Khatharim said regarding that:
*O Aqra' ibn Habis, O Aqra' ... Indeed I am your brother so look at what you do.*
*Indeed, if you throw down your brother, you will be thrown down ... Indeed I am the caller of Nizar, so listen.*
He said: He made *tusra'u* (you [pl.] will be thrown down) for the plural, meaning Al-Aqra' and his people, and there is no witness in it for this aspect. This Rajaz is narrated with genitive rhyme (majrur), and he recited:
*O Aqra' ibn Habis, O Aqra' ... Indeed I am the caller of Nizar, so listen.*
*In a lofty [place] of honor and a refuge.*
*And standing, then say in the assembly ... to the man Arta'ah: I am the son of Al-Aqra'.*
*Behold, this is a day of height and gathering ... and a sight for him who saw and a place of hearing.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*My two friends, does the appearance of the peaks of the mountains ... heal the hearts of passion? No, rather it increases it.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
The amount that Ibn al-Sirafi knew about this Rajaz and mentioned yields no benefit to the beneficiary; rather, it increases his ignorance and blindness. Furthermore, he erred in the amount he mentioned from several aspects. Among them is that he attributed this Rajaz to Abu al-Khatharim al-Bajali, but he is Ibn al-Khatharim, who is Amr ibn al-Khatharim al-Bajali. Among them is that he mentioned the boasting contest was between Bajila and Kalb, whereas it was between two men, not two tribes: Jarir ibn Abdullah al-Bajali and Khalid ibn Arta'ah ibn Khushayn ibn Shabath al-Kalbi. Among them is his saying: Bajila said we are brothers of Nizar, and he did not clarify the brotherhood from which side it is. Among them is his saying: This Rajaz is narrated with genitive rhyme, whereas they are two separate Rajaz poems, so he mixed the pasture with the neglected camels; one of the Rajaz poems is nominative (marfu'), and the other is genitive (majrur). The explanation of that will come to you, Allah willing.

Abu al-Nada dictated to us saying: The cause of the boasting contest between Jarir ibn Abdullah al-Bajali and Khalid ibn Arta'ah ibn Khushayn ibn Shabath al-Kalbi was that Kalb had captured a man from Bajila in the Jahiliyyah called Malik ibn Utbah from Banu Adiyah ibn Amir ibn Qadad. They brought him to Ukaz. The Adi man passed by a cousin of his called Al-Qasim ibn Aqil ibn Abi Amr ibn Ka'b ibn Arij ibn al-Huwayrith ibn Abdullah ibn Malik ibn Hilal ibn Adiyah ibn Amir ibn Qadad, who was eating dates. He took some of those dates to seek protection/hospitality thereby. The Kalbi pulled him away. Al-Qasim said to him: "He is a man of my clan." He said to him: "If he had a clan, they would have defended him."
So Al-Qasim went to his cousins, Banu Zayd ibn al-Ghawth, and asked them to follow him. They said: "We are cut off among the Arabs, and we have no group to be strong with." So he went to Ahmas and asked them to follow him. They said: "Whenever a hair from Banu Zayd flies into the hands of the Arabs, do we want to follow it?" So he went then to Jarir ibn Abdullah and spoke to him. Al-Qasim used to say: "The first day I was shown dyed clothes and red domes was the day I came to Jarir in Qasr." He [Jarir] was the master of Banu Malik ibn Sa'd ibn Zayd ibn Qasr, and they were his father's sons. He called them to reclaim the Adi man from Kalb, and they followed him. He went out walking with them until he attacked the dwellings of Kalb at Ukaz, and snatched Malik ibn Utbah al-Adi from them. Kalb stood against him. Jarir said: "You claimed that his people would not defend him?" Kalb said: "Our group is absent." Jarir said: "Even if they were here, they would not have defended anything from you." They said: "It is as if you are arrogant over Quda'ah... If you wish, we will compare glory with you." The leader of Quda'ah that day was Khalid ibn Arta'ah ibn Khushayn ibn Shabath. He said: "Our appointment is next year at the market of Ukaz."
So Kalb gathered and Qasr gathered, and they came to Ukaz the next year. The one in charge of Kalb's affair who brought them the next year was Khalid ibn Arta'ah. They made Al-Aqra' ibn Habis ibn Iqal ibn Muhammad ibn Sufyan ibn Mujashi' the judge; both tribes accepted his judgment. They placed the bets in the hands of Utbah ibn Rabi'ah ibn Abd Shams among nobles of Quraysh. Among the stakes from Qasr was Al-Asram ibn Awf ibn Uwayf ibn Malik ibn Dhubyan ibn Tha'labah ibn Amr ibn Yashkur ibn Ali ibn Malik ibn Sa'd ibn Nadhir ibn Qasr. From Ahmas, Hazim ibn Abi Hazim and Sakhr ibn al-Ulbah. From Banu Zayd ibn al-Ghawth ibn Anmar, a man.
Then Khalid ibn Arta'ah stood and said to Jarir: "What shall we wager?" He said: "The risk is in your hand." He said: "A thousand red she-camels for a thousand red she-camels." Jarir said: "A thousand virgin slave-girls for a thousand virgin slave-girls. Or if you wish, a thousand yellow ounces [gold] for a thousand yellow ounces." He said: "Who guarantees fulfillment for me?" He said: "Your guarantor is Al-Lat, Al-Uzza, Isaf, Na'ilah, Shams, Ya'uq, Dhu al-Khalasa, and Nasr. So who guarantees fulfillment for you?" He said: "Wadd, Manat, Fals, and Rida." Jarir said: "You have for fulfillment seventy boys, having uncles on father's and mother's side, placed in the hands of competent men from the people of Allah [Quraysh]." So they placed the pledge from Bajila and Kalb in the hands of those we named from Quraysh, and appointed Al-Aqra' ibn Habis judge, who was the scholar of the Arabs in his time.
Al-Aqra' said: "What do you have, O Khalid?" He said: "We descend the open land, and we stab with spears, and we are the youths of the morning." Al-Aqra' said: "What do you have, O Jarir?" He said: "We are the people of yellow gold, and the red dyed [clothes], we frighten and are not frightened, we feed and do not ask for food, and we are a tribe unpolluted/free, we feed as long as the winds blow, we feed the month and guarantee the era, and we are the kings of Qasr."
Al-Aqra' said: "By Al-Lat and Al-Uzza, if you competed with Caesar king of the Romans, and Chosroes the great of Persians, and Al-Nu'man king of the Arabs, I would have judged you superior to them."
Nu'aym ibn Hajbah al-Namari approached—and Qasr had gifted a horse to Jarir, so he rode it from its off-side (wahshi). It was said: "He does not know how to ride a horse." Jarir said: "Horses are auspicious (mayamin), and we only ride them from their right sides (wujuh/right)."
Amr ibn al-Khatharim, one of Banu Jusham ibn Amir ibn Qadad, had called out saying:
*Let no youth overcome today your two clients*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*O sons of Nizar, help your brother ... I found my father to be your father.*
*And I found no lineage for me other than you ... Abundant rain, extending is your dew.*
*Until the people settle in your pasture ... You are the joy of the eye of him who sees you.*
*It was filled so it sees none but you ... He has won, the day of boasting, who called you.*
*And no one counts your pebbles [numbers] ... And if they built, they did not reach your building.*
*A glory your father built for you two ... That, and he who helps the likes of you.*
*A day when your fire is kindled.*

And he also said:
*O family of Nizar, he has risen in the rugged mountain ... The call of a caller, the call of the seeker of help.*
*O family of Nizar, then strive and ride ... O family of Nizar, there is no way away from you.*
*Indeed your father is my grandfather and my father ... The client is not helped if you do not get angry.*
*O family of Nizar, I did not lie ... I encompassed your lineages and my lineage.*
*And whoever you are his glory is not overcome ... He rises to a pure, noble glory.*
*As if he is in the tower at the star.*

And he also said:
*O family of Nizar, a call of the morning ... The matter has exposed us, a disgrace.*

And he also said:
*O Aqra' ibn Habis, O Aqra' ... Indeed I am your brother so look at what you do.*
*Indeed, if your brother is thrown down, you are thrown down ... Indeed I am the caller of Nizar, so listen.*
*I have a lofty [place] of his glory and a refuge ... by it the capable harms and benefits.*
*And I repel injustice tomorrow and benefit ... A glory, fierce, high, not suppressed.*
*People follow it and it does not seek followers ... Is he anything but a tail and shins?*
*And lower legs, mixed, gathered ... And a lineage and shackles and a cut nose?*

And he also said:
*O Aqra' ibn Habis, O Aqra' ... Indeed if you throw down your brother you are thrown down.*
*Indeed I am the caller of Nizar so listen ... In a lofty [place] of his glory and a refuge.*
*Stand standing then say in the assembly ... to the man Arta'ah: O son of the club-footed.*
*Behold, this is a day of height and gathering ... and a sight for him who saw and a place of hearing.*
So Al-Aqra' judged him superior by virtue of Mudar and Rabi'ah, and were it not for them, the Kalbi would have won.

S said: The kinship between Bajila and the children of Nizar was that Irash ibn Amr ibn al-Ghawth ibn Nabt ibn Malik ibn Zayd ibn Kahlan ibn Saba' ibn Yashjub ibn Ya'rub ibn Qahtan went out for Hajj. He married Salamah bint Anmar ibn Nizar, and they resided together in the abode in the lowland of Tihama. She bore him Anmar ibn Irash and men. When Irash died, a dispute occurred between Anmar ibn Irash and his brothers regarding the division. So he withdrew from his brothers, and his brothers stayed in the abode with their maternal uncles. Anmar ibn Irash married Hind bint Malik ibn Ghafiq ibn al-Shahid, and she bore Aqil, who is Khath'am, then she died. Then he married Bajila bint Sa'b ibn Sa'd al-Ashirah, and she bore him Abqar—she named him after her grandfather Sa'd, and he was nicknamed Abqar because he was born on a mountain called Abqar—and she also bore Al-Ghawth, Wadi'ah, Suhaybah, Khuzaimah, Ashhal, Shahla', Saniyah, Tarif, Fahm, Jad'ah, and Al-Harith.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Dirar ibn al-Azwar said:
*And if you asked Janub about us, she would inform ... an evening Aqraba flowed with blood.*
*An evening when spears did not avail their place ... nor arrows, except the determined Mashrafi [sword].*

He said: Aqraba is a specific place, and Janub is a woman. He meant that they fought a fierce battle at Aqraba until blood flowed in it.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Indeed its two sides, if they separate ... crush the clumsy villager.*
Ibn al-Sirafi was not of the men of this poetry, by making the first verse have *iqwa* (rhyme defect), whereas it has no *iqwa* according to those who know it. He stated that Aqraba is a specific place. What benefit is under this speech if Aqraba is not known in which land it is, and what the reason for Dirar mentioning it was? If you understood the story of this poetry, you would know that Ibn al-Sirafi fell short of knowing it.
Abu al-Nada dictated to us saying: Dirar ibn al-Azwar is the Knight of Al-Muhabbar in the Ridda (Apostasy) wars for Banu Asad ibn Khuzaimah. Khalid ibn al-Walid had sent him with cavalry to Al-Ba'udah—a land of Banu Tamim—so he killed Malik ibn Nuwayrah, the knight of Banu Yarbu', there (and Banu Tamim claims he granted him safety). Dirar ibn al-Azwar fought fiercely that day. He said regarding that—and news of his people Banu Asad's apostasy had reached him:
*O Banu Asad, what you have done has grieved me ... And there is no sanctuary for a people who fought Allah.*
*And I know truly that you have erred ... Banu Asad, so retreat or advance.*
*I forbade you from plundering your alms [Zakat] ... and I said to you: O family of Tha'labah, know.*
*You disobeyed the possessors of wisdom among you and obeyed ... Dajim, and the command of the son of the foundling woman is more ill-omened.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*And they have sent a delegation to the people of Dumah ... So ugly is the delegation and he who intends [it].*
*And if you asked Janub about us, she would inform ... an evening Aqraba flowed with blood.*
*An evening when spears did not avail their place ... nor arrows, except the determined Mashrafi [sword].*
*If the disbelievers seek Janub ... unrepentant, then I am a follower of the religion, so know.*
*I fight since fighting is booty ... and Allah knows best the striving servant.*
Dajim is Talhah ibn Khuwaylid [the false prophet], and his mother was a Himyari captive. The son of the foundling woman is Uyaynah ibn Hisn. His saying: "O family of Tha'labah": he meant Tha'labah al-Hillaf ibn Dudan ibn Asad. Abu al-Nada said to us: Aqraba with a Ba is a land in Yamama. He said: And Aqrama with a Mim is in Yemen. He recited for a man from Ju'fi regarding the killing of Malik ibn Mazin, one of Banu Rabi'ah ibn al-Harith:
*You mutilated our noses with a viper at al-Dhahab ... so we turned on your noses, so they became cut off.*
*So whoever is grieved by the killing of Malik ... indeed we left him thrown down at Aqrama.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Qays ibn al-Khatim said:
*If our swords fell short, their reach was ... our steps towards our enemies, so we strike.*
*And I strike them on the day of the garden, bare-headed ... as if my hand with the sword is the kerchief of a player.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*And I am the most wretched of people if I were indebted ... my camels wandering between al-Liwa and Aban.*
I do not cease from fatigue in returning what Ibn al-Sirafi errs in to the state of correctness; it is as if I am the mother of a camel [caring for it]. That is because he attributed a verse by Ruqaym al-Muharibi to Qays ibn al-Khatim, and corrupted the verse to make it a witness in grammar. The verses belong to Ruqaym al-Muharibi, and they have nominative rhymes, not genitive.
*And we are the children of the fierce war, we kindle it ... and by war we were named, so we are Muharib (Warrior).*
*If our swords fell short, their reach was ... our steps towards our enemies, so we strike.*
*So that annihilated us and left tribes ... who protected themselves by us when the battalions struck us.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Hassan said:
*Perhaps forbearance wasted by lack of wealth ... and ignorance covered over by bliss.*
*I do not care if a goat bleats at al-Hazn ... or a mean person blames me in absence.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Where are you today, and where is a rider from you ... who dismounted at midnight at al-Nabk.*
Meaning how can he reach you and approach you. How can this second verse be following the first, when the first is by Hassan, and the second is by Abd al-Rahman his son, in verses with which he satirized Miskin ibn Amir al-Darimi? They are three verses, which I present:
*O reviler of me for the lineage of my like ... You are only wandering in error.*
*Do not insult me, for I am not a captive ... Indeed the captive among men is the generous one.*
*I do not care if a goat bleats at al-Hazn ... or a mean person blames me in absence.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Ajir al-Saluli said:
*And a 'Mustalham' (one sought in war/overwhelmed) whom the adversary struck a blow ... of few clients, obtained what was defended.*
*I returned to him what he exceeded in speech in the forenoon ... and yesterday, until I tracked him while he was humble.*
*And that was not because he was my cousin or my brother ... but whenever I own the harm, I benefit.*
He said: Perhaps a *mustalham* whom his adversary struck with an argument.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*You have begun to rise in your error, bewildered ... Indeed error is the son of Al-Alal, so desist.*
Ibn al-Sirafi went astray here because he did not know the verse preceding this verse, and that it is conjoined to it. The verse before it is:
*Nay, adversaries will weep for me, and an assembly ... and disheveled ones who were insulted in the presence of the house, hungry.*
The beginning of the verses is:
*If I die, the people will be halves: a gloater ... and another praising what I used to do.*
*Nay, adversaries will weep for me, and an assembly ... and disheveled ones who were insulted in the presence of the house, hungry.*
*And an oppressed one (*Mudtahad*) whom the adversary struck a blow ... of lowly clients, obtained what was defended.*
So the wording of the verse is *Mudtahad* not *Mustalham* as Ibn al-Sirafi claimed.
*I returned to him what the people advanced in the forenoon ... and yesterday, until he attained it while he was strong.*
*And I am not his client nor his cousin ... but whenever I own the harm, I benefit.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Kulhabah—and his name is Hubayrah ibn Abdullah from Banu Urayn ibn Tha'labah ibn Yarbu'—said:
*I commanded them my command at the bend of al-Liwa ... and there is no command for the disobeyed except wasted.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*And every love except for Su'da is pure ... [departing] to its people from us with peace.*
This wisdom should be returned to Ibn al-Sirafi with blame, for the man is *Ibn* al-Kulhabah, not Al-Kulhabah as he mentioned. Al-Kulhabah is his mother, a woman from Jurm ibn Rabban. His name is Hubayrah ibn Abd Manaf ibn Urayn ibn Tha'labah ibn Yarbu', and he is the uncle of Waqid ibn Abdullah ibn Abd Manaf.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Ru'ba said:
*My daughter says: It has neared, your time.*
*So seek determination from Allah and leave your 'perhaps' [hope].*
*O my father, perhaps or maybe.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Hub hub (call to camels), it is a day of trampling and mixing.*
Ibn al-Sirafi confused here because the date stones are similar [things look alike], and he misread a word in the verse also, which is his saying: "Ya Abata" (O my father), whereas it is "Ta'anniyan" (Acting slowly/deliberately). The explanation will come to you in its place, Allah willing. That is because his saying: "So seek determination from Allah and leave your 'perhaps'" is from one Urjuzah (poem), and his saying: "Slowly, perhaps or maybe" is from another Urjuzah. The one containing "So seek determination from Allah" is his saying praising Al-Harith ibn Sulaym al-Hujaymi:
*My daughter says: It has neared, your time.*
*So seek determination from Allah and leave your 'perhaps'.*
*And he attains the need, your planner.*
*He had been folding the earth, your ascender.*
*You are feared and hoped for, and your brilliance is seen.*
*So I said: I am seeking your aid, with you.*
*Rain, and I do not seek the Arak tree.*
*So convey to Banu Umayyah the kings.*
*In Syria, and the Caliph the owner.*
*And in Khurasan, so where is that.*
*From me, and I have no power for that.*
*Or travel to Kerman, you will find your brother.*
*Indeed in it is Al-Harith, if he meets you.*
*He gave a gift that was not weak.*
These are verses from which I mentioned the amount needed here.
The other Urjuzah he praised Ibrahim ibn Arabi with, which is:
*When you put down the saddle and the rear pad.*
*From the loin of a traveler that emaciated you.*
*More captive than her evening, your strap.*
*Yellow from the attack of the midday heat, sticking.*
*The yellowing of the hands of the bride, the aromatics.*
*Slowly! Perhaps or maybe.*
*Ibrahim asks: What distracted you.*
*From two years that came successively.*
*Stripping the Talh tree and the Arak.*
*They did not leave a sandal nor a strap.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: 'Itr ibn Dajajah said, and perhaps it appeared in copies as Anz ibn Dajajah ibn al-'Itr, and the first narration is more famous, and he attributed him in his poetry as Dajajah ibn al-'Itr. And it is narrated for Mu'awiyah ibn Kasir al-Mazini:
*O my night, what is my night at al-Baldah ... it became confused over its stars so it returned.*
It consists of verses.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Indeed the Tufawi, the brother of the Ya'sub (male bee/leader) ... in every tribe there is a share for them.*
Ibn al-Sirafi left no name without assigning a share to it, due to his ignorance of names and genealogies. The correct view is what Abu al-Nada informed us, that he is Dajajah ibn 'Itr, with Kasra on the Dal in Dajajah, and the 'Ayn of 'Itr, and the Ta dotted with two dots from above, and the Ra undotted. He said: The man's name is Dajajah with Kasra, and the bird is Dajajah with Fatha on the Dal. The second short piece belongs to this Dajajah, not to Mu'awiyah ibn Kasir.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Sa'd ibn al-Mutanahhir, who is Jahili (Pre-Islamic), said:
*O Bajji, O Bajji, perform my brother.*
*Indeed my brother is among you, not an adopted one.*
*And a free woman bore him, not a fornicator.*
*From the children of Imran ibn Amr ibn Adi.*
Ibn al-Sirafi said: He meant O Bajilah, so he truncated (tarkhim) after truncation. This poetry clarifies what Sibawayh went for.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*There is no water in the reservoir if you do not rise ... attacking with the head of the camel turned sideways.*
I had mentioned to you in more than one place in this book that whoever embarks on explaining such poetry, regarding genealogy or story, without having mastered these two sciences—is exposed to disgrace. Even if Sibawayh's Book and Al-Farra's Definitions were coupled with this poetry, its meaning would not be known except by knowing its story. The last verse also has a defect, and its correction is: *From the children of Amr ibn Imran ibn Adi*.
The story of this poetry is that the mother of Walan ibn Amr ibn Imran ibn Adi ibn Harithah ibn Amr ibn Muzayqiya ibn Amir ibn Ma' al-Sama' ibn Harithah ibn Imru' al-Qays ibn Tha'labah ibn Mazin ibn al-Azd—she was Azzah bint Malik from Bajila. Walan is Shukr, and it is Shukr Qarni, a nickname. She took him to Bajila, so Bajila used to say: He is one of us. So Sa'd ibn al-Mutanahhir al-Bariqi, a Jahili poet, said:
*O Bajji, O Bajji, perform my brother.*
*Indeed my brother is among you, not an adopted one.*
*And a free woman bore him, not a fornicator.*
*And indeed, the wife of my father was from the children of Amr ibn Imran ibn Adi.*

Chapter of Inna

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
Ibn al-Sirafi said: Dajajah ibn Abd al-Qays said in the Chapter of Inna:
*An oath came to me from people: We will surely ride ... against me, while before me are the hills of Ghul, advancing (Muqadim).*
*Absolve yourself and treat your own soul and look ... O Abu Ja'l, perhaps you are dreaming.*
He said: Al-Hadb: Plural of Hadbah, which is the mountain. Muqadim: Advancing (feminine plural), and the singular of Muqadim is Muqadimah. Ghul: A specific place. And Hadb is nominative by inchoative (Mubtada'). It is permitted to narrate *layarkabunna* (they will surely ride) in the passive voice, so *al-Muqadim* would be its subject, and it would be the plural of Miqdam, and *duni* (before me) would be the predicate of Hadb.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*What a twisting Mayyah twists ... while she has no large apron.*
Ibn al-Sirafi strove and raved in this poetry after misspelling it, but he did not succeed. This is among the most disgraceful things he came up with, which is his saying "Hadb Ghul Muqadim," due to his ignorance of the stopping places. The correct reading is: *Hadb Ghul fa-Qadim* (The hills of Ghul then Qadim). They are two valleys belonging to Al-Dabab, and rarely does Ghul appear in poetry separate from Qadim. Al-Harith ibn Amr ibn Kharjah al-Fazari recited to us:
*You remembered the daughter of Al-Sa'di a remembrance, while before her ... was the mill of Jabir, and my family occupied Al-Adahim.*
*Then the rugged ground of Qutayyat when the mind was good ... then Kabshat Ma'ruf, then Ghul, then Qadim.*
The verse in the Book belongs to Dajajah ibn Abd al-Qays, not Dujanah ibn Abd al-Qays as Ibn al-Sirafi mentioned.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Hatim ibn Abdullah al-Ta'i said:
*Their slaughterer brought a lean, dry she-camel ... in the head of it and in the loins there is salting (fat/goodness).*
*When the milch-camels went early to pasture, I bound them ... and no noble of the children is given the morning drink.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*As for the camel, it is a thing I will not give ... and your love of the sheep is the love of the parent for the child.*
Neither in poetry does Ibn al-Sirafi succeed, nor in genealogy, nor in the names of stopping places and water sources, as was said:
*You exhausted me at the end of the sky, and the end of building, and the end of sleep, and the end of drowsiness.*
This verse belongs to a man from the Ansar from al-Nabit. He has a long known story with Hatim and Mawiyah bint 'Afzar, and for that reason, I omitted mentioning it. The verses are:
*Why did you not ask the Nabitis what is my reckoning ... in the winter when the wind blows?*
*Their slaughterer brought a lean, dry she-camel ... in the head of it and in the loins there is salting.*
*And their scout said: Their wealth is equal ... two likes: A like for one who grazes and pasturing.*
*When the milch-camels went early to pasture, I bound them ... and no noble of the children is given the morning drink.*
So look how much confusion occurred in what Ibn al-Sirafi presented of this poetry.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: A man from Banu Sulaym, who is Anas ibn al-Abbas, said:
*No lineage today and no friendship ... the hole has widened on the patcher.*
And in some copies: *The tear has widened on the stitcher.*
He said: Some narrators claimed that Al-Nu'man ibn al-Mundhir sent an army to Banu Sulaym for something he held against them. Over the army was a man known as Kafir ibn Fartana or Amr ibn Fartana. He passed with the army by Ghatafan, so they sought their help against Banu Sulaym. Banu Sulaym defeated the army, and Amr ibn Fartana was stabbed and captured. Ghatafan pleaded to Sulaym by the kinship between them. So Abu Amir, the grandfather of Al-Abbas ibn Mirdas, recited a poem in which [he said]: What was between us and Ghatafan has been cut off by what they did. Its beginning is:
*Indeed Baghid is a rebellious lineage ... neither trusted nor trusting.*
*No lineage today and no friendship ... the hole has widened on the stitcher.*
*No peace between me, know it, nor ... between you, as long as my shoulder bears.*
*My sword; and we were not in Najd when ... the pigeon of the valley cooed at the peak.*
He said: His saying "pigeon of the valley": he means the pigeons whose nests are in the trees of the valley, flying onto the mountains and cooing.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*They came to the lizard-hunting of the Dabab as if ... they came to the fat she-camels of Amarah ibn Ziyad.*
Ibn al-Sirafi prolonged the speech in explaining this poetry and broadened it, then followed this arrogance with what yields no benefit. That is because he brought a story that falls under the ruling of night-tales, which is his saying: "Al-Nu'man sent an army..." to the end of the story. In the verses he cited, there is disturbance and deficiency, and he did not know the meaning of the last verse, which is the intended one. The story of this poetry—as I read it to Abu al-Nada in the Book of Banu Sulaym—he said: Abu Amir ibn Harithah al-Sulami neighbored his maternal uncles Banu Murrah. They drove away his camels. So he went out, along with Murrah ibn Jariyah, Sunnah ibn Jariyah, and Sinan ibn Jariyah, until they attacked Banu Murrah between Abanayn, killing people from them and driving away great camels of theirs. Murrah ibn Jariyah returned reciting Rajaz:

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*O Murr, indeed I am your pure friend ... and you are my uncle and I am the namesake.*
*And the distant lineage might be humiliated.*
And Abu Amir recited Rajaz and said regarding that:
*The people ask me: Where is my wealth? ... Do not ask me, but ask my maternal uncles.*
*O Lord of water belonging to you at Al-Ajdal ... at Ghaybagh, drawn with the rope.*
*Into which falls the fruit of the palm/mistletoe.*
Abu Amir said regarding that:
*I know my maternal uncles and call them ... as if my mother there was from Bariq.*
*No lineage today and no friendship ... the hole has widened on the stitcher.*
*Indeed Baghid is a canceled lineage ... neither trusted nor trusting.*
*Our swords take the first of them ... the snatching of the stick of the gathering water-provider.*
*No peace between me, know it, nor ... between you, as long as my shoulder bears.*
*My sword; and we were not in Najd when ... the pigeon of the valley cooed at the peak.*
The meaning of his saying: "And the pigeon of the valley cooed at the peak" means that a torrent comes which the meadows cannot accommodate, so it resorts to the trees and peaks. Then the pasture and fertility abound, and war is stirred up between them.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Ibn al-Ruqayyat said:
*May Allah not bless the beautiful women; do ... they arise except having a demand?*
He said: The witness in it is that he moved the Ya of *Al-Ghawani* with Kasra for necessity.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Hunger drives her to the bitter tree.*
The verse is only evidence in case of necessity if there isn't another narration in the place of the witness that is better than the first, and it is not possible to narrate it in another way. As for this verse which he cited, another version has been narrated by Al-Asma'i, which is:
*May Allah not bless the beautiful women; and do ... they arise except having a demand?*
The reliance of the arguer on this verse indicates that he was not abundant in narrating poetry. If he had argued with the saying of the sayer:
*The clients have almost taken away the world and its pleasure ... like the rams of the 'Aws (sheep), fat.*
*There is not one among them but at his waist ... for his door, from the craft of the smith, is a key.*
It would have been stronger and more upright for the argument.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Akhdar ibn Hubayrah al-Dabbi said:
*I am not, on the day of the two Raqams, recoiling ... nor is the sword, if I drew it, blunt.*
*And I was not a Dhaffat (one rushing to food), but a seeker ... who stayed a little upon the back of a path.*

He said: Al-Akhdar ibn Hubayrah al-Dabbi said this poetry regarding a son of his whom Tuhayyah killed in a war between them.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*A day on Dhat al-Shuquq, sunny ... followed by a drought in the bellies of al-Rah.*
Such poetry exhausts its interpreter—if he is not deeply versed in knowing the Days (battles), and not abundant in narrating poetry. Ibn al-Sirafi erred here from [several] perspectives: One is that he attributed this poetry to Al-Akhdar ibn Hubayrah, and it is not his. Then he brought two verses distorted from the path of correctness. And such poetry—if its story is not fully known—its meaning is not known at all.
The story is that Al-Harith ibn Hatib al-Jumahi was over the charities of Amr ibn Hanzalah, and Marwan ibn al-Hakam had appointed him. Banu Tuhayyah made food for him, and Awf ibn al-Qa'qa' made food for him. The food of Banu Tuhayyah was ready before the food of Awf, so Al-Harith ate their food. Zuhayr ibn Shaddad al-Mithawi gifted a bowl of Hays to Awf ibn al-Qa'qa'. He rejected it and said: "He thinks we eat Hays in which the testicles of Zuhayr spent the night dripping." Evil occurred between them, and they threw stones at each other. A man from them threw Qays ibn Awf ibn al-Qa'qa' with a stone on the center of his liver, and he died. The Rajiz of Banu Tuhayyah said:
*We killed Qays in the brawl ... then we ate the Hays after that.*
So they sought the help of Al-Harith ibn Hatib, and claimed the throwing against Zuhayr ibn Shaddad. They established proof against him. He called Al-Harith ibn Tuhayyah, and the witnesses were impugned. Al-Akhdar ibn Hubayrah ibn al-Mundhir ibn Dirar al-Dabbi stood up and said to the witness who testified against Zuhayr: "I do not know that I have seen an obscenity except that I have seen this one riding it, except that I have not seen him screwing his mother." So they nullified this man's testimony against him.
Then Al-Akhdar ibn Hubayrah said:
*I defended Zuhayr after he thought that he was ... mixing seriousness; there is no falsehood in seriousness.*
*I defended and threw the heavy weight before him ... a connection; a joiner will not lack good.*
*At an hour whose address no one ... of the people is capable of unless a speaker is granted success.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
Qays ibn Awf left two sons: Murriq ibn Qays and Shihab ibn Qays. Murriq's name was Utybah; he was named Murriq because there was a war between Banu al-Qa'qa' ibn Ma'bad and Banu Ubayd ibn Khuzaimah ibn Zurarah. His grandfather Awf ibn al-Qa'qa' saw him while his horse was passing through the dust with him. He said: "Who is the owner of this passing (Muriq) horse?" It was said: "Utybah, your son." So he was named Murriq. Death approached Shihab, so he said to his brother Murriq: "O my brother, I died a mean death, so die a noble death." A man from Banu Tuhayyah named Hakim ibn Barq exited performing Hajj. Murriq ibn Qays intercepted him—having hidden two men with him. Murriq said: "O uncle, we are riders who stopped at the flow of this valley, and we disputed, and there is no person of reason among us to reconcile us. If you would turn and reconcile a group of Muslims." So he went with him. When he descended into the valley, the two men jumped on him and made him kneel, holding him. Murriq struck him and killed him, and began to say:
*I am not, on the day of the two Raqams, incapable ... nor is the sword, when I executed it, blunt.*
*So do not grieve, O clan of my mother, for I ... spent the night a killer of you with a killed one.*
*And I was not a Dhaffat, but an avenger ... who made [his camel] kneel a little upon the back of a path.*
*If the echoes [of the dead] tell anything, they would tell ... Shihab that I have healed my burning thirst.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Imam ibn Aqram al-Numayri said—and I doubt regarding Aqram: is it with Ra or with Zay—:
*And when I emerged to my weapons ... and Bushra, I said: I am not the poor one.*
*The freedman of Allah; no favor upon him by ... Abu Dawud and Ibn Abi Kathir.*
*Nor Jaz', nor Ibn Abi Sharif ... nor the client of the Emir, nor the Emir.*
*Nor Al-Hajjaj; my eye is the daughter of water ... turning her gaze in fear of the falcons.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Lead the chests of the white camels, O Ibn Bishr ... to the right of the setting place of the Vulture star.*
*Beware of doubt and weakness of the matter.*
If the explainer is doubting, how will the condition of the one explained to be? Anyone whose extent of knowledge of poetry is this amount should not address explaining such poetry and mentioning its speakers. The correct name is Aqram with an undotted Ra. Ibn al-Sirafi did not explain Bushra either, and it is the strangest thing in this poetry; it is the mare of Imam ibn Aqram al-Numayri.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Nabih ibn al-Hajjaj al-Sahmi said:
*They [dual fem.] asked me for divorce when they saw me ... my wealth was little; you two have brought a terrible thing.*
*Woe! Whoever has property is loved ... and whoever becomes poor lives a life of harm.*
*And perhaps wealth will increase with me ... and my back will be stripped of debts.*
*And slaves will be seen for us, and maids ... and servants from workers, ten.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*He left the joints of bones to their owners ... and turned to pick the marrow of the hamstring.*
Ibn al-Sirafi was ignorant of the speaker of this poetry, who is from the best of Quraysh, and attributed the poetry to Nabih ibn al-Hajjaj, who is from their worst. This poetry belongs to Zayd ibn Nufayl, and its beginning in order is:
*Indeed my two wives speak to me blame ... deliberately, a speech of falsehood and desertion.*
*They asked me for divorce when they saw me ... my wealth was little; you two have brought a terrible thing.*
*Lower [your voices], I have nothing but the command ... and the pauper must have patience.*
*For perhaps wealth will increase with me ... and my back will be empty of debts.*
*And slaves will be seen for us, and maids ... and servants from newborn girls, ten.*
*So we will drag the trails in the bliss of a man ... You two say: Put down your staff for an eternity.*
*Woe! Whoever has property is loved ... and whoever becomes poor lives a life of harm.*
*And he is avoided [in] the secret of matters, but ... the possessors of wealth are the attenders of every secret.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Abdullah ibn Rawahah said:
*That you spend the night sleeping, pillowed ... struggling with the blanket or twisting the hand.*
*Is easier than your driving until you reach Najd.*

Ibn al-Sirafi was not one who mastered the science of Rajaz and investigated it, for he did not bring these verses consecutively despite their fewness. The correct version is:
*O Zayd, Zayd of the working camels, the lean ones.*
*And Zayd of the desert of the wasteland, the unknown place.*
*The night has grown long, you have been guided, so descend.*
*So Zayd swooped down like the swooping of the falcon.*
It is Zayd ibn al-Arqam al-Ansari; he said it on the dispatch of the Muslim army to Mu'tah.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Hassan said:
*Do not forbid a behavior and do the like of it ... It is a disgrace upon you, if you do, great.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*There is no cure for one who has no shame.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
Whoever has this merchandise of poetry, it is right for him not to expose himself to explaining poetry and mentioning its speakers given his ignorance of them. This verse is not by Hassan; rather it is by another, Al-Mutawakkil al-Laythi admonishing his son, and it is well-known poetry "not hidden from the hyena."

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Amr ibn Ma'di Yakrib said:
*Salma and her female neighbors knew ... no one threw down the horseman except me.*
*I pierced his chest/belt area with the spear ... while the horses run in groups between us.*

He said: *Qatara al-Faris*: He threw him on one of his *qutrayn*, meaning his two sides. In speech resembling this.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*The day was long for one who has no drink ... and no comforter except the prison of Dawwar.*
This amount mentioned by Ibn al-Sirafi in explaining this poetry is of little avail to the beneficiary, because the true meaning is hardly known except by knowing the story related to it. That is because Amr ibn Ma'di Yakrib charged on the day of al-Qadisiyah against a Marzban (Persian commander)—thinking he was Rustam—and killed him. So he said regarding that:
*Visit Salma before she departs ... Indeed for Salma with us there is a habit.*
*Salma and her female neighbors knew ... no one threw down the horseman except me.*
*I pierced his chest/belt area with the spear ... while the horses run in groups between us.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Miskin al-Darimi said:
*And Nabigha al-Ja'di, in the sand is his house ... upon it is a slab of marble, placed.*
*Ibn Ju'ayl's day came in Al-Jazirah ... and he parted the world and what he used to gather.*

He said: He meant that the grave of Al-Nabigha is in the sand. He mentioned the state of the earlier poets, and that they perished and went and no one remained of them. He belittles the matter of the world and scorns it.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Look with your eyes; and does looking heal?*
What Ibn al-Sirafi mentioned in explaining this poetry avails not a wick's worth. That is because he did not bring the two verses consecutively, but left a verse between them. Then he did poorly in his saying: "The grave of Al-Nabigha is in the sand." Were it not that the poet intended by this a meaning hidden from Ibn al-Sirafi—and did not intend *a* sand from the sands here indefinitely—he would have been correct in what he said. But he meant here the sands of Banu Ja'dah, which are sands beyond Al-Falaj. He only specified these sands as having the grave of Al-Nabigha al-Ja'di because it is his land. In this poem, he mentioned poets, attributing the grave of each one to his country and birthplace. The verses indicate what I told you, and they belong to Miskin ibn Amir al-Darimi:
*And I am not more alive than men I saw ... for every man one day is a death and a falling place.*
*The caller of deaths called Dabi', so he came to him ... and when they called by the name of Ibn Darah, they made [him] hear.*
*And Hisn, in the desert of Al-Thawiyyah is his house ... Indeed, the world is but an enjoyment to be enjoyed.*
*And Aws ibn Maghra' al-Quray'i has settled ... for him above the tents of Al-Riyahi a lying place.*
*And Nabigha al-Ja'di, in the sand is his house ... upon it is a slab of marble, placed.*
*And a group from Himyar did not return ... to Ibn Wathil his soul when it was being pulled out.*
*I see Ibn Ju'ayl, in Al-Jazirah is his house ... and he left the world and what he used to gather.*
*In Najran the limbs of Al-Najashi have become ... birds seek refuge in him, circling and landing.*
Do you not see that he placed the house of Ibn Ju'ayl in Al-Jazirah because it is the land of Banu Taghlib, and placed the grave of Al-Najashi in Najran because he is from Yemen, the land of Banu al-Harith ibn Ka'b.
*And Shammakh has died, and Muzarrid has died ... and which mighty one, you have no father, is protected?*
*Those are people who have passed to their path ... just as Luqman ibn Ad and Tubba' died.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Akhtal said:
*If Sadus is stingy with her two dirhams ... then the wind is good, blowing from the east (Qabul).*
He said: His saying: "Then the wind is good, blowing from the east"—it was said in its explanation: The earth is wide, man aims from it wherever he wishes, and in whatever directions of the wind he wishes to travel, he travels.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
