*I want his union and he wants my abandonment ... and how far is the affection-refuser from the affectionate mother.*
Al-Akhtal intended by this verse a meaning other than what Ibn al-Sirafi went to. The meaning of his saying: "If Sadus is stingy with her two dirhams... the verse" is: We are wealthy in our condition; their withholding from us did not harm us and we did not become weak. Similar in meaning is the saying of Nasr ibn Sayyar to Banu Tamim:
*If you help us, we are not honored by your help ... and if you forsake us, then the sky is sky [high].*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Adi ibn Rabi'ah al-Taghlibi—brother of Kulayb and Muhalhil sons of Rabi'ah—eulogizing Muhalhil, and mentioning those who perished of his people:

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*A gazelle from the gazelles of Wajrah reaching ... with her hands to the fresh leaves.*
*She struck her chest towards me and said ... O Adi, for your yearning heart.*
*What do we hope for in life after drinking companions ... whom you see having been given the cup of shaving [death] to drink.*

He said: He means he is yearning for those who perished of his people.

S said: Ibn al-Sirafi erred in the second hemistich of the second verse. The correct version is:
*O Adi, the protectors have indeed protected you.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Zuhayr said:
*If you settled at Jaww among Banu Asad ... under the religion/obedience of Amr, and Fadak came between us.*
He said: Al-Jaww is the valley, Al-Din is obedience, and Amr is Amr ibn Hind the King.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*I hinted with speech I thought her above ... understanding, but Sulayma came with the obscure stories.*
Often Ibn al-Sirafi misspells in obvious things that schoolboys would not misspell. That is his saying: "If you settled at *Jaww* among Banu Asad" with Jim dotted once below, then explaining it as the valley, and he erred in this too. The correct reading is: "If you settled at *Khaww*" with Kha dotted from above. Khaww is a valley belonging to Banu Asad, and there Utybah ibn al-Harith ibn Shihab was killed. Abu al-Nada recited to us for Ramah bint Husayn al-Asadiyyah—and she was Jahili (Pre-Islamic) as he claimed, and she mentioned Khaww and other lands of Banu Asad—:
*I am blamed regarding Najd, and whoever has a love ... in Najd, various desires stir his longing.*
*The south wind stirs him when it comes early with its scent ... Yemenite, and the lightning if its flasher flashes.*
*And whoever blames me for the love of Najd and its people ... then let him be blamed for the like, and let his mutilator make it thorough.*
*By your life, regarding the flood-channels, the channel of Muqallad ... then Dhu Nujub, its thickets and pushers.*
*And Khaww, when its showers watered Khaww ... and its Tyn and its Rabai' became fertile.*
*And the voice of a whistler [bird] answered at midnight ... whoever stays awake for it hears it.*
*Is dearer to us than the chickens of a village ... clucking, and a settlement where its frogs croak.*
He said: Al-Rabai' are sides of the land of Banu Asad. He recited to us:
*And between the two Khawws is a wide alley ... an alley between Al-Tin and Al-Rabai'.*
Al-Tin is a mountain belonging to Banu Asad. Another recited:
*A flashing lightning kept me awake tonight ... before it are the two Tins and Al-Rabai'.*
*Then Waridat, then Qana, then Al-Na'i' ... and from the peak of Laman is a lofty hill.*
Al-Awam ibn Abd al-Rahman said mentioning Al-Tin, so he dualized it too:
*Is it true, O peak of the two Tins, that I am not seeing ... your summits except my eye is pouring [tears]?*
Fadak is thirteen days from Mecca in the land of Banu Sulaym.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Farazdaq said:
*I did not cease opening doors and closing them ... until I came to Abu Amr ibn Ammar.*
*Until I came to a youth, pure, his nature is ... bitter of determination, free and son of free men.*
He said: He praises Abu Amr ibn al-A'la, and Ammar is a grandfather of his ancestors.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*O would that Murrah were a man ... who could bear weapons and suffice a group.*
If Ibn al-Sirafi knew this obvious amount of genealogy, I would have been spared speaking on it. Ammar is his nearest grandfather, not "a grandfather of his ancestors" as he claimed. He is: Abu Amr Zabban ibn al-A'la ibn Ammar al-Mazini, from Banu Mazin ibn Malik ibn Amr ibn Tamim. Qurad ibn al-Ayyar al-Mazini meant him by his saying:
*If the man does not have angry for him when he gets angry ... horsemen who if told 'Ride death' they ride.*
*And a mighty people did not grant him victory ...*
These are well-known verses.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: The daughter of Abu al-Husayn from Madhhij said:
*We and Bahila ibn Ya'sur, between us ... is the disease of co-wives, hatred and mutual abuse.*
*Whoever of us is caught is not returning ... ever, and the killing of Banu Qutaybah is healing.*
He said: She said these verses in a war between them and Bahila.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Far be it! You seek a thing you will not attain ... Who will provide the deaf with the sound of the bass and treble [strings]?*
Far be it that the beneficiary benefits from anything Ibn al-Sirafi mentioned in this poetry. This poetry is not by the daughter of Abu al-Husayn ibn Madhhij; rather, it is by the daughter of Murrah ibn 'Ahan. She said it when Bahila killed her father at Armam. It is:
*We and Bahila ibn Ya'sur, between us ... is the disease of co-wives, hatred and mutual abuse.*
*Whoever of us is caught is not escaping ... ever, and the killing of Banu Qutaybah is healing.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*Qutaybah went in the encounter with a knight ... not reckless, trembling, nor hesitant.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Akhzam ibn Qarib al-Ta'i, and it is said Al-Muq'ad ibn Amr, said:
*And their sayer says while glancing behind him ... O length of this day! Will it not end?*
*Hallaq (Death) caught up with them on their rear parts ... striking of necks, and the booty is not important.*
He said: *Hallaq* is death (al-maniyah), and it is a dominant adjective like *Jada'*: which is the year of drought.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*So I do not see Amr returning after this ... nor did a day come to us where Amr benefited us.*
Ibn al-Sirafi did not bring any benefit here, for he made the beneficiary doubt this poetry, saying once: It is for Al-Akhzam, and once for Al-Muq'ad. Then he confused in his saying: "Hallaq caught up with them." The correct reading here is: *Lihyaq caught up with them*, and *Lihyaq* is from the wording of the verb [Lahiqa], as he said:
*When he said 'Awfa' (fulfill), a Drukah (overtaking) overtook him.*
The verses belong to Al-Akhzam al-Sanbasi; he said them on the Day of Qarat Huwq between Jadilah and Al-Ghawth. They are:
*When the two raiding parties met, the raiders of Tayy ... each says: Our tribe will not be defeated.*
*So the two gatherings collided, then overcame them ... hardship and a sword for death, sharp.*
*Short-haired horses pacing with the heroes to the battle ... their groups follow in succession when bridled.*
*Wide-chested, the shouting has frightened its heart ... quick in its legs, and short-haired, huge.*
*Jadilah calls, while the spears overturn them ... until a dark road became clear with them.*
*And their sayer says while glancing behind him ... O length of this day! Will it not end?*
*Lihyaq (Overtaking) caught up with them on their napes ... cutting of necks, and the booty is not important.*
*Except for killing their nobles, since they exceeded ... they have advanced from their doom what they advanced.*
*Bujayr inspires while the spearhead is in his throat ... and says: We are more undutiful to you and more unjust.*
*They claimed that we do not wheel our steeds ... and they are the horsemen, and the horsemen know best.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Yazid ibn Sinan ibn Abi Harithah al-Murri said:
*So I was not cowardly and I did not recoil, but ... I aimed with it at Abu Sakhr ibn Amr.*
*So if he recovers, I did not blow [magic] on him ... and if he perishes, then that was my destiny.*
He said: Yazid ibn Sinan had killed Abu Amr ibn Sakhr al-Qayni, and he was the master of Banu al-Qayn. What is in the Book [Sibawayh] is: *Abu Sakhr ibn Amr*, and what I found in the poetry is: *Abu Amr ibn Sakhr*.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*I think thoughts of her and I do not know ... Did Su'da kindle them or Ramim?*
Ibn al-Sirafi became confused here: he said once Yazid ibn Sinan killed Abu Sakhr ibn Amr, and said another time: And what I found in the poetry: Abu Amr ibn Sakhr. He did not exit the darkness of doubt, nor did he know the story of this poetry correctly. Then he brought the last verse of this poetry and placed it at its beginning, so he deserved that the proverb be applied to him:
*A vulgar woman, my family married me to her ... A reckless one who thinks my head is my foot.*
And he did not know the story of the verses either. The cause of this poetry is that Banu al-Qayn killed Qays ibn Zuhal al-Murri. Yazid ibn Sinan ibn Abi Harithah met them and killed Abu Amr ibn Sakhr al-Qayni, so he said:
*When I saw the sons of Huyayy ... I remembered my hatred among them and my vengeance.*
*I shot them with a Wajzah (arrow/spear) when they connected ... so they could shoot its throat from near and my throat.*
*When I pierced them, it returned against them ... as if its foal was among them and my young camel.*
*At Dhat al-Ramth when they lowered the upper spears ... as if their blades were scattered coals.*
*So I was not cowardly and I did not recoil, but ... I aimed with it at Abu Amr ibn Sakhr.*
*I pierced the meeting places of the backbones of him ... with a penetrating [blow/arrow] amidst shock and panic.*
*I left the spear swaying in his loins ... as if its head was the beak of a vulture.*
*So if he recovers, I did not blow on him ... and if he perishes, then that was my destiny.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Hutam al-Qaysi said:
*The night wrapped her with a driver who crushes.*
He said: Thus I found it in the Book. This verse differs regarding its speaker. I found it attributed to Abu Zaghbah al-Ansari in poetry he said on the Day of Uhud:
*I am Abu Zaghbah, running with the old camel.*
*Disgrace is not prevented except by pain.*
*A Khazraji from Jusham protects the sanctuary.*
*The night wrapped her with a driver who crushes.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Do not pass on to a youth you seek his favor ... when you meet Al-Musawir ibn Rabab.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
He should not have skipped what he found in the Book, as he said: It belongs to Al-Hutam al-Qaysi, which is explicit and correct. Al-Hutam is Shurayh ibn Dubay'ah ibn Sharhabil ibn Amr ibn Marthad. He was named Al-Hutam only because when he returned from his raid from Hadramawt, he said while driving [camels] with his companions:
*The night wrapped her with a driver who crushes (Hutam).*
*Not a shepherd of camels or sheep.*
*Nor a butcher on the back of a chopping block.*
These are well-known verses.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Nusayb al-Aswad said—and this Nusayb is not Nusayb al-Aswad al-Marwani—:
*I remained at Dhu Dawran seeking my young she-camel ... and I have no young she-camel upon it nor a young he-camel.*
And he mentioned four other verses.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*A collapsing cliff, and a clearing cloud.*
Ibn al-Sirafi's turning away from verifying the author of this poetry after this arrogance announces his ignorance of him. That is because he mentioned that its author is Nusayb al-Aswad and not Nusayb al-Marwani. So if it is neither this one nor that one, is it Nusayb the semen? The poetry belongs to Nusayb ibn Rabah al-Aswad al-Habaki, the client of Banu al-Hubayk ibn Abd Manat ibn Kinanah. Its beginning is:
*O eagle of the nest, the nest of Dariyah ... May you be watered by the morning clouds, O eagle on a nest.*
*Clarify to us, may your feathers not cease to be soft ... and may you not cease to be a bird with dyed claws.*
*I saw you among birds, surpassing above them ... at the bend of the valley, the crooked one with Sidr trees.*
*The nights pass as they passed, and I do not see ... the passing of nights making me forget the daughter of Al-Nadr.*
*She says: Connect with me and abandon me, and you may see ... if you abandoned, that there is no connection with abandonment.*
*So I was not pleased with what she said and did not show anger ... and my chest became tight with what I mumbled of her love.*
*So am I anything but like the animal driven by enemies ... if it advances, slaughter; and if it retreats, hamstringing.*
*I remained at Dhu Dawran seeking my she-camel ... and I have no young she-camel upon it nor a young he-camel.*
*And I do not ask the shepherds except for a diversion ... with the one of bright teeth, of good scent.*
*So the shepherds said to me: She did not mix with us ... So I said: Yes, indeed I was remembering her.*
*And a familiar one was mentioned to me at the dune ... young camels of Sulaym or young camels of Banu Wabr.*
*So a group said: No. And their group said: Yes. And a group said: Woe to you, we do not know.*
*Nay, by the One whom the Talbiyah-chanter performed Hajj to His House ... and honored the signs of sacrifices and slaughter.*
*Indeed, nights Layla spent at Al-Jafr ... increased my love for Al-Jafr and its people.*
*So does Allah count it a sin against me that I mentioned her ... and diverted my companions with her on the night of departure?*
*And I flew, while there was no boredom in me nor slumber ... and no fatigue or slackness in the riding camels.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Awf ibn Atiyah said:
*Why did you not attack your mother's son, Ma'bad ... while the Amiri was leading him with a bond?*
*And remember a drink from the milk of Al-Muhallaq ... while the horses were running in the highland, scattered.*

S said: Ibn al-Sirafi erred in narrating this verse, which is his saying: "Why did you not attack your mother's son, Ma'bad." The correct reading is: *Why did you not turn to your brother Ma'bad*, because he addressed Laqit with this poetry, and Ma'bad is his brother from his father and mother.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Aghlab al-Ijli said:
*A girl from Qays ibn Tha'labah.*
*Slender-waisted, possessing a concave navel.*
*Firm of the upper part, heavy of the hips (buttocks).*
*As if she is the ornament of a gilded sword.*
He said: His saying "As if she is the ornament of a sword" means in her glitter and beauty.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*The desire of my she-camel is behind me, and my desire is ahead ... and she and I are different.*
The poet's intent in these verses is other than what Ibn al-Sirafi went to. That is because he imagined they were ghazal verses intended for a beautiful matter, and did not know what follows it, for it leads to obscene satire, and this description is a digression to it. These verses are by Al-Aghlab satirizing Kalbah, and Kalbah used to satirize him. She is the one who says to Al-Aghlab:
*The father of Kalbah screwed the mother of Al-Aghlab.*
*So she jumps upon his penis.*
*The jumping of the dog to lick the hare.*
And Al-Aghlab's verses are:
*A girl from Qays ibn Tha'labah.*
*Slender-waisted, possessing a concave navel.*
*Firm of the upper part, heavy of the hips.*
*As if she is the scabbard of a gilded sword.*
*An old man, strong of nerve, fell for her.*
*Firm of flesh, his penis like wood.*
*So she struck with love upon the tip of the nose.*
*Then she bent back with it above the neck.*
*So she announced with her voice: O father!*
*Every girl is impressed with her father.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*So he said regarding the kindnesses at the organ (need).*
*It suffices the blame of the dyed woman hating her husband.*
*Hard, like the leg of the pruned young palm tree.*
*In its head is like the knotted leather bag.*
*He hastens before what is in her with gurgling.*
Al-Aghlab also said regarding her:
*Will a poet overcome me, wet of vulva.*
*Mixed, his black and his red.*
*His weapon on the day of excitement is a censer.*
*Soft, when he fights a peer, he overwhelms him.*
*Kohl-eyed, sweet of appearance.*
*More perfect than him is his color and his eye-socket.*
*And the body is complete, and his appearance is complete.*
*Wearing a necklace and bracelet.*
*Slender of waist, adorned by his rear.*
*Like a sand dune, his waist wrapper stuffed.*
*Dyed of extremities, free of skin.*
*His coquetry and look please the bed-partner.*
*While she calls out under him and urges him.*
*And he is intense in his erection and his masculinity.*
*Until his probe disappears in the scabbard.*
*She said to him in some of what she shares.*
*Who buys my sword while this is its trace.*
This is a proverb saying: Who wants this when this is its effect? As if she is promoting her goods, saying: This is it.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Layla al-Akhyaliyyah said:
*You assault Suwar for glory and highness ... and it is in my dhimma (guarantee), if you did, he would do.*
He said: Suwar is Suwar al-Qushayri. He used to exchange satire with Al-Nabigha al-Ja'di. Al-Nabigha said something to Suwar that angered Layla, so she satirized Al-Nabigha.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Do not recite poetry.*
Ibn al-Sirafi explained this poetry without reflection. Layla did not get angry for what Ibn al-Sirafi said, but rather she got angry because of Al-Nabigha's saying about her in a poem of his:
*Leave aside the satire of men and turn ... to an Adhla'i (large penis) that fills your anus and flows.*
Al-Nabigha only satirized her because of her saying:
*Qushayr, and if I praise Qushayr, for they are ... the builders of the endeavors of Amir and its masters.*
When Al-Nabigha satirized her, Layla said in a poem answering him: "You assault Suwar... the verse".

Ibn al-Sirafi said: The poet said:
*The tribes of Ma'add and others knew ... that the generous one is Muhammad ibn Utarid.*
He said: He is Muhammad ibn Utarid ibn Hajib ibn Zurarah al-Darimi.

S said: This lineage was hidden from Ibn al-Sirafi, and the poetry deceived him, for poetry is a place of necessity. He is Muhammad ibn Umayr ibn Utarid ibn Hajib ibn Zurarah.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Shammakh said:
*O distract me before the raid of Sinjal ... and before early deaths and appointed times.*
*And before the separation of the people, between a plunderer ... and another plundered, falling between heroes.*
He said: Sinjal is a place in the region of Azerbaijan, or a man's name. Al-Shammakh eulogized with this poem a man from Banu Layth ibn Abd Manat ibn Kinanah.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Al-Ja'di does not know the core of the Ghayl ... nor the Ancient Falaj except by guessing.*
Ibn al-Sirafi's guessing does not yield certainty, and this indicates a deficiency he had, which is his saying: Sinjal is a man's name or a place name. Sinjal is a village of the villages of Azerbaijan. The one eulogized in the poetry is Bukayr ibn Shaddad ibn Khalid ibn Amir ibn al-Mulawwah ibn al-Shaddakh ibn Ya'mar ibn Awf ibn Ka'b ibn Amir ibn Layth ibn Bakr ibn Abd Manat ibn Kinanah.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Sibawayh said in the Broken Plural, Hakim ibn Ma'yah al-Rab'i from Banu Tamim said:
*In it are 'Ayayil (thickets), lions, and leopards.*
He said: What is in his poetry is *Ghayayil*. And *Ayyal*: The strutting one, and its plural is *Ayayil*. He described before the verse a spear that grew in a place surrounded by mountains and trees, so he said:
*Surrounded by mountains, peaks, and acacia trees.*
*In the thick of the forests, wrapped in the enclosure.*
*In it are 'Ayayil, lions, and leopards.*
He said: And what is in his poetry is *Usudin* (lions) in the genitive, by adding *Ayayil* to it.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Fresh news has come to you from me ... true if Al-Waddakh did not lie.*
Ibn al-Sirafi misspelled in his saying *Ayayil* that it is with an undotted Ayn, so he lied. The correct word is *Ghayayil* with a dotted Ghayn, plural of *Ghayl* (thicket/forest) on a non-standard measure. His saying: "He described a spear" confuses the person, so he imagines he meant by the spear here a weapon he stabbed with. Rather, he meant by the spear here stubborn might and sturdy honor. What precedes it of verses indicates that to you. It is:
*I protect a solid spear/honor that does not break.*
*Hard, completed in a lofty, high place.*
*Surrounded by mountains, peaks, and acacia trees.*
*In the thick of the forests, wrapped in the enclosure.*
*In it are Ghayayil, lions, and leopards.*
*Quivering, making the noses of the unwilling bleed.*
*When the straightener bites it, it does not bend.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Zabban ibn Sayyar al-Fazari said:
*I traveled to you from Janfa' until ... I made [camels] kneel at the courtyard of your house at Al-Matali.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*For young camels that wandered a month ... in error/loss, did not travel to an error.*

He said: Zabban ibn Sayyar had bestowed favor upon Hanzalah ibn al-Tufayl ibn Malik, then Zabban traveled to him seeking reward. Al-Matali is the plural of Matla', which is soft ground. He says: Camels that wandered a month in error, meaning that after their journey and arrival, they did not obtain anything of what they wanted, so their journey was an error (loss). He says: Young camels that traveled a month in error did not travel to an error regarding the one they traveled to, because he rewarded and compensated him, so his camels did not travel in error like the camels of another man who traveled a month to a place he wanted and obtained nothing from it.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*She gathered firewood from dry and wet ... to her tent my firewood ends.*

Ibn al-Sirafi emptied his quiver here, bringing much nonsense of which not a year [tooth/truth] is sound. I had mentioned to you that whoever undertakes explaining this poetry without mastering the science of genealogy, days of the Arabs, and knowing the stopping places and water sources, his mistakes will be many. What benefit is there in his saying: "Zabban ibn Sayyar had bestowed favor upon Hanzalah ibn al-Tufayl ibn Malik, then Zabban traveled to him seeking reward"—without mentioning whether he rewarded him or not? He left the speech truncated due to his ignorance of this story. If he knew the stopping places and water sources, he would know that his saying: "Al-Matla': The soft ground" is obscene. The correct reading is Al-Matla with Fatha on the Mim and shortening (Qasr). It is a valley in the land of Banu Kilab belonging to Banu Abi Bakr. The sayer meant it when he says—recited to us by Abu al-Nada—:
*The pigeon sang on the branches of a thicket ... of the lote trees of Bisha, wrapped in its upper parts.*
*Singing not Arabic songs, with tongues ... of Persians, and the most pleasant gesture is their gesturing.*
*So I said, while the white camels were sunken-eyed in their reins ... twisting the clothes of my companions vying with them:*
*My young she-camel grazes the Arak trees, then I water her ... at the water of Al-Harirah and Al-Matla, so I give her drink.*
*O two palm trees of the belly of Matlub, I became familiar with you ... for the soul does not end its wishes regarding you.*
*And towards you is a filth in the people, no womb ... brings it close to us, nor a favor it repays.*
*Surrounded by the shadow of death, you two overlooked ... at the head of a hill, difficult are its ascents.*
*Whoever Allah gives your shade in the world ... He writes for him degrees highly in it.*
*Your shade is moist while the sun is rising ... until its driver hides it in the lowland.*
*Both of you, the Basil branches are your sprout ... so its morning side was turbaned with the tall, succulent [plant].*
Matlub: A water source of Banu Abi Bakr. Zabban pluralized Al-Matla with what is around it, making it Al-Matali. Sometimes they dualized Al-Matali and said Matlayan. A Bedouin said:
*I watered Jarir on the day passion threw him ... and Busra, and the winds led your spare horses.*
*May Allah water Najd in spring and summer ... and single out its highlands and sides.*
*To Ajla, then the two Matlas, then Farahis ... There is passion if only a thing approached.*
Ibn al-Sirafi did not know Janfa' either, that it is in the land of Banu Fazarah, and that Zabban said: I only traveled to you from Janfa', i.e., from the land of my people. Regarding Janfa', the Rajiz says—and shortening it is a necessity, and it is a proverbial verse—:
*If you reach Janfa, then sleep ... and increase then in dreams.*
His saying "at Al-Matali" meant the land of Hanzalah ibn al-Tufayl ibn Malik. If he knew the story of the poetry as it is, he would not have said regarding the meaning of "error, they did not travel to an error" that it is praise; this is complete stupidity. The story of this poetry is that Zabban ibn Sayyar captured Hanzalah ibn al-Tufayl ibn Malik, and bestowed favor upon him. Then he came to him seeking reward, but he [Hanzalah] did not approve his reward. It is said he imprisoned him and sent his brother with his ransom. So he said:
*The beautiful woman asks about me when ... months passed without her visitor.*
*Why does she say he imprisons me while I have ... a swift camel and straps and a saddle?*
*Seeking thanks did not cease until ... I sat as a hostage while my brother is a warner.*
*A prisoner in the land of Banu Tufayl ... and how does the prisoner sleep in the leather bonds?*
And Zabban also said:
*Is there anyone to convey from me to Tufayl ... and Hanzalah who overcame my request.*
*That young camels cast a month ... in error/loss, they did not travel to an error.*
*We saddled them from Janfa' until ... they knelt in the courtyard of your house at Al-Matali.*
*For sheep have profited with you ... and I will not fill my gaps with them.*
*For if you ask your father about me ... and your mother on the day of the pebble-ground of Dhu Talal.*
*For they, upon captivity, sought help ... from a town of haters, reddish of mustaches.*

text:
*Do I feel safe after Hanzalah son of a female ... with a thing to which my foot did not guide my shoelace?*
*That month was absent from you until ... it came to you for a night after the crescent.*
*And your father said: If my Lord brought ... him a need, then do not give him my wealth.*
*So if you thank, I have bestowed favor among you ... and if you deny/disbelieve, I do not care.*
*And were it not for Amir and the man Amr ... I would have shot at you two the shot of the one shooting high.*
*And were it not for Utbah the praised, I would have brought ... the riders near to you with a brand not worn out.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Sulayk said:
*As if the hooves of Al-Nahham, when ... my company went in the evening, were oyster shells.*
*Upon Qarama', its legs are high ... as if the whiteness of its blaze is a veil.*
He said: Al-Nahham is the name of his horse, and Al-Nahham had died. He said: And I saw some of those who explain poetry mention other than this, and explain the poetry as if the horse is alive. And he said: His saying "its legs are high": He meant that it is complete, having no shortness.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*If the Sidi (wolf/man) is given a choice between error ... and guidance, the Sidi comes to what is erroneous.*
Often Ibn al-Sirafi clings to the bad and leaves the good aside, due to his ignorance of poetry and its meanings. Rather, it is an elegy for Al-Nahham, not praise of it. He also did not know Qarama', in which land it is. Qarama' is a village of Banu Numayr, and there Al-Nahham died.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: The Rajiz said:
*She says: O my Lord, O Lord, will ... if you are saving my ropes from this one.*
*Either by divorce or by 'Ride/Depart'.*
*As if his testicles, from dangling ... were the container of an old woman containing two colocynths.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*If you work, work with seriousness ... and do not be like the processor of skin.*
Ibn al-Sirafi did not know this Rajaz nor its author, and was negligent in extracting its verses correctly. The three verses he cited before his saying "As if his testicles" are all defective. He did not know the author of the Urjuzah either. Its author is Khitam al-Rih al-Mujashi'i, and the order of the verses is as I have established for you here. They are:
*O Lord of a white woman on the soft sands of Al-Armal ... whose eye resembles the eyes of a gazelle.*
*In her is glancing away from a husband, an old man ... and she treats that with endurance.*
*She has become enamored with a youth, huge ... shaking the sides, moist, combed.*
*Thinking himself swaggering though he doesn't swagger ... He sent to her with a summarized messenger.*
*Asking: How is the union with you, or how for me? ... So she did not cease with her husband, the poor one.*
*Send, so be among those going or eat ... And eat what you ate in a lawful place.*
*And burden, O guided one, my camel ... until when satisfaction crept into the joint.*
*And there was in the heart the malice of the cougher ... Then the Sheikh went to her with a bag.*
*Of satisfaction, [like] stones of a pile ... As if his testicles, from dangling.*
*Were the container of an old woman containing two colocynths ... When he went, she began to invoke, not falling short.*
*Saying: Lord, O Lord, hasten against him ... with a stone-bruise that kills him or a boil.*
*Or a snake biting above the connection.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Amr ibn al-As said on the Day of Siffin:
*If I squinted, and there is no squint in me ... then broke the eye without blindness.*
*You would find me twisty, far of bitterness ... possessor of an assault in the great calamities.*
He said: This Rajaz is narrated for Al-Najashi al-Harithi, and I think it is narrated for others besides them too.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*No, not except that you think a thought ... even if the owl sang or trilled.*
If the interpreter interprets poetry with "I think" and "perhaps" and "it is permitted" and "it is narrated"—know that he is a jade (slow horse) in it. This poetry belongs to Al-Musawir ibn Hind, and its beginning is:
*I am, for one who denied my affair, the moon ... I circumcise whom I wish and whom I wish I leave.*
*If I looked with one eye, and there is no blindness in me ... then squinted the eye without squint.*
*You would find me twisty, far of bitterness ... possessor of an appetite in the great calamities.*
*Foul-mouthed if called from a male dog ... Knotted, urinating, nourished in the trees.*
*Carrier of what I carried of good and evil ... Snake of a valley between a rocky ground and a stone.*
*I have almost known the signs of old age ... Sleep at dinner and coughing at dawn.*
*And sharpness of the glance and erratic look.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Muzahim al-Uqayli said:
*And they said: You know the stopping places of Mina? ... Not everyone who comes to Mina do I know.*
He said: *Ta'rifuha* is like *A'rifuha* (I know it/them). *And not everyone who comes to Mina do I know*: his place where he is staying.

S said: Ibn al-Sirafi erred in his saying "And they said" (wa qalu). Rather it is "And they [dual] said" (wa qala). Before the verse is:
*And my passion for her is the passion of one who lost his camel ... at Mecca, upon whom the compassionate ones did not turn.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*He saw roughness from his two companions, and missed him ... at its sandy ground, the hasty, turning camels.*
*So they [dual] said: Do you know the stopping places of Mina? ... Not everyone who comes to Mina do I know.*
And "ta'rifuha" means "do you search/call for it [the lost camel]." Ibn al-Sirafi's explanation of the verse leads a person astray, making him imagine that the phrase "Ana Arif" (I know) is Muzahim expressing about himself. Rather, he mentioned that as a quotation from the one who lost his camel, and mention of him passed in the first verse of these three verses, so know it.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Ja'di said:
*What did you see Al-Saylahin and Bariq ... avail Hujr ibn Umm Qatal?*
*King of Al-Khawarnaq and Al-Sadir and he subdued ... what is between Himyar—its people—and Awal.*
He said: The meaning is that this kingdom did not avail Hujr, nor did what he possessed and gathered push death away from him. In speech resembling this.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*He brought the testicles of Dukan.*
Ibn al-Sirafi brought nothing good here, for he changed the wording of the verse and corrupted it. The correct reading is: *Availed Amr and Umm Qatal*. He means Amr ibn Hind the King, and Umm Qatal is his wife.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Jarir said:
*A slave! He settled in Shu'ba as a stranger ... Is it baseness, may you have no father, and alienation?*
Jarir satirizes with this poetry Al-Abbas ibn Yazid al-Kindi. Shu'ba is a valley or a place.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Only the Arab [pure-blooded horse] witnesses the race.*
Anyone who does not know the names of the stopping places accurately—as I mentioned to you before—will slip in such a slippery place. That is because Ibn al-Sirafi did not mention the reason for Jarir's saying to Al-Abbas ibn Yazid: "A slave! He settled in Shu'ba as a stranger." Why did he make it a satire, and what is the fault in his settling in Shu'ba? He only shamed him for being an ally (*Halif*) to Banu Fazarah, and Shu'ba is from their lands, while he is a Kindite, a stranger in abode to them. Being a *Halif* (client/ally) is a disgrace among the Arabs. From this is the saying of Laqit ibn Zurarah:
*Has anyone seen the two slaves when mentioned to him ... Adi and Taym seeking someone to ally with?*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Marrar al-Faq'asi said:
*Ask worries with every [camel] giving its head ... swift, mixing reddish-white color with *Muta'ayis*.*
He said: *Al-Muta'ayis*: That which leans towards whiteness.

S said: The correct reading is: *Mixing reddish-white color (Suhba) and whiteness (Ta'is)* (*Mukhalit Suhbatun wa Ta'is*). Meaning he mixed the Suhba with the Ta'is; so he conjoined the verbal noun to the verbal noun.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Husayn ibn Yazid al-Harithi said:
*Every year cattle you gather ... a people impregnate it and you deliver [the offspring].*

S said: The author of this verse is a man from Banu Dabbah, who said it on the Second Day of Kulab.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Dhu al-Rumma said:
*So lift the saddle upon a sturdy, strong she-camel ... of Mahri breed, produced by her planter, Al-Id.*
*Looking [far] when the sun rises over its rider ... casting with the eyes of a white bull in which is sharpness.*
He said: Al-Id is a tribe from Mahra.

S said: *Al-Id* came in the poetry out of necessity [of meter], so Ibn al-Sirafi thought it was a verification, due to his stupidity in the science of genealogy. Rather, it is: *Al-Idiyy* ibn al-Nadghi ibn Mahra ibn Haydan. Al-Ra'i said:
*From [the breed of] Al-Idiyy, carrying me and my saddle.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Tufayl al-Ghanawi said:
*Her combs remain absent in the middle of it ... when she lets it loose, or like that, not let loose.*
*If she does not clean her teeth with a stick of Arak ... she selects, then she cleans them with a stick of Is-hil.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Far it is! Between baseness and generosity is a distance ... further than what is between Busra and the Sanctuary [Mecca].*
Between the two verses are many verses which Ibn al-Sirafi did not mention so their order could be arranged. The first of the two verses has disturbance in its beginning. Its correct form and the order of the verses is:
*The combs get lost in her upper braids ... when sent loose or like that, not sent loose.*
*As if the earrings and the ornaments jingled ... upon the two nose-rings of a gazelle whose horn is spun.*
*She spent the months of summer between staying ... in a valley submissive to her, and a soft sand dune.*
*In a wide valley, you find her above her mattress ... heavy in the forenoon, she did not gird herself with a sash.*
*The pigeon sings above her every morning ... the singing of the drunkards in a shaded arbor.*
*When she comes to water, her shepherds water from a sipping-well ... of short rope, its bottom not roped.*
*Adorning the roaming-place of the eye between her pocket opening ... and her upper chest are the middles of onyx, separated.*
*Like the ember of Ghadha wood, the wind blew on it while it was glowing ... with a fan, the north wind did not veil it.*
*And a lush [plant] visited by the rains, as if it is ... extended, the flood fed it from the plant of the squill.*
*If she does not clean her teeth with a stick of Arak ... she selects, then she cleans them with a stick of Is-hil.*
So look now how much is between the two verses—based on what Ibn al-Sirafi presented.

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Najashi said:
*I said to him: O Wolf, do you want a brother ... who consoles without reproach upon you nor miserliness?*
*He said: May Allah guide you to the right path; you have only ... called to that which no beast before me has done.*

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*He does not know the 'Hay'' (come here) from the 'Jay'' (go away).*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Shurayh ibn Imran from Banu Qurayzah, and it is said the poetry belongs to Malik ibn al-Ajlan al-Khazraji:
*Between Banu Jahjaba and Banu ... Zayd; so where is destruction for my neighbor?*
*The guardians of the nakedness [weakness] of the clan, no ... leak comes to them from behind them.*
He said: *Al-Hafizu* (The guardians) is nominative because it is praise, as if he said: They are the guardians of the nakedness. In speech resembling this which does not benefit its hearer.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Indeed Banu al-Ahmar from Fazarah ... do not fear disgrace nor a raid.*
If Ibn al-Sirafi feared shame and avoided disgrace, he would not have satisfied himself with interpreting poetry by saying "it is said" and "I think" and "it is narrated" and the like. The second verse is by Amr ibn Imru' al-Qays in a poem of his forbidding Malik ibn al-Ajlan from war. The first verse is from another poem, and has no connection to the second verse, so he brought them and their author haphazardly. The verses of Amr ibn Imru' al-Qays are:
*O Mal[ik], and the turbaned master might ... be made reckless by some of his opinion, the excess.*
*The slave is not raised above his Sunnah [status] ... and the truth is fulfilled and acknowledged.*
*Indeed Bujayr is a slave to others ... O Mal[ik], and the truth is with him, so stop.*
*For fulfillment will come acknowledging ... the truth in it to you, so do not refrain.*
*We, with what we have, and you with what ... you have, are content, and the opinion differs.*
*We are the patient ones, praised for ... patience, and we are the drawn swords, the disdainful.*
*The guardians of the nakedness of the clan, no ... leak comes to them from behind them.*
*By Allah, our clan is not scorned ... lions of a thicket whose resting place is the reed-beds.*
*If we walk in the Persian [carpets/formation] as ... difficult [unbroken] camels walk, bending.*
*We walk to death due to our protectiveness ... a swift walk, and our judgment is just.*
*Indeed Sumayr, his clan refused ... to pay more than the truth they stipulated.*
*Or to turn back the horses while they are full ... under their ears are skulls, dried.*
*Or swallow the rage as it appears to you ... so practice war where you turn away.*
*Indeed, I belong, when I belong, to ... a high glory, and our people are nobles.*
*White, light, as if their eyes ... are lined with Kohl by the darkness in the epic battles.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Durayd ibn al-Simma said:
*Does it please you that Time is a face [variable] ... upon you, coming and going with its gifts?*
*And that you do not suffer the loss of family and wealth ... whose destruction harms you, and my life is prolonged?*
*So your soul has lied to you, so belie it ... for it is either anxiety or beautiful patience.*
He said: He is addressing his wife, saying to her: If you think or your soul tells you this which I told you about. In speech resembling this.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*You memorized something, and things were absent from you.*
Durayd's purpose in striking this proverb and addressing his wife with it was only a meaning for which he made this digression, which is that he eulogizes with this poetry Mu'awiyah ibn Amr ibn al-Harith ibn al-Sharid, the brother of Al-Khansa, whom Banu Murrah killed. The verses are:
*Is it not that she came early blaming without measure ... and she was harsh with me and entered my veil?*
*If you do not leave my blame foolishly ... your soul will blame you for me in any age.*
*Does it please you that Time is neglected [variable] ... upon me, coming and going with its evil?*
*And that you do not suffer the loss of a soul and wealth ... whose destruction harms you, and my life is prolonged?*
*So your soul has lied to you, so belie it ... for it is either anxiety or beautiful patience.*
*For the calamity, the day I stood calling ... and Mu'awiyah ibn Amr did not hear.*
*I saw his place so I turned askance ... and what a resting place of crookedness, O Ibn Bakr.*
*To stones and rocks and a grave ... and branches of the Salam trees, brown.*
*And the building of graves, there passed over them ... the length of time, of a year and a month.*
*And if you had made him hear, he would have come hastily ... striving quickly or he would have come to you running.*
*With the equipment of a determined one, there is no fault in him ... when the heroes wear the skins of leopards.*
*So if you spend the evening in a grave, staying ... in a place swept by the winds, desolate.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*Then hard upon me is your death, O Ibn Amr ... and I have no determination or patience regarding you.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Ibn Muqbil said:
*O eye, weep for Hanif, the head of their tribe ... the breakers of spears in the nakedness of the rear/turn [of battle].*
He said: Hanif is a clan in Banu al-Ajlan.

S said: This benefit from Ibn al-Sirafi increases the beneficiary's ignorance of this lineage. It is only said: "So-and-so is from Banu So-and-so" if there are fathers and grandfathers between him and the Great Grandfather. But if he is from his loins, it is said: He is his son. Hanif is the *son* of Al-Ajlan, and the name of Al-Ajlan is Abdullah ibn Ka'b ibn Rabi'ah ibn Amir ibn Sa'sa'ah.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Ibn Muqbil said:
*A Yemeni girl circled his old properties ... calling the leaders from Amr and what they gathered.*
He said: Amr is a tribe, and it is Amr ibn Kilab in my opinion. And it is possible he meant Banu Amr ibn Tamim. It is narrated: "The leaders from Bakr," and it is possible he meant by Bakr Banu Abi Bakr ibn Kilab. His saying "Yemeni" does not agree with this explanation, because the tribes I mentioned are all from Nizar [Northern Arabs].

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*You stirred up from the disease what had been obliterated ... as the wind obliterates the trench of the dust.*
If Ibn al-Sirafi had not spoken on this verse, the nakedness of his tongue would not have appeared—may his eye be hot [may he weep]. [He erred from] two aspects: One is that he said: It is possible he meant Banu Amr ibn Tamim. Where are Banu al-Ajlan from Tamim? It is only Amr ibn Kilab. The other is that he said: His saying "Yemeni" does not agree with this explanation, because the tribes I mentioned are all from Nizar. He did not know that Banu Amir are attributed to Yemen because they used to inhabit Najd adjacent to Yemen, and that Ghatafan are called Shamiyah (Levantine) because they inhabit Najd adjacent to Syria/Levant. Therefore, Al-Nabigha al-Dhubyani said in his satire of Zur'ah ibn Amr ibn Khuwaylid ibn al-Sa'q from Banu Nufayl ibn Amr ibn Kilab:
*And you would have been his trustee if you hadn't betrayed him ... but there is no trust for the Yemeni.*
So Zur'ah ibn Amr answered him:
*And which people is more treacherous than a Shami (Levantine/Northern) ... who has two cold places [conditions], loose of tongue.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said regarding the saying of Al-Nabigha al-Ja'di:
*So a day remained for the women of Al-Nu'man from us ... at Safwan, a hard/grieving (Arwanani) day.*
He said: The verse is recited in the poem as *Arwananin* (genitive), attributed (Nisba). He lightened the Ya of attribution from it; he intended *Arwananiyyun* so he lightened it. Similar to it is:
*Indeed, for he who denies me, I am Ibn al-Yathrubi ... I killed Ilba' and Hind al-Jamali.*
He said: He intended *Al-Yathrubiyy* and *Al-Jamaliyy*. It should be written with a Ya because it is attributed, and the doubt is removed from it.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*This has a root, so what is the root of this? ... And I am not far from investigating it.*
*Al-Jamali* is attributed as he mentioned. As for *Al-Yathrubi*, it is a verified name, not attributed, just as they said: Makki ibn Sawadah, and Fadaki ibn Amr, and Idiyy ibn al-Nadghi, and likes of that are many in the speech of the Arabs. Ibn al-Sirafi did not know the speaker of this poetry, nor whom it was said about. It belongs to Abdullah ibn Yathrubi al-Dabbi. Hind al-Jamali is Hind ibn Amr ibn Jandalah ibn Ka'b ibn Rabi'ah ibn Jamal ibn Kinanah ibn Najiyah ibn Yahabir, and he is Murad. He was killed, may Allah have mercy on him, with Ali ibn Abi Talib, peace be upon him, on the Day of the Camel; Abdullah ibn Yathrubi al-Dabbi killed him. He said:
*If you deny me, then I am Ibn Yathrubi ... Killer of Ilba' and Hind al-Jamali.*
*Then Ibn Sawhan upon the religion of Ali.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Jandal al-Tahawi said:
*Did it deceive you that I became few/poor (Taqarabtu), O Abu 'Uray ... and that you saw Time possessing circles [calamities]?*
*It bent my bones and I show it my gaps [missing teeth] ... and applying Kohl to my eye with motes.*
His saying: *Taqarabtu* O Abu 'Uray: He means that he left traveling and journeying to kings, so his camels are gathered, not separating from each other.

S said: Ibn al-Sirafi erred here. The meaning of *Taqarabtu* is "I became few" (Qallaltu), meaning from its fewness, some of it became close to some.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Maqas al-A'idhi, and his name is Al-Nu'man, said:
*Ransom for Banu Dhuhl ibn Shayban is my she-camel ... when there is a day possessing stars, gray.*
*Kalb treated us with hardship, and Taghlib directed ... against our delegates in Al-Jazirah.*
He said: Kalb complained to Yazid ibn Mu'awiyah that a man from Banu Shayban was settled at some waters, and if traveling people passed by him, he prevented them from water. So he wrote to Ziyad, and wars occurred between some of Banu Shayban and others caused by this matter.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*At Dhat Ghisl is what is at Dhat Ghisl ... and Tharmada' is a branch of my mind.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
Ibn al-Sirafi's mind wandered here, and he brought nonsense speech that does not resemble itself nor fit, due to his ignorance of the conditions of the Arabs of the Jahiliyyah and Islam and what is between them. When did Maqas al-A'idhi meet Yazid ibn Mu'awiyah when he was in the deepest Jahiliyyah? He eulogized Sharik ibn Amr Abu al-Hawfazan, and Al-Hawfazan did not reach Islam. He is the one who says regarding Sharik ibn Amr:
*O eye, weep for the youth of wars, Ibn Amr ... and mourn him, for you have been bereft of a great one.*
*O drinking companion of kings, he is given the cup of quenching to drink ... neither spoiled nor bored.*
Rather, the verses of Maqas are verses of boasting about Banu Shayban; he boasted of them while he was from 'A'idhah of Quraysh, except that his count is among Banu Shayban. The verses are:
*Ransom for Banu Dhuhl ibn Shayban is my she-camel ... when there is a day possessing stars, gray.*
*When the flank becomes shivering as if ... it is completed by thousands of horses, brought near.*
*Kalb treated us with hardship and Taghlib directed ... against our delegates in Al-Jazirah.*
*It flew the sandgrouse of peace from every side ... so the caller almost overcame the people.*
*You see the horses galloping, limping as if ... upon them are thickets of blackness, reeded.*
*Defended by them are women, without obscenity ... and the insults of a sheikh who was not reviled.*
*And whoever does not find a building-place for his forehead ... with a master of ours, prominent of horn, gray-haired.*
*And whoever's house his people of glory do not establish ... our house establishes a glory, mighty, strong.*
*And whoever of them is distant from his origin ... then my origin is fixed among them.*
*I pour praise upon them as if I am ... when night covers, a yearning singer.*
*And indeed my life is attached to their life ... and among their dead my bird falls.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Ru'ba said:
*Were it not for my ascending upon the heights, there would have fed me [to death] ... in the desolate desert.*
*In the like of the fall of the Pit of Al-Wassaf.*
*Your saying sayings with swearing.*
*In it is swallowing/slighting, what a swallowing.*
*And Allah is between the heart and the intestines.*
He said: *Al-Huwwah*: The pit/hollow. *Al-Mahwa*: The space between the top of a thing and its bottom. *Al-Wassaf*: A man from the people of the desert; he attributed the pit to him.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*The worst of helpers if you seek his help ... is an old man who if you wake him, scratches his ass.*
Ibn al-Sirafi's saying: "Al-Wassaf here is a man from the people of the desert" indicates that he was weak in the science of genealogy. And his saying "Al-Huwwah: The pit" indicates also his weakness—it was—in knowing the stopping places and water sources of the Arabs. What benefit is there in his saying: "Al-Wassaf is a man from the people of the desert"—whether he is Bedouin or settled—if his name and cause are not known? The Pit of Al-Wassaf (*Huwwat al-Wassaf*) in Ru'ba's poetry is a hole/cavity (Dahl) in Al-Hazn belonging to Banu al-Wassaf from Banu Ijl. Al-Wassaf is Malik ibn Amir ibn Ka'b ibn Sa'd ibn Dubay'ah ibn Ijl ibn Lujaym. The Pit of Al-Wassaf is a proverb among the Arabs, they use it in invoking curses upon a person. It was recited for Al-Haddar ibn Hakim invoking against a person of mixed lineage:
*Whoever cheats or mixes lineage some mixing ... may Allah single him out with a shivering fever.*
*And with a hot water burning the intestines ... and the bitter cold after that, the freezing wind.*
*And may He throw him into the Pit of Ibn al-Wassaf ... so that his grave is far from the graves.*
*You have from me neither muddy nor pure [water] ... except the supplication of Allah, not unjust.*
*He is the One who creates what is in the interiors ... and taught writing with Mim or Kaf.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Abu Tharwan said, and it is narrated for Al-Ma'lut ibn Badal:
*Indeed the gazelle whose inadvertence you hope for ... is a gathering [army] by which Al-Atakan or Atad become narrow.*
*Carrying the rings of the Maziy (armor), urged by ... the Mashrafi [swords] and a forest [of spears] above it, reaped/dense.*
Al-Atakan: Dual of a place name. Atad is conjoined to it. Al-Maziy: The armor. In speech resembling this raving.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*The man is not in anything, and the jerboa is not in anything.*
Neither Abu Tharwan is anything in this poetry, nor Al-Ma'lut. Rather, it belongs to Al-Zibriqan ibn Badr. Ibn al-Sirafi also did not mention in his explanation anything indicating useful benefit, because he did not know its story. Such poetry, if its story is not known, its meaning is not known at all.
The story of this poetry is that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family, sent Al-Zibriqan ibn Badr over the Sadaqat (alms) of Awf ibn Ka'b, and Abd Shams ibn Sa'd, and Imru' al-Qays ibn Zayd Manat. The Prophet, peace be upon him and his family, passed away while many camels from the Sadaqah had gathered in his [Al-Zibriqan's] hand. Tribes apostatized, and some collectors of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family, apostatized and went away with what was in their hands.

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
Among those who apostatized was Qays ibn Asim al-Minqari; he distributed the Sadaqah of the Prophet, peace be upon him, among his people. When Banu Awf and some of Al-Zibriqan's companions saw that, they said: "Do with us as Qays did." He kept delaying them with promises. The Abna' (Sons)—the sons of Sa'd—wanted to demand it. He promised them: "Meet me tomorrow." Then he gathered it and shouted at it [drove it] to Abu Bakr, he and his sons. He said: "O my sons, this is the salvation of the Hereafter and the glory of the World." He and his six sons drove it: Hazn, Taghlib, Ayyash, Al-Hurr, Ziyad, and Bajalah—sons of Al-Zibriqan. Ayyash had no offspring. He said regarding the Abna' when they tried to trick him out of it, in a poem of his:
*O wonder! The 'Uqad (Knots) of the Abna' try to trick me ... and Allah knows best what the 'Uqad try to trick.*
*They marched to us at midnight to carry [it] away ... and there is no hostage except a master, a leader.*
*You have seen settling clans not far ... from you, near, watered on alternate days, before them are lions.*
*March slowly, for we will not miss you ... even if what is between us is easy for you, level ground.*
*Indeed the gazelle whose inadvertence you hope for ... is a gathering [army] by which Al-Atakan or Atad become narrow.*
*Carrying the rings of the Maziy, urged by ... a striking, severe, and stabbing between it, reaping.*
Al-Atakan and Atad are valleys belonging to Banu Bahdalah.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Ajjaj said:
*A striking like Hadhadhik, and stabbing and piercing.*
*It penetrates to the stubborn vein, the flesh.*
*Until they shattered like beads scattered.*
He said: *Darban* (Striking) is accusative by implication of: We strike them a striking like Hadhadhik, i.e., it cuts the meat a cutting after cutting. In speech resembling this that does not heal burning thirst. That is because he did not mention the one praised in this poetry, so the imaginer imagines they are verses of boasting. Rather, they are verses of praise; he praised Al-Hajjaj ibn Yusuf with them. It is:
*So they found Al-Hajjaj refusing oppression.*
*Neither senile nor recently young/tender.*
*And from the pure nobles, pure.*
*He repays them with stabbing, a loan for a loan.*
*And sometimes they advance an obligation.*
*A striking like Hadhadhik, and stabbing and piercing.*
*It penetrates to the stubborn vein, the flesh.*
*Until they shattered like beads scattered.*
These are verses. So his saying "Striking and Stabbing" is actually a substitute (Badal) for his saying "Obligation" (Fardan), and what Ibn al-Sirafi said is not correct.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Mulabbid ibn Harmalah from Banu Abi Rabi'ah ibn Dhuhl ibn Shayban said:
*My camel complains to me of the length of the night journey ... Beautiful patience, for both of us are tested.*
And in his poetry: *My horse complains to me of the fall of spears.*

S said: Agreement of Al-Mulabbid's poetry and the verses of the Book [Sibawayh]. The verse of the Book is not by Al-Mulabbid ibn Harmalah al-Shaybani. Rather, Abu Ubaydah was asked about its author, and he said: It is by some camel drivers. He recited:
*My camel complains to me of the length of the night journey ... O my camel, the complaint is not to me.*
*Beautiful patience, for both of us are tested ... The two Dirhams have burdened me with what you see.*
S said: My memorization is: "Sabran Jamili" (My patience is beautiful). As for Al-Mulabbid's verses, there is no "beautiful patience" in them. They are:
*My horse complains to me of the fall of spears ... Patience, Jamil, for both of us are tested.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Ibn al-Zubayr al-Asadi said:
*Convey to Yazid son of the Caliph that I ... met from injustice the one with a blaze and white legs [conspicuous injustice].*
*If it were you, if the like of it bit you ... you would have dragged upon whatever you wished a chest and a breast.*
*And I was your brother of truth in every scene ... of pain, even if they boiled my flesh in a cauldron.*
Ibn al-Sirafi mentioned in the explanation of these verses something of syntax and language that does not benefit its reader much. I had mentioned to you that such poetry, if its story is not known, its meaning is not known at all. Ibn al-Zubayr satirized with this poetry Abd al-Rahman ibn Abdullah ibn Rabi'ah ibn Habib al-Thaqafi, and his mother was Umm al-Hakam bint Sakhr ibn Harb ibn Umayyah, and he was over Kufa. The cause of his satire of him was: That people from Banu Alqamah ibn Qays ibn al-A'sha ibn Najrah killed a cousin of Ibn al-Zubayr from the descendants of Al-Ashyam ibn al-A'sha. Abd al-Rahman guaranteed to Ibn al-Zubayr two blood-monies against the people, but refused to grant him retaliation (Qisas). Abdullah [Ibn al-Zubayr] got angry and refused to accept. He went out to Yazid ibn Mu'awiyah—and Yazid hated Abd al-Rahman—so Abd al-Rahman sent in pursuit of him, and he was returned to him. He fled from him, so he took his women and imprisoned them and demolished his house. So Ibn al-Zubayr said:
*Convey to Yazid son of the Caliph that I ... met from injustice the one with a blaze and white legs.*
*I met by analogy of the matter a hardship ... and a day at Jaww that was most arduous and longest.*
*And I was your brother of truth in every situation ... of pain, even if they boiled my flesh in a cauldron.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*And if it were you, if the like of it bit you ... you would have dragged upon whatever you wished a chest and a breast.*
*And I was a right hand to your left wherever ... your hands pointed with it, until it separated.*
*And indeed, the son of a stick belonging to Al-Bazikh made me kneel ... at Jaww, indeed he gave me a misleading resting place.*
It was said to Umm al-Hakam while she was with Abdullah [al-Thaqafi]: You married this Thaqafi while you are who you are and he is who he is? She said: A husband from a stick ('Ud) is better than sitting (Qu'ud) [spinsterhood].

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Aghlab said:
*The length of nights hastened my undoing.*
*They took some of me and left some of me.*
*They bent my length and bent my width.*
*They made me sit after the length of my rising.*

S said: This Rajaz is not by Al-Aghlab; it is like others of the stray Rajaz. Its beginning and completion is:
*I have become such that some of me does not carry some of me.*
*Exhausted, I go like the emaciated camel.*
*The passing of nights hastened my undoing.*
*They folded my length and folded my width.*
*Then they stripped the flesh from my bones.*
*They made me sit after the length of my rising.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: The poet said:
*And you are a man from the people of Najd, and our family ... is Tihami, so what [connection] is the Najdi and the Tihami [dweller]?*
That is: You are a man different from us in the place you inhabit of the earth. You are from the people of Najd, and we are from the people of Tihama, and the two places are different, so we do not agree, and what is between us is far like the distance of our land from your land.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*I want small things from Hunayn so they twist ... against me; and from where are small things for Hunayn?*
The meaning of the verse and the poet's intent is not what Ibn al-Sirafi went to. Between the correct [view] and what he said is what is between Jabalqa and Jabarsa. The meaning of the verse—which is by Jamil—is that my family will be suspicious of you if they find you with them, because you are a stranger, far of abode from them, so they will deny your presence among them. So you must avoid and turn away. She warns him of her male cousins. He recounts that from Buthaynah. The verses clarify this meaning for you, Allah willing. They are from a poem of his:
*And the last covenant I had with her was the day she bid farewell ... and a cheek, pure, and an eye-socket appeared to us.*
*An evening she said: Do not waste our secret ... when you are absent from us, and guard it when you are present.*
*And do not let the tribe know if you come visiting ... for you are seeking us, not when you turn back.*
*And your glance, if you come to us, guard it ... for the deviation of passion is apparent to one who looks.*
*And turn away if you meet an eye you fear ... and show some [indifference], for that is more concealing.*
*For if you expose me in speech ... a slanderer, increasing in what you said, will increase.*
*And spread a saying among the friend and others ... whose spreading is hard upon us when it is spread.*
*And I did not cease working your glance towards us ... with your eyes until your secret almost appeared.*
*To my family, until every advisor blamed me ... compassionate, having kinship with me and a bond.*
*And the friend cut me off regarding you in blame ... and indeed I disobey their prohibition when I am rebuked.*
*And I did not say this, know well, to cut ... the rope, nor is this shortening [of love] for an hour.*
*But rather I, my family be your ransom, fear ... the eyes of the haters against you and I am cautious.*
*And I fear my cousins against you, and sometimes ... the thinker fears and his honor is kept pure.*
*And you are a man from the people of Najd, and our family ... is Tihami, so what is the Najdi and the Tihami?*
*A stranger, when you come seeking a need ... and enemies are around me, and you are conspicuous.*
*So I said to her: You have advised, O Buthn, sufficiently ... and every man whom Allah does not guard is exposed.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said in explaining his saying: *And she wiped the crushed antimony (ithmid) on the gums*.
Ithmid was not among the things found in the land of the Arabs, so they do not know its reality. Similar to that is the saying of Abu Nakhilah:
*A girl of the wilderness, she did not eat the flatbread.*
*And did not taste from the legumes (baqul) the pistachio.*

S said: Ibn al-Sirafi misspelled in the verse he cited, making *Al-Nuqul* (dried fruits/nuts) which is with Nun, *Al-Baqul* (legumes) with Ba, because of what he and others say: that Abu Nakhilah imagined pistachio is a legume. Abu Nakhilah was not one who didn't know pistachio; someone older than him knew it, namely Abu al-Qamqam ibn Mus'ab al-Asadi. Rather, the meaning of Abu Nakhilah's saying is: that this Bedouin woman does not eat thin bread, and does not snack on pistachios, the goods of city women; she is only fed on the pure and sour milk of milch camels, as Bishr said:
*Sour milk flowing over her fed her ... and pure milk where the pregnant camels are engaged.*
Abu al-Qamqam's verses are:
*Prepare two sandals for the foot of a Hadlaq (big-lipped one).*
*If you do not give him shoes, he will split.*
*A mountain path of sheep, they lived by hanging on [grazing].*
*And say good to him even if you do not validate.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*And thunder and do not rain anything, and flash.*
*You ask me about the good things of pistachio.*
*While I only lived on the grains of the 'Ashraq plant.*
*And on soup of burnt barley.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Farazdaq said:
*We found Nahshal preferred Fuqaym ... like the preference of the son of the pregnant camel over the weaned foal.*
*If they settle at Lasaf they build upon it ... houses of baseness and long humiliation.*
He said: Nahshal and Fuqaym are the two sons of Darim.

S said: Ibn al-Sirafi's saying that Nahshal and Fuqaym are the two sons of Darim indicates that he was poor in insight into the genealogies of the Arabs. Rather, Fuqaym is the nephew (brother's son) of Nahshal; he is Fuqaym ibn Jarir ibn Darim. He left a verse between the two verses without which the meaning of the first verse is not correct. The order of the verses—and they are three—is:
*We found Nahshal preferred Fuqaym ... like the preference of the son of the pregnant camel over the weaned foal.*
*Both young camels [sons] helped what was next to him ... but the difference between them is small.*
*If they settle at Lasaf they build upon it ... houses of baseness and long humiliation.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Malik ibn al-Rayb said:
*Upon me is the blood of the sacrificial camels if you do not part from ... Abu Hardab one day and the companions of Hardab.*
He said: Abu Hardabah was one of the thieves. He used to cut the road (rob), he and Malik ibn al-Rayb and a group with them. The Rajiz says about him:
*Allah saved you from Al-Qasim.*
*From the belly of Falj and Banu Tamim.*
*And from Ghuwayth, opener of baskets.*
*And from Abu Hardabah the sinner.*
*And Malik and his ominous sword.*
He said: He meant by his saying "if you do not part" his riding camel; he meant that it parts from his companions. It is possible he meant camels they had taken, so Malik wanted to take them from them.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*They fought; if only they were blowing into charcoal.*
Ibn al-Sirafi spoke much in explaining this verse without hitting the joint or applying the articulation. He mentioned everything except the meaning of his saying "if you do not part from Abu Hardab," which is the pillar of the verse's meaning, and it is not known except after knowing the story. The story of that was: A man from the Ansar from the people of Medina was appointed over them. He advanced and took Malik and Abu Hardabah. He sent Abu Hardabah away and stayed behind with the group containing Malik. He ordered a servant of his, so he began driving Malik. Malik caught the Ansar's servant unawares—he was wearing the sword—so he snatched it from him then struck him with it until he killed him. Then he attacked the Ansari and killed him. Then he fled until he reached Bahrain, then went to Fars fleeing from that event. He remained residing there until Sa'id ibn Uthman came to him and took him as a companion, so he went out with him. Regarding this story and his parting from Abu Hardabah, Malik says:
*I traveled in the darkness of a night, so the deserts of Humran al-Sharif became before it [the camel], setting.*
*Looking out from Wadi al-Kilab as if she is ... when she ascended from it, a lone gazelle of a herd.*
*Upon me is the blood of the sacrificial camels if you do not part from ... Abu Hardab at night and the companions of Hardab.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Abu Mihjan said:
*O Lord, a naive woman like you among women ... white, I have given her enjoyment by divorce.*
Ibn al-Sirafi erred in attributing this verse to Abu Mihjan. He was deceived by the fact that the author of this verse is a Thaqafi, but he is not Abu Mihjan; rather he is Ghaylan ibn Salamah al-Thaqafi. They are two verses, the second being:
*She did not know what was under the ribs, and deceived her ... from me, the beauty of my companionship and my character.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Salim ibn Darah said:
*I am Ibn Darah, my lineage is known by her ... And is there, O people, any disgrace in Darah?*
*From the stock of Qays, and my maternal uncles are Banu Asad ... the noblest of people, my fire stick ignites among them.*
He said: Darah: Salim's grandfather.

S said: Ibn al-Sirafi erred in that. Darah is the mother of Salim and Abd al-Rahman sons of Darah, a woman from Banu Asad likened for her beauty to the halo (Darah) of the moon.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Ashhab ibn Rumaylah said:
*And how many a brave hero I missed ... and a gambler in winter, generous, digestible [easy-going].*
*So did the day cease so it became night ... and did the stars leave their rising places?*
He said: He says, did the day cease because of his loss and death, and did the stars sink because of the calamity of him? He means: The world; the habit in it is that people perish, and it does not change for the loss of one lost from it, even if he was noble.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*If the masters of Al-Hujaym and Mazin are ... few, then their fools are not few.*
If Ibn al-Sirafi's correctness is little; his confusions are many. Al-Sirafi advanced a verse that should be delayed, and delayed a verse that should be advanced.

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
The verse that should be advanced is his saying: "So did the day cease," which is in the description of a long night. The other verse is an elegy for a killed man, and neither of the two verses relates to the other in meaning. Such poetry, if its story and completion are not known; its meaning does not become clear at all. I will present the verses that clarify the meaning of the two verses for you, then I will mention their story afterwards, Allah willing. The verses are:
*You stayed awake and worries did not sleep from you ... and the old yearning returned to your heart.*
*You struggle with the middle of a dark [night] possessing shadows ... as the sick man struggles with the night.*
*As if its stars are herds of cattle ... appearing in the sky and not moving.*
*So did the day cease so it became night ... and did the stars leave their rising places?*
Up to here is the completion of the description of the length of the night. Then he began to eulogize whom he lost of his people, and mention their loss. As Amr ibn Ma'di Yakrib said:
*How many a righteous brother of mine ... I settled him with my hand in a niche-grave.*
*I did not get anxious nor panic ... and my weeping does not return a fire-stick.*
Returning to the verses of Al-Ashhab:
*And how many a brave hero I missed ... and a gambler in winter, generous, digestible.*
*And refusing [injustice], when he is offered humiliation ... fierce when adversaries oppose.*
*They passed to their way and I sat alone ... fate turning away with me and going straight.*
*As if the accidents of days come ... upon a smooth rock having no scratch.*
Up to here is the complete meaning of the two verses. Then we mention the rest of the verses after mentioning the story, Allah willing.
The story of this poetry—which is the hadith of Rabab ibn Rumaylah—is that Rumaylah was a slave girl of Khalid ibn Malik ibn Rab'i ibn Salma ibn Jandal ibn Nahshal ibn Darim, born among Arabs, they claim she was from the captives of the Arabs. Thawr ibn Harithah ibn Abd al-Mundhir ibn Jandal ibn Nahshal ibn Darim bought her, and he was with her among his camels. He married her, and she bore him: Rabab, Hajn, Al-Ashhab, and Suwayt. They were among the strongest of brothers among the Arabs in tongues and hands, and the most protective of their side. Their wealth increased in Islam. Thawr had bought Rumaylah in the Jahiliyyah. When people went out to the desert from their waters, Rabab used to take a red velvet cloak of his. When people got rain, he would occupy the pools of Al-Samman, take its fringe and place it on the trees of it—meaning I have preceded to this—so no one would approach it, and he would take what he needed and what he didn't need. They got rain, so he did that in the pools of Al-Samman. People from Banu Qatan ibn Nahshal occupied the pools with him. Banu Qatan, Banu Zayd ibn Nahshal, and Banu Manaf ibn Darim were allies. Al-Ahjar were allies over them, and Mukharribah also were with them. A man from Banu Manaf ibn Darim called Samurah ibn Awdah, kunya Abu Karsha'—he is the one Al-Farazdaq says about:
*And Abu Karsha' is not a thief ... but whenever the people steal, he eats.*
The Manafi man came to some of Rabab's troughs and watered his camel. Rabab slapped his camel. He went away angry to those who were there from Banu Qatan, who were Banu Arbad ibn Damrah ibn Jabir ibn Qatan ibn Nahshal. He informed them and they got angry. Evil occurred and the people fought. Rabab ibn Thawr struck Bishr ibn Subayh ibn Arbad ibn Damrah—he is Ibn al-Absiyyah, his mother being the daughter of Ubayy ibn Humam ibn Qurad ibn Makhzum, and Bishr is Abu Badhal—with the pole of his tent. The hair flew from his skull and what was under the skin of his head was crushed, but no blood flowed, and he did not die on the spot; he remained alive. Rabab said:
*I said to him: Patience, Abu Badhal ... Indeed I, by the House of Allah, do not care.*
*That the last of the nights returns.*
Then the two clans separated, and each gathered for his opponent. Banu Qatan said: "O Banu Jandal and O Banu Sakhr and Jarwal, your companion has struck our companion this blow, and we do not know if he will die from it or live. So be fair to us: hand over your companion to us and take our companion and treat him. If he recovers, ask us and we will gift [compensation] to you. If it is the other [death], then he is our killer. If we pardon, we pardon our right, and if we take retaliation or blood money, we take our right." The people refused. So they fought that day of theirs until the night. But Ubayy ibn Ashyam, the brother of Banu Jarwal—and he was their master—went out for a need. Some of Banu Qatan met him, took him, and brought him to their companions. Nahshal ibn Huray said: "O Banu Nahshal, obey me today and disobey me forever." They said: "Yes, we obey you." He said: "This man is not your killer, and he is innocent; his blood is not lawful for you. And his people are the fiercest of those fighting you, so let him go." They said: "Consider your opinion."

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
Nahshal said: "O Abu Asma', we do not care who stands between us and our killer before us. You and your people have fought us denying our right, and Allah has enabled us over you. By Allah, your blood satisfies us more than Banu Rumaylah. By Allah, I will kill you or you will give me what I ask you." He said: "Ask me." He said: "You swear to me by Allah that you will turn Banu Jarwal away from me entirely. If they do not obey you, you will turn away from me with Banu Ashyam. If they do not obey you, you will come to us." He said: "Yes." So he released him under the cover of night. He came to them while they were within sight of each other and said: "Banu Jarwal, turn back. Do you not fear Allah, exposing yourselves against a people seeking their right?" More than seventy men turned back with him. When Banu Sakhr and Banu Jandal saw that, they said: "By Allah, we are wronging our kinsmen, we will not fight them." So the people deserted each other. When Al-Ashhab ibn Rumaylah saw that, he said: "Woe to you! Will you shed your blood for a blow of a stick? By Allah, there is no harm in him [the injured man], so give your people their right." Abu Thawr said: "Far be it! The lock has closed and the key is lost. They have taken a man from your gathering whom they are satisfied with—meaning Abu Asma', not knowing they had released him." They said: "They have released him." Hajn and Rabab said: "By Allah, we will leave, and we will join others besides you and will not give in with our hands." Al-Ashhab ibn Rumaylah kept saying: "Woe to you, will you leave the abode of your people for a blow of a stick that amounted to nothing?" He did not cease until they brought Rabab. They handed him to Qatan and took Abu Badhal from them. He [Abu Badhal] died that night while in their hands, but they hid it. They sent to Abbad ibn Mas'ud ibn Khalid ibn Malik ibn Rab'i, and to Awf and Ma'bad sons of Al-Qa'qa' ibn Ma'bad, offering the blood money. They said: "What is the meaning of blood money when our companion is alive?" They said: "Your companion is not alive." Banu Qatan marched until morning came, traveled a little, then said to Rabab: "Make your will." He said: "By Allah, I had a need from my Lord, but what prevented me from praying more than I prayed was only the fear that they would see that my excess [in prayer] was fear of death. Let a man from you with a strong arm strike me." So they pushed him to a man with a strong arm, they pushed him to Hazimah ibn Bashir Abu Badhal, and he struck his neck. Then they buried him among them. That was during the Fitna before the killing of Uthman. When the people settled under Mu'awiyah, a man said to Ibn Rumaylah: "Your brother only killed their companion by mistake, and they killed your brother intentionally. So seek legal redress against them." So he sought redress against them later before Marwan ibn al-Hakam, and Nashbah ibn Malik ibn Qatad ibn Salma ibn Jandal, and Saqr ibn Malik, brother of Nashbah. Marwan gathered them in Medina. Banu Qatan said: "We killed their companion and there was no authority to seek redress from." So Ibn Rumaylah was given fifty camels to follow [as blood money]. Al-Ashhab ibn Rumaylah said:
*The driving of the white camels did not cease until I drove them ... fifty followed by Abu Badhal.*
Al-Farazdaq said replying to him:
*Be gentle with your people, O liberator of Khalid ... and remember the leading of your brother on the first day.*
*The mongrel was fierce against the clients of his mother ... so they castrated him from the back of the neck with the blade.*
*Marwan knows, when he enacts your blood monies ... at fifty, that your blood monies were not complete.*
Al-Farazdaq also said:
*Rabab called the call of the pregnant woman when he saw ... Banu Qatan shaking the spears so he trembled.*
Al-Ashhab ibn Rumaylah replied to him:
