*O my two eyes, pour tears; who is for your brother ... that you stay awake the full night and panic?*
*And a weeping woman weeping for Rabab, and a sayer ... May Allah reward with good the most chaste and protective.*
*Striking in the distress when the battle heats up ... and feeding when the nursing mothers become hungry.*
*When we intercepted their brother for our brother ... we quenched [our thirst] and did not heal the burning thirst so we would be satisfied.*
*We combined blood while the guest was awaiting hospitality ... and the call of a caller who called us so he made us hear.*
*We extended—and it was a slip of our dreams—... a hand to the children of Damrah, severed.*
*And my people blamed me, and my soul blames me ... for what a viewer said regarding Rabab: He was lost.*
*If my heart were of iron it would have weakened ... and if it were of solid rock it would have cracked.*
*We killed the master of the people, no honor was before him ... and there was no prevention by Al-Ahjar so he would be protected.*
*Did the son of a blacksmith gloat that a calamity befell ... a noble one, while Time did not leave a place of hearing for you?*
*For the killing of a man who heated his weapon against you ... while you were humiliated, growing [grazing] in the saltwort, all of you.*
And he said:
*I see the eye, from the memory of Rabab, as if ... it has ophthalmia, its mote does not accept Kohl.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*May Allah reward my people for an intercessor and seeker ... with the reward of an evildoer when his secrets are tested.*
*They gouged my eye; neither was the 'Uriyy (lion/leader) commanding ... good, nor the sinner forgiving when he was [able].*
*If the clan of Mirdas ibn Hayyan had acted ... the bone would have healed and its splints closed over it.*
*So I was not, in what befell me, the first man ... who committed an event or whom his clans surrendered.*
*He called, when a people called against his brother ... Tumadir, when Tumadir surrendered him.*
*Verily, long have I hoped in you and praised you ... So this is the time of insults, its bird is most ill-omened.*
*My Lord did not make me wretched, nor did my brother disgrace me ... when a star from Tihama set, its setter.*
*You extended [your hand] and left no advance for yourself ... except a loan of misery, that the holder of the loan remembers.*
Al-Ashhab also said regarding that:
*You stayed awake and worries did not sleep from you ... and the old yearning returned to your heart.*
*You struggle with the middle of a dark [night] possessing shadows ... as the sick man struggles with the night.*
*As if its stars are herds of cattle ... appearing in the sky and not moving.*
*So did the day cease so it became night ... and did the stars leave their rising places?*
*And how many a brave hero I missed ... and a gambler in winter, generous, digestible.*
*And refusing [injustice], when he is offered humiliation ... fierce when adversaries oppose.*
*They passed to their way and I sat alone ... fate turning away with me and going straight.*
*As if the accidents of days come ... upon a smooth rock having no scratch.*
*So convey to Banu Salma a message ... for we did not have a blameworthy one from them.*
*They got angry for us and felt compassion for us ... as the loving mother [camel] feels compassion for the stuffed skin (baww).*
*If Nahshal held back, then we ... we have the noble deeds and the root.*
*Let a knower know what was in us ... we have the misery and the noble removal [of clothes/spoils].*
*Is what Banu Subayh say true? ... So Quda'ah or Tamim may know it.*
*Do not their dreams forbid them from wronging us? ... And they have no dreams [minds].*
*I swore by the immigrants of Al-Ghusl, disheveled ... and what the holy sites and Al-Hatim gathered.*
*If calamities gathered between my people ... and the injustice of the root, its pasture is unhealthy.*
*We will surely seek for ourselves women ... who become clear in marriages or become widowed.*
*And dead bodies, the heroes were aborted from them ... thirsty, on their faces is gloom.*
S said: We have prolonged speech in this story, and that is only so the burning thirst of the beneficiary may be healed, so no heat remains in his heart.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Umayyah ibn Abi al-Salt said:
*Perhaps what souls hate of the matter ... has an opening like the undoing of the shackle.*
He said: The pronoun in his saying "lahu furjatun" (it has an opening) refers to "ma" (what). Meaning: For this hated thing there is an opening, i.e., relief. The meaning is clear.

S said: This is a proverbial verse he struck for verses preceding it; the knowledge of its meaning is not complete without them. They are:
*With Ibrahim who fulfilled the vow ... and Isaac, carrier of the wood.*
*His son would not have been patient regarding him ... if he saw him in a group of enemies.*
*He said: O my son, I have vowed you to Allah ... slaughtered, so be patient, may my maternal uncle be your ransom.*
*So the boy answered having said regarding it ... Everything is for Allah without plagiarism.*
*O father, I have rewarded you by Allah ... being pious to Him in every state.*
*So fulfill what you vowed to Allah and hold back ... from my blood that my trousers touch it.*
*And tighten the bonds lest I swerve from the knife ... the swerving of the captive in chains.*
*Indeed I feel pain at the incision, and I ... do not touch the chins possessing beards.*
*And he has a knife imagining in the meat ... cutting, clear like the crescent moon.*
*While he was taking off the shirts from him ... his Lord ransomed him with a great ram.*
*He said: Take it and send your son, indeed I am ... not hating of what you two did.*
*A father fearing [Allah] and another born ... so they flew from Him with a high reputation.*
*Perhaps what souls hate of the matter ... has an opening like the undoing of the shackle.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Aswad ibn Ya'fur said:
*Is it true, O sons of the sons of Salma ibn Jandal ... is your threatening of me in the middle of the assemblies?*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
He said: He meant "O sons of the sons of Salma ibn Jandal." The meaning is clear. They were threatening him because of a horse his son, Al-Jarrah ibn al-Aswad, took belonging to a man from Taym Allah ibn Tha'labah, called the Knight of Al-Asma'. His story with them is long.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Little sufficiency from dependents and children ... going early to the Dini [land/task] then returning.*
What Ibn al-Sirafi mentioned and the news related to it does not avail a wick's worth nor benefit. His saying: "The meaning is clear" might deceive the beneficiary, so he restricts himself to his raving, and does not pursue investigating its meaning and knowing the truth of its story. I will mention what clarifies the meaning, Allah willing.
The story of this poetry was: When Abu Ju'al, the brother of Banu Amr ibn Hanzalah al-Burjumi, and his companions were defeated, and Bakr ibn Wa'il captured them, a man from Banu Taym Allah ibn Tha'labah from Banu al-Jadh'ah—who was the Knight of Al-Asma'—caught up with people from Banu Nahshal, among them Al-Jarrah ibn al-Aswad, Harir ibn Shammar ibn Hadhan ibn Zuhayr ibn Jandal, Rafi' ibn Suhayb ibn Harithah ibn Jandal, Amr ibn Hudayr, and Al-Harith ibn Harir ibn Salma ibn Jandal. He said to them: "Come to me, you are free. Your fighting today pleased me, and I am better for you than thirst." So they answered him. He dismounted to bind them, and Al-Jarrah noticed quality in his horse, so he jumped on its back and escaped on it. The Taymi said to Rafi' and Harir and their companions: "Do you know this man?" They said: "Yes, and we are guards (guarantors) for your horse." When Al-Jarrah came to his father with it, he ordered him to take it to Banu Sa'd, so he hid it in three bellies [clans/valleys]. When Rafi' and Harir and their companions returned to Banu Nahshal, they said: "We are the guards of the Knight of Al-Asma'," and they threatened Al-Jarrah. Banu Jarwal were allies of Banu Salma ibn Jandal against Banu Harithah ibn Jandal. Tayhan ibn Balj returned Rafi' and Harir against Al-Jarrah, until they returned the horse to the Taymi. So Al-Aswad ibn Ya'fur said regarding that:
*There came to me, and I did not fear what they sent ... as a guard, Banu Salma, Harir and Rafi'.*
*They both deprived me every day of a booty ... so I destroyed them, if that were useful.*
*So I followed their rear on the road of Alah ... as it is said a star has fallen, falling successively.*
*And the best of what I give you, and it is its evil ... is a terrifying thing in which are shining swords.*
*I am not giving you an injustice against me ... nor am I withholding a right known to belong to you.*
*If he is guided to me, then I am ... a brother of war, neither a decree-man nor panicking.*
*And I am sharp when my sharpness is sought ... and difficult of leadership, the Qanadi' (calamities) did not please me.*
*And I host the guest as my father advised ... and the neighbor of Abu Tayhan is hungry, starving.*
*So say to Tayhan ibn 'Aqirat Istiha (Son of the one whose rear is wounded) ... Are you persisting, so meeting error, or are you desisting?*
*But Tayhan ibn 'Aqirat Istiha ... has a sin in his affair and consequences.*
*If Tayhan ibn 'Aqirat Istiha wished ... I would have guided him, and for matters there are rising places.*
*And I guard the secret until I return it ... to its people, and evil is ugly, spreading.*
*If you gave Ibn Aswad his right ... a mutilator stood with a razor over your nose.*
*Omani, or possessing two teats, Arabic ... trained, the locations have sharpened her.*
They swore they were the guards of the Taymi, so Al-Aswad gave them the horse itself, and kept her foal. The guards returned to him and threatened him, so he began to say:
*It came to me from the Abna' that Mujashi' ... and the family of Fuqaym and the Karadis agreed.*
*And the clan of Jurays; I said: Jurays suffices you ... a spearhead like the lamp of the night-worshipper, opened.*
Mu'awiyah and Qays, the two sons of Malik ibn Zayd Manat ibn Tamim, are called the two Kardus, so he said Al-Karadis. Jurays is a man from Al-Barajim.
*Al-Asa (the mare) raised him until he rose as if he was ... a meteor in the hands of a horseman burning.*
*In the hands of a boy whose maternal uncle is not a sitter ... Noble, his father is Jandal or Mutlaq.*
And he also said:
*Is it true, O sons of the sons of Salma ibn Jandal ... is your threatening of me in the middle of the assemblies?*
*Why did you not make a pride of your threat ... against the clan of Qa'qa' and the clan of Ibn Habis?*
*For they prevented you from the inheritance of your father ... so the inheritance went to the clever nobles.*
*And they brought you to the bank of the sea, overflowing ... and they left you between shamed and bowing.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Hadrami ibn Amir ibn Mujamma' said:
*And every companion paired with another ... even if she was stingy with him, they will separate.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*And every brother, his brother is parting from him ... by your father's life, except the two Farqad stars.*
He said: He means that every two where one loves the other will be cut off from him, even if he is stingy with him, strictly holding to his brotherhood. In speech resembling this.

S said: What Ibn al-Sirafi mentioned in these two verses hardly heals, unless what is before them is known, for they are a proverb he struck for consolation regarding those of his brothers and clans he was bereaved of. Before them is:
*And a possessor of grief, the soul turned away from him ... beware of the gloaters, and he has grieved me.*
*A brother of trust, when the night becomes dark ... to the twisting of my rope, he sufficed me.*
*I cut my bond from him so his richness sufficed ... so I will not see him and he will not see me.*
*And every companion paired with another ... even if she was stingy with him, they will separate.*
*And every brother, his brother is parting from him ... by your father's life, except the two Farqad stars.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Akhtal said:
*Did your eye lie to you, or did you see at Wasit ... in the darkness of the gloom, from Al-Rabab, a silhouette?*
Ibn al-Sirafi said: Wasit is a place in the regions of Syria (Sham).

S said: Ibn al-Sirafi erred in this. There is no place called Wasit in the regions of Syria. Wasit here is: Wasit of Al-Jazirah. Abu al-Nada informed me saying: The Arabs have seven Wasits: Wasit of Najd, which Khadash ibn Zuhayr mentioned:
*Wasit's pastures and waters have become effaced ... to where its flood ends and its returning flows.*
And Wasit of Hijaz, which Kuthayyir mentioned:
*They strove; as for the family of Azzah in the morning ... they departed, but Wasit is remaining.*
And Wasit of Al-Jazirah, which Al-Akhtal mentioned in the verse that passed just now, and in his other verse:
*Wasit of the family of Radwa is effaced, then Nabtal ... then the meeting place of Al-Hurrayn, so patience is more beautiful.*
And Wasit of Yamama, which Al-A'sha mentioned in a poem. And Wasit of Iraq. And I have forgotten two.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Farwa ibn Musayk said:
*If we are defeated, we have been defeaters of old ... and if we are conquered, we are not ones to be conquered always.*
*And cowardice is not our nature, but ... it is our deaths and the turn of others.*
He said: His saying "If we are defeated, we have been defeaters of old" says: If we are defeated in this battle, we have defeated people before it many times. With speech resembling this which does not indicate the meaning of the verse.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*Far it is! That you see the settled land ... the decreed fate came before it.*
It is far for the beneficiary to know the meaning of his saying "If we are defeated" and why he admitted defeat despite the shame in it—if the story is not known. I had mentioned to you that if poetry is related to a story, the people of meanings cannot extract its meaning except by it.
The story of this poetry was: The idol of Murad was in A'la and An'am, which are two clans of Murad. Nobles of Murad said: "Why are our gods not in our noses (chiefs)?" So they wanted to snatch the gods from them. They went out from them and came to Banu al-Harith and sought protection with them. Murad sent to Banu al-Harith: "Expel our brothers from your abode, and send us two men from you so we may kill them for our companion"—for Murad was seeking a blood revenge from Banu al-Harith. When Al-Husayn ibn Yazid ibn Qanan saw that Murad insisted on demanding their companions, he feared them and knew he had no power against them. Murad, if a man of theirs was killed, would kill two men for him, and they would not accept blood money except doubled.
So Al-Husayn ibn Yazid, who was the leader of Banu al-Harith, marched to Umayr Dhu Marran. He asked him to ride with him to Arhab to make peace between him and them, and ask them for an alliance against Murad. Al-Husayn said: "O assembly of Arhab, I am not happier about the destruction of Murad than you." Arhab used to raid Murad before that. So Arhab allied with him, and they set out.
Al-Husayn ibn Yazid ibn al-Harith marched, and the Bedouins of Hamdan marched, led by Yazid ibn Thumamah al-Arhabi al-Asamm. And Murad approached as if they were a black lava field, crawling a crawl, led by Al-Harith ibn Zabyan al-Muthallam, whose kunya was Abu Qays al-An'ami. They fought at a place called Al-Razm next to Aya', a fierce battle. Banu al-Harith were shaken. Al-Husayn turned to them and said: "O Banu al-Harith, by Allah, if you do not strike the faces of Murad with swords until they clear the courtyard for you, I will leave you to be spoil among the Arabs." Then he turned to the Bedouins of Hamdan and said: "O assembly of Hamdan, patience, patience! Let not Murad say we sought refuge in the numbers of Hamdan and their might but they did not avail us."

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
The people fought a fierce battle. Al-Husayn was killed. Both sides were patient. Banu al-Harith prepared to flee, and Arhab was shaken—they had brought the women with them and placed them behind their backs. When Arhab saw the women's anklets showing for flight, they returned to fight and said: "We will not flee until Yaghuth flees." They were patient against the people, and Banu al-Harith were patient against them. Murad was defeated, and killing spread among them. They captured women from their women, so Islam arrived while they were in the houses of Hamdan. On that day Al-Muthallam, the leader of Murad, was killed, and Aziz, Qays, and Nimran. It was named the Muradi [Day]. Al-Husayn ibn Yazid al-Harithi was killed on that day. Yazid ibn Thumamah al-Arhabi said regarding that:
*The tribe attacked in the morning knew that I ... at the side of Aya' was not a recoiling coward.*
*I left Aziz with birds hopping around him ... and I covered Qays with the edge of a sharp white [sword].*
*And Nimran, I settled a grudge from him ... upon rage on the day of the intertwining of tribes.*
*Ukkab, I healed the soul from him, and Harith ... with a penetrating [spear] in his chest possessing barbs.*
*And I destroyed Sumayy in the attack with our spears ... and he encountered a quick death, not delayed.*
S said: If the meaning of the story is not known, the meaning of the verse is not known:
*If we are defeated, we have been defeaters of old ... and if we are conquered, we are not ones to be conquered always.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-Nabigha al-Ja'di said:
*Except like Mu'arrid, the one stripping his two Bakrs ... he insults me wrongfully.*
He said: It means, but Mu'arrid circulates among the tribes insulting me. Mu'arrid is not Suwar, nor is he the exception; so it is an exception meaning 'but'. His saying "the one stripping his two Bakrs": dual of Bakr, and the Bakr among camels is like the youth among people.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*He strikes him sometimes, and sometimes throws him down ... as if he honors him or binds him.*
Ibn al-Sirafi spoke on this verse in a way that suggests he hit the mark in it, and brought the intent of the beneficiary. But his arrow missed, for he did not mention Mu'arrid from which tribe he is, leaving him unknown. And he mentioned that the two Bakrs here are the dual of Bakr, and that it is the youth of camels. Mu'arrid here is a man from Banu al-Harish; he ordered two men from Banu al-Harish to insult Al-Nabigha, and they were his two Bakrs. This is the meaning of his saying: "Except like Mu'arrid, the one stripping his two Bakrs."

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Al-A'sha said:
*And the people of Jaww, it came upon them ... so it corrupted their life so they perished (baru).*
*And a time passed over Wabar ... so Wabar perished (hamadat) openly.*
He said: Wabar, they claimed, was a city the Jinn inhabited. And it is said: Wabar is a place in Al-Dahna. Some claimed it is a land where there were wild camels and many palm trees with no one to remove their stumps or harvest their fruit; and that a man fell into it, rode a stallion from those camels, and went towards the land of his people, and the camels followed him.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*You have brought, O Bahshar, the calamity ... where the sand-heaps of the well are full.*
Ibn al-Sirafi spoke on this verse and increased, so he became confused in it and confused [others], then brought a hadith of two slave girls with lies and falsehood. The correct view is that Wabar is on the side of Al-Shihr, the end of the sands of Banu Sa'd ibn Zayd Manat ibn Tamim. That is because Wabar ibn Amim ibn Lawidh ibn Sam ibn Nuh settled it, so it was named after him.

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Mu'awiyah ibn Malik ibn Ja'far said:
*I repaired the rift of Ka'b, and they were ... from hatred, they had become ankles (Ka'ab).*

S said: Ibn al-Sirafi struck two verses into a verse, making them one verse. The correct version is:
*I repaired the rift of Ka'b which had perished ... and the rift was not counted as repairable.*
*So their heel (Ka'b) became a heel (high), and they were ... from hatred, called ankles (low).*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Ru'ba said:
*Indeed I feared that I would see drought.*
*In this year of ours after it had been fertile.*
*When the locusts (Daba) crawled over the high grounds.*
*And the wind blew with it a blowing.*
*Leaving what the locusts left a wasteland.*
*And the straw and the Halfa grass, so it inflamed.*
*Like the torrent when it flows wide.*

S said: Ibn al-Sirafi imagined that all Rajaz poems belong to Ru'ba because Ru'ba was a Rajiz; this is a generalization in him. The verses are not by Ru'ba; rather, they are from the stray Rajaz whose author is unknown. The verses he brought are mostly defective. The correct version is:
*Indeed I hope to see drought.*
*In this year of yours after it had been fertile.*
*When the locusts crawled over the high grounds.*
*And the wind blew with dust that blew.*
*Leaving what the locusts left a wasteland.*
*And the straw and the Halfa grass, so it inflamed.*
*Like the torrent when it flows wide.*
And the completion of the verses, and the meaning of the verse is not complete without them, is:
*When you see the old camel with much hair*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*And the sixth [year camel], the lusty, the loving.*
*From lack of pasture, it has fallen down.*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Khadash ibn Zuhayr said:
*No bowls and no horsemen raiding ... except your burping at the ovens.*
*You are unknown, unlawful is your dweller ... and in wars you are slingshots, blind.*
He said: Khadash satirized with this poetry a group from Banu Sahm, because of a race that was between him and them.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*The tribe at Al-Khabur is not defended when they are frightened ... except by horsemen like Ibn Humran.*
I had mentioned to you in several places: that whoever is not precise about the genealogies of the Arabs and their days (history), and flows into explaining such poetry—targets himself for the tongue of the critic. Ibn al-Sirafi erred here from several aspects: One is that he mentioned Khadash addressed this poetry to a group from Banu Sahm, whereas he addressed it to a group from Banu Taym al-Adram. Another is that he mentioned the race was between Khadash and them, whereas the race was between Banu al-Irqah from Taym al-Adram and Kuraz ibn Rabi'ah ibn Amr ibn Amir, who is from Khadash's clan. Furthermore, he did not know the story so the meaning would become clear and the beneficiary healed.
The story of this poetry was: The first thing that stirred between Quraysh and Banu Amir ibn Sa'sa'ah was that Kuraz ibn Rabi'ah ibn Amr ibn Amir ibn Rabi'ah ibn Amir ibn Sa'sa'ah bet Usayd, Amr, and Abdullah sons of Al-Irqah, from Banu Taym ibn Ghalib—who is Taym al-Adram—on a horse of theirs called Al-Barq. The stake (Al-Siq) was thirty like it with it, none of them possessing shoes, nor *Hira'* (?), nor refusing, nor club-footed, nor having a defect. They made the limit and the track up to Kuraz. He made the limit between Al-Sajsaj to Dhat al-Falj from the middle of Kusht, and made the end of the track the whiteness of Rukbah. His people blamed him, so he said: "By Allah, I do not fear anything for you from him: He was never suckled by a pregnant camel, nor climbed in any guarded place ever, and he enters the morning with his full hair. However, he had a bruise he got when he was a foal, then it did not cease to be in oil (treatment), and today he is a four-year-old. If it opens up before he runs a mile, he will come first, and if it stays as it is, then I do not know."
So they sent the two horses. Al-Mujalid ibn Zuhayr ibn Rabi'ah ibn Amr ibn Amir mounted Kuraz's horse. He did not run a mile until the bruise opened up, so he came first. Al-Barq died at Rukbah. So he took the stake (Al-Siq). They pleaded to him by the womb of Majd bint Taym ibn Ghalib, who is the mother of Banu Rabi'ah ibn Amir ibn Sa'sa'ah, but he refused to return the Siq. They stayed for nearly two years. Then Banu al-Irqah rode out and met Usayd ibn Malik, Amr ibn Malik, and Uthman ibn Usayd from Banu Amir ibn Rabi'ah at the bottom of Al-Aqiq with camels of theirs, among which was a young she-camel, boiling (fast), called Al-Inab, ten months pregnant. They drove the camels. Uthman ibn Usayd met it, scaring it with his garment, and sent the slave girl towards his father and uncle seeking help. His father rode an old mare, and his uncle rode its daughter, a difficult mare. When he caught up with the people, Amr ibn Malik said: "Inform us who you are?" They said: "Quraysh." They said: "Which of them?" They said: "Banu al-Irqah." They said: "Was there any event?" They said: "No, except the Day of Al-Barq." He said to them: "Hold Al-Inab, hold the milch-camel, the milch-camel of one who does not betray." Amr said to them: "No, by Allah, you will not suckle from it a front teat nor a back one." He said: "We do not suckle camels, but we milk them." He charged at him and killed him. Usayd ibn Malik charged at Usayd ibn al-Irqah and killed him. He said regarding that:
*Indeed, like that I strike the armed man ... and the namesake will not be miserable by me.*
That was the Day of Al-Inab. Khadash ibn Zuhayr said regarding that:
*We turn the armed men onto their chins ... when it is a day with a long tail.*
*Such is Time and its changing ... and those are the horsemen of the Day of Al-Inab.*
Then raiding and fighting occurred between them after that. So Khadash ibn Zuhayr said regarding that:
*Convey to Abu Kanaf if you pass by him ... and Al-Abjaran and Wahb and Ibn Manzur.*
*No bowls and no horsemen raiding ... except your burping at the ovens.*
*Then attend to us when our eyes turn red ... in every day that removes the skulls, famous.*
*You will meet horsemen, neither inclining nor unarmed ... nor bulky ones, defecating in the houses.*
*You will meet Usayd and Amr and their cousin ... Warqa' in the disheveled raiding group.*
*From the family of Kuraz, the morning of fright, they were known ... at the fighting, [belonging] to a corner and a joy.*
*They drive their peers in every battlefield ... stabbing and striking like splitting with saws.*
*So ask horsemen of yours on the day of Dhu Saraf ... about you, and your horsemen on the day of Al-Ya'amir.*

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
*There runs with us every [horse] wrapped in its lower parts ... and every disheveled [mare], running fast in the soft ground.*
*Nay, by the Lord of the young camels dancing with us ... the evening of the departure, like boats.*
*You shall not be left while we have not tested your bravery ... and we have not raided you the strike of the raiders.*
*Until we make you taste a strike with a pure ... Indian [sword] and fighting that is not false.*
*The insulters, while without me are the peaks of Hadan ... and the deed is snatching and the saying is transmitted.*
*You are unknown, unlawful is your dweller ... and in wars you are slingshots, blind.*
*You do not cease being at the doors of meanness ... helping each other in it as long as the gazelle wags its tail.*
*As if you are Nabatean women at a farm ... peeling noses, toothless, thick-clothed.*
*You see their chests brown, narrowed ... and in their lower parts spreading and tucking up.*
*When they are scattered at the heights, throwing them down are ... blue spearheads and white cutting swords.*
*Their last call their first in panic ... and the horses are reluctant and death is cautioned.*
*And the excluded ones when hardship circles us ... and the honored ones when ease circles.*
*And the ones carrying them in every battlefield ... in which are captivity and killing and dusting [in dirt].*

Ibn al-Sirafi said: Ziyad ibn Wasil said:
*So when our voices became clear ... they wept and ransomed us with fathers.*
He said: He means that when they recognized their voices, they wept to them so they might rescue them, and they ransomed them with their fathers.

S said: This is the place of the proverb:
*O blower of the evil of hadith, the lie ... Suffices you of making [camels] kneel, the bending of the knees.*
Ibn al-Sirafi lied in explaining this verse and did not know little or much of it. How could they ride to them to rescue them when they were captives as he claimed? The meaning of the verse is: Ziyad boasted in these verses of the fathers of his people and their mothers from Banu Amir, and that they had tested well in their wars and their assistance. When they returned to their encampments and were with their women, and they [the women] recognized their voices, they ransomed them [said: May my father be your ransom], because they had tested well in the wars. The verses indicate the correctness of this meaning. The first of them—and they are by Ziyad ibn Wasil al-Sulami—is:
*The women of Banu Amir strengthened us ... so we branded the men with a humiliating disgrace.*
*And we are their sons on the day of the slapping ... when we face the people, rough and rugged.*
*With a striking like the lapping of male wolves ... you hear for the skulls in it a ringing.*
*And shooting upon every buzzing [bow] ... it returns the left and gives the right.*
*And we were with the horses until they matured ... the youth of men, and delighted the eyes.*
*And when our voices became clear ... they loved [us] and ransomed us with fathers.*

This is the end of *The Delight of the Man of Letters*. I have deposited in it the mention of what Ibn al-Sirafi stumbled in regarding his explanation of the verses of Sibawayh's Book. I clarified it and corrected it, and guided the beneficiary to its correctness and directed him. Even if its size is small, its knowledge is abundant. Whoever wakes up and looks with the eye of fairness will acknowledge the superiority of many of the successors over the predecessors. But most people stumble in the tails of confusion and falling, and lack of acquisition and clarity, and abundance of mixing and raving. As for the people of verification:
*We used to count them as few ... and they have become fewer than few.*
I will follow it, from the best of what I create, with what increases benefit, and the hearing shakes for its narration, in fulfillment of the conditions of service, and performance of the right of the favor. And Allah is the Helper upon what is in the intention and ambition; He is Vast in Mercy.
*May Allah keep for us our master, and may ... our days never cease to be new in his shadow.*
*Indeed the Chief, for the favors he bestows ... makes lawful the hunting of knowledge in my sanctuary.*
*Nothing is more beautiful than a favor of his that abounded ... my thanks for it is the thanks of the meadow of Al-Hazn for the drizzle.*

End of the original manuscript, which I symbolized with 'A'.
The book is completed, and praise be to Allah as He deserves, and blessings upon His Prophet Muhammad and his family. That was on Sunday, the twenty-ninth of Sha'ban, the year five hundred and ninety-two. And praise be to Allah alone, and His blessings upon our master Muhammad His Prophet and his pure family and His peace. And Allah is sufficient for us, and the best Disposer of affairs. The collation was completed with the praise of Allah and His help.

And the end of the Baghdadi manuscript, which I symbolized with 'B'.

book_title: The Delight of the Man of Letters in Refuting Ibn al-Sirafi's Explanation of the Verses of Sibawayh (The author critiques Ibn al-Sirafi (d. 368 AH) in his explanation of some verses of Sibawayh's Book (d. 180 AH))
text:
This book was completed with the help of Allah Almighty, at the hand of the one in need of the mercy of his Forgiving Lord: Abd al-Qadir ibn Umar ibn Bayazid ibn al-Hajj Ahmad al-Baghdadi. He wrote it for himself, and for whom Allah wills after him. The writing began on Sunday, and ended in the forenoon of Monday, the twenty-ninth of the blessed month of Shawwal, of the months of the year one thousand and seventy-eight of the Hijra. The date of the original from which I wrote it was Sunday, the twenty-ninth of Sha'ban, the year five hundred and ninety-two. Thus I saw it dated. And Allah is sufficient for us, and the best Disposer of affairs.
In the margin: So the duration of writing was nine days, with occupations hindering it. And praise be to Allah for it.
